title: Writers Meet and Greet! (Virtual for now)
description:
A chance for this group to have a virtual meet up!

An open discussion on what we need from the group and how often we want to meet.

Potential brainstorm for an in-person outing as a writing stress reliever!

Ideas will be very much welcomed : )

group.name: Women of Colour Science Fiction & Fantasy Writers Group

title: Feedback Session!
description: A chance for us to get feedback on our work!

group.name: Women of Colour Science Fiction & Fantasy Writers Group

title: Writers Meet and Greet! (Virtual for now)
description:
A chance for new and current members to introduce themselves and their writing to the group!

Agenda

* We'll start with an introduction from everyone, how they got into writing and where they are with their writing journey.
* Then we'll outline what you need from the group i.e. beta readers, critique partners, feedback sessions.
* Set a date and plan for the next meet-up!

group.name: Women of Colour Science Fiction & Fantasy Writers Group

title: French conversation with a native tutor
description:
"To improve your fluency, to get more vocabulary, knowledge and understanding of the French, the French language and France"

The class occurs weekly and lasts 90 minutes (small group - maximum of 6 attendees). It is conducted by a French native, experimented professional, who enjoys handing over his passion for his country and his mother tongue.

The class is interactive and made of chats, exercises or games. The tuitor may use supports and will help students to improve their language by kindly correcting their potential mistakes.

Please be aware that the whole class unfolds in French.

As an introductory offer, a charge of £5 is due at the beginning of the class.

Big Fernand is a restaurant located in central London, close to Tottenham Court Road Station (http://bigfernand.com/restaurants/londres (http://bigfernand.com/restaurants/londres/)/)

title: Thematic Learning session 1: What is "La France"?
description:
This session is a part of a 3 session Thematic Learning set occurring on Saturday 11th, Saturday 18th and Saturday 25th November.

The objective of this set is to give the pupils the base of knowledge about the French Culture in order to the fit in a French environment.

Session 1: What is “La France”?

Where does France come from? How has it been built up? How does it work - or not?

3 hours of an interactive class to improve your knowledge about what make France.

You will understand, by some meaningful presentations, exercises or games, the main line of its history, the essential parts of its geography and the inner working of its political and administrative organisation. Then you will be able to better appreciate how France goes.

The sessions are based on an interactive learning directed and fed by a French native tutor and experimented professional who had been working for more than fifteen years in Public Relations and Institutions in France.

Each session lasts 3 hours and consists in a combination of rundowns, exercises and talks which makes the pupils assimilating the content of the lessons.

Be aware that the whole class unfolds in French.

To guarantee the performance of the learning experience, the number of attendees is included between a minimum of 2 attendees and a maximum of 4.

You can book for one, two or three of them.

Notice that a charge of £50 per session is due, payable in advance (£80 for 2 sessions booked, £100 for 3)

title: Speak French at the supermarket
description:
You want to improve your "daily French"?

Then we are going to experience concrete situations during Summer time. Today, we are going at the supermarket and we will do everything in French.

**THE SESSION:**
This is a face-to-face conversation based session lasting 90 minutes run by a French native & professional tutor (more than 6 years in London).

The whole session happens in French and is dedicated to French speakers with a mixed level (from Intermediate to advanced) (if not sure, send a message to the organiser).

The tutor will lead the session in a public environment. He will help you to structure and improve your phrasing, and to develop your understanding.

Of course, attendees will interact and be able to ask questions.

We will meet at the place at the begining of the session. The tutor will give you a sheet with adapted vocabulary. Please bring a notebook and a pen to be able to write done things.

We will end the session with a chit-chat on site or a cafe nearby.

**IMPORTANT**
If you are new to our Meet Up, please send ASAP an email at frenchlondonexperience at gmail dot com to introduce yourself, to check your level, to confirm your space, to get the Bank details for payment and to be able to get the text.

**PRICING:**
You can pay each time or by block (then you save money)
This is included in the Conversation Class offer
\- £15 per session \(to be paid by bank transfer in advance or in cash at the begining of the class \- Bank details on request\)
\- £60 for 6 sessions \(to be used within 3 months \- to be paid in advance by bank transfer \- Bank details on request\)

If, after your first attendance, you decide to subscribe to the offer of £60 for 6 classes, you add £45 and then you incorporate your first class in the subscription.

The pricing is made to encourage you to attend more regularly as improvements will come with regularity.

**TERMS & CONDITIONS**
If you are to join, you are more than welcome to sign up. But, please, if you have an unforeseen hitch, up date your status as soon as possible. As there are only 6 spaces, if you don't turn up, someone else can't join. Thanks for helping.

For last minute cancellation, a message would be much appreciated. Fees will be requested or not refunded for late cancellation (less than 4 hours before the start). People who don't turn may be banned.

Follow French London Experience

Website: [www.frenchlondonexperience.com](http://www.frenchlondonexperience.com/)

title: Speak French in Queen's Park
description:
We weekly meet at Queen's park cafe and speak French together. It is a friendly opportunity to speak French and to ask questions to a French native as well.

**THE SESSION:**
This is an in person French conversation session lasting 90 minutes run by a French native & professional tutor (more than 6 years in London).

This is dedicated for any French speaker / learner with an Intermediate level or above. Attendees need to have some bases in French and a conversation level as the whole sessions is in French. If you are not sure, send a message (in French) to the organiser.

This is a very small group session: maximum of 6 attendees (minimum of 2). So you will speak directly to the tutor who enjoys handing over his passion for his country and his mother tongue. He will support you along the way to improve your speech flow.

The event consists of conversation and chats.

**IMPORTANT**
If you are new to our Meet Up, please send ASAP an email at frenchlondonexperience at gmail dot com to introduce yourself, to check your level, to confirm your space and to get the Bank details for payment.

**PRICING:**
£10 per session (to be paid by bank transfer in advance or in cash at the begining of the session - Bank details on request)

**TERMS & CONDITIONS**
If you are to join, you are more than welcome to sign up. But, please, if you have an unforeseen hitch, up date your status as soon as possible.

As there are only 6 spaces, if you don't turn up, someone else can't join. Thanks for helping.

For last minute cancellation, a message would be much appreciated. Fees will be requested or not refunded for late cancellation (less than 4 hours before the start). People who don't turn may be banned.

title: [online] FRENCH CONVERSATION CLASS (Rusty Intermediate) with a native tutor
description:
You want to improve your fluency, your pronunciation and your French skills? You want to get more vocabulary, knowledge and understanding of French, the French and France? You want to speak on various topics with the support of a French native tutor?

Each week, we come up to a different theme. It pushes your conversation skills up. It helps you to speak about many topics and to interact in French in multiple contexts.

Regular attendees learn a lot, make improvements and are able to have a chat about numerous topic!

The bonus, you will be able to ask questions to an authentic French native!

**THE CLASS:**
This is an online conversation class lasting 60 minutes run by a French native & professional tutor (more than 6 years in London).

We will use "Zoom" for the session (link visible on Meet Up as soon as you sign to the session)

This is a Conversation Class dedicated to French learners who struggle to have a spontaneous conversation. If you think your French is rusty, if you feel not really comfortable to interact among a group of other French speakers, this class is for you (if not sure, send a message to the organiser).

The class goes on an adapted pace with a first part dedicated to a chit-chat and then we'll focus on a short text to learn about French culture and the language.

We approach the theme, read a short text ((you get a copy for the session by email - see below), speak, learn vocabulary and things about French culture. The theme is always linked to French, the French and France. At the end, we wrap up and keep a few minutes for some miscellaneous questions.

After the class, you will get an email with a list of vocabulary (some words / expressions seen along the class).

This is a very small group class: maximum of 4 attendees and a minimum of 2. So you will speak directly to the tutor.

During the class, the tutor helps you to structure and improve your phrasing, and to develop your understanding.

**IMPORTANT**
If you are new to our Meet Up, please send ASAP an email at frenchlondonexperience at gmail dot com to introduce yourself, to check your level, to confirm your space, to get the Bank details for payment and to be able to get the text

title: Let's sing iconic French songs!
description:
Everyone knows one or another very famous French song!!!

Aux Champs Elysées, Douce France, La Vie en Rose, A la Claire Fontaine, Sur le Pont d'Avignon, Prendre un Enfant par la Main, and of course the famed Malbrough s'en-va-en guerre or some "variété française"

Curious?

We will sing some of them as an amateur French choir!!!
We will mostly sing a capella in a friendly atmosphere.
The tutor will bring lyrics and help you to get the meanings.

In the session, we will learn 4 or 5 songs that every French fellow knows. The idea is to gain a bit of the French culture, not necessarily the one you get in books, but the one that French people have.

Furthermore, singing is an amazing and efficient way to improve the pronunciation.

Please, bring what you need to be confortable in the park and during the whole session (water, rug, jumper, cushion, scarve...).

Feel free to come with a guest.

Once more, it is an amateur and friendly session. The goal is more
linguistic than musical. All welcome. No specific requirement, only to speak and read a bit of French.

**THE SESSION:**
This is a face-to-face conversation based session lasting 90 minutes run by a French native & professional tutor (more than 6 years in London).

The whole session happens in French and is dedicated to French speakers with a mixed level (from Intermediate to advanced) (if not sure, send a message to the organiser).

**IMPORTANT**
If you are new to our Meet Up, please send ASAP an email at frenchlondonexperience at gmail dot com to introduce yourself, to check your level, to confirm your space, to get the Bank details for payment and to be able to get the text.

**PRICING:**

This is included in the Conversation Class offer
\- £15 per session \(to be paid by bank transfer in advance or in cash at the begining of the class \- Bank details on request\)
\- £60 for 6 sessions \(to be used within 3 months \- to be paid in advance by bank transfer \- Bank details on request\)

title: Let's sing iconic French songs!
description:
Everyone knows one or another very famous French song!!!

Aux Champs Elysées, Douce France, La Vie en Rose, A la Claire Fontaine, Sur le Pont d'Avignon, Prendre un Enfant par la Main, and of course the famed Malbrough s'en-va-en guerre or some "variété française"

Curious?

We will sing some of them as an amateur French choir!!!
We will mostly sing a capella in a friendly atmosphere.
The tutor will bring lyrics and help you to get the meanings.

In the session, we will learn 4 or 5 songs that every French fellow knows. The idea is to gain a bit of the French culture, not necessarily the one you get in books, but the one that French people have.

Furthermore, singing is an amazing and efficient way to improve the pronunciation.

Please, bring what you need to be confortable in the park and during the whole session (water, rug, jumper, cushion, scarve...).

Feel free to come with a guest.

Once more, it is an amateur and friendly session. The goal is more
linguistic than musical. All welcome. No specific requirement, only to speak and read a bit of French.

**THE SESSION:**
This is a face-to-face conversation based session lasting 90 minutes run by a French native & professional tutor (more than 6 years in London).

The whole session happens in French and is dedicated to French speakers with a mixed level (from Intermediate to advanced) (if not sure, send a message to the organiser).

**IMPORTANT**
If you are new to our Meet Up, please send ASAP an email at frenchlondonexperience at gmail dot com to introduce yourself, to check your level, to confirm your space, to get the Bank details for payment and to be able to get the text.

**PRICING:**
You can pay each time or by block (then you save money)
This is included in the Conversation Class offer
\- £15 per session \(to be paid by bank transfer in advance or in cash at the begining of the class \- Bank details on request\)
\- £60 for 6 sessions \(to be used within 3 months \- to be paid in advance by bank transfer \- Bank details on request\)

If, after your first attendance, you decide to subscribe to the offer of £60 for 6 classes, you add £45 and then you incorporate your first class in the subscription.

The pricing is made to encourage you to attend more regularly as improvements will come with regularity.

**TERMS & CONDITIONS**
If you are to join, you are more than welcome to sign up. But, please, if you have an unforeseen hitch, up date your status as soon as possible.

For last minute cancellation, a message would be much appreciated. Fees will be requested or not refunded for late cancellation (less than 4 hours before the start). People who don't turn may be banned.

Follow French London Experience
[http://www.facebook.com/frenchlondonexperience/](http://www.facebook.com/frenchlondonexperience/)
[https://www.instagram.com/frenchlondonexperience/](https://www.instagram.com/frenchlondonexperience/)
[https://twitter.com/FLE_Christian](https://twitter.com/FLE_Christian)
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0ZB8-AhXTeqNF9MwEySmeg

Website: [www.frenchlondonexperience.com](http://www.frenchlondonexperience.com/)

title: Summer FRENCH CONVERSATION CLASS (mixed levels) with a native tutor
description:
You want to push up your fluency, your pronunciation and your French skills? You want to get more vocabulary, knowledge and understanding of French, the French and France? You want to speak on various topics with the support of a French native tutor?

Along the Summer Classes, we will use support of games to push your conversation skills up. It helps you to speak about many topics and to interact in French in multiple contexts.

Regular attendees learn a lot, make improvements and are able to have a chat about numerous topic!

The bonus, you will be able to ask questions to an authentic French native!

This class is for French speakers with various levels, from Rusty Intermediate to Advanced.

**THE CLASS:**
This is a face-to-face conversation class lasting 90 minutes run by a French native & professional tutor (more than 6 years in London).

The whole class happens in French and is dedicated to French speakers with various levels, from Rusty Intermediate to Advanced (if not sure, send a message to the organiser). The tutor helps you to structure and improve your phrasing, and to develop your understanding.

During the class, first, we dedicate some time for a little introductory chat. Then, we approach the theme, read a text (you get a copy for the session), speak, learn vocabulary and things about French culture. The theme is always linked to French, the French and France. At the end, we wrap up and keep a few minutes for some miscellaneous questions.

After the class, you will get an email with a list of vocabulary (some words / expressions seen along the class).

**IMPORTANT**
If you are new to our Meet Up, please send ASAP an email at frenchlondonexperience at gmail dot com to introduce yourself, to check your level, to confirm your space and to get the Bank details for payment.

**PRICING:**
You can pay each time or by block (then you save money)
\- £15 per session \(to be paid by bank transfer in advance or in cash at the beginning of the class \- Bank details on request\)
\- £60 for 6 sessions \(to be used within 3 months \- to be paid in advance by bank transfer \- Bank details on request\)

If, after your first attendance, you decide to subscribe to the offer of £60 for 6 classes, you add £45 and then you incorporate your first class in the subscription.

The pricing is made to encourage you to attend more regularly as improvements will come with regularity.

**TERMS & CONDITIONS**
If you are to join, you are more than welcome to sign up. But, please, if you have an unforeseen hitch, up date your status as soon as possible. As there are only 6 spaces, if you don't turn up, someone else can't join. Thanks for helping.

For last minute cancellation, a message would be much appreciated. Fees will be requested or not refunded for late cancellation (less than 4 hours before the start). People who don't turn may be banned.

Follow French London Experience

title: [online] FLE Book Club
description:
Our very own book club is dedicated to Non Native French Speakers who want to take advantage of this experience to refine their French skills. Members must have at least an Intermediate level in French.

The whole session will be in French!

We will read books in French, books by French speaking writers.

We meet once a month (except July and December) for 1 hour / 1,5 hour and will talk (in French) about the book we will be reading.

The idea is to read a book (the same book for the whole group) on a slow pace, to be able to absorb most of it. We may adapt the pace on our way.

Along the session, we will talk about the writer, plot, story, characters, topics on one hand and about comprehension of the text, phrasing and vocabulary on the other hand.

We may read some passages during sessions as well. And of course, we will share our impressions and find out more about the themes.

The book club is a long-distance journey. Then, if you decide to join, you commit to a regular attendance for a few months at least!

Cost :
2 options :
£15 per session,
£60 for 5 months

When you sign up to one session, the payment (£15) will be processed through Paypal.

If you choose the option £60 for 5 months, please send me a message for details and make your payment (£60) by Bank transfer. Once payment processed, the organiser will put you on the list.

Once booked and paid, get the book as it is better to know about it if you are to attend the Book Club session.

title: First Chichester Writers' Meet Up
description:
Hi all,

Hope everyone's well!

So I've confirmed the details for the first meet up next week and really looking forward to it.

Location - We'll be heading to The Old Cross in North Street, Chichester (transport info to be added as a separate comment).

Please do update your 'attending' status if you can't make it!

As this is the first time we're meeting up, I thought it might be nice to keep it informal and go the pub. I have a pretty good idea of how to structure the meet ups moving forward in terms of quiet writing time followed by the chance to stay and socialise, but for this first one I figured it would be nice to familiarise ourselves and get an idea of what people would like from a Chichester Writers' group.

I was part of a similar group in Brighton and I know how beneficial it can be to have a specific place/ community to focus on your writing - so looking to replicate it here and meet some likeminded people!

They'll be a sign on the table - I have optimistically booked a table for 12 so all being well we should stick out a little.

I have noted whose currently attending and the website will automatically cap people from attending in the unlikely event we hit more than 12 - so please do check before bringing a friend etc.

Finally, if anyone is set on writing during the first session then please do bring your equipment, and we can have a writing end of the table, but I think as mentioned this first session is probably more of an icebreaker!

Hope to see you there,

David

title: Writers' Meet Up
description:
Hi all!
Thanks again to all who came for a really fun first meet up. I'm pleased to say we will be at Sit and Sip Chichester next week. We'll be doing quiet writing time from 7-8pm followed by drinks/ socialising for anyone who wants to stay afterwards.
Thanks!

title: Writers' Meet Up
description:
*Bar Fifty Four*

Hi all!

Thank you to everyone who attended today's session!

Next week we'll be at Bar Fifty Four in North Street, Chichester (PO19 1NQ).

A couple of us sniffed it out after today's meet and they have a quiet seating area booked for us!

*NO FURTHER SPACES AVAILABLE FOR THIS WEEK*

As this is a trial venue, we will be limited to 10 spots tonight and those places have now been filled. We will be extending the number of attendees moving forward!

Cheers again,

title: Writing in Fellowship
description:
This meetup will be a informal write together / writing in fellowship and then a short social/chat afterwards over a coffee.

It will be at the National Theatre starting at 10am. During the time please feel free to arrive or leave whenever you wish. But please say hello when you arrive.

It will be two hours writing on your work and then their will be a short social afterwards.

I will aim to stay for at least 30 minutes from 12, but need to leave around 12.30, but in this time it would be great to hear more on the type of meetups people would be further interested in attending as part of this group.

As this will be a Friday morning - depending on how many people are able to make this time it may be the case we have to sit on one or more tables for the writing. Please feel free to find your space :)

Any questions please ask.

If you need to contact me please text/whatsapp or call my mob - 07849374152

title: Writing in Fellowship
description:
Hi all, this meetup will be another informal write together / writing in fellowship and then a short social/chat afterwards over a coffee.

title: Fiction Writing Style (Three Key Elements) - Workshop and Discussion
description:
One of the key aspects of fiction writing is developing and using an adept style of writing. There are many elements that go towards this, but for this meet-up we will concentrate on three of these.

This session will delve into elements that go towards writing and we will concentrate on the fabric (so to speak) of writing style.

PLEASE NOTE: This will be an interactive session sitting around a table. So you will discuss and engage with other members of the meeting.

AGENDA:

1. Show, don't tell (Detail/Specifics).
2. Evocation (Evoking emotions).
3. Profluence (Profluence).

1. SHOW, DON' TELL:

One of the most commonly discussed aspects of writing style. - We will discuss this and then try some examples. Starting with some basic 'tell' sentences and then developing them to see how they can be improved.

In this session there will be around four or more sentences that will be given to the group for jumping off points. Some time will be allowed for the group to chat and come up with suggestions for how the sentence(s) can be developed.

E.G.

- 'John walks down the street to his grandmother's house.'

Nothing wrong with the above sentence, but it is not engaging with the reader.

Instead, try writing:

- 'Every step was like walking through mud, as sweat rolled down his cheeks and an impending feeling of doom saturated John’s mind, for he knew that soon he will be at his grandmother’s house.'

2. EVOCATION:

Evoking emotions. This is a sure fire way to engage with your audience. There are many ways to do this and (perhaps worryingly at times) newspapers or websites often do this with great effect even though they are not writing fiction.

Creating an impulsive or engaging feeling that draws in the reader. This can be subtle or have a great effect.

We will discuss examples and ways of how to do this. Ways to do this could be show injustice, love, vengeance... etc..

We will also write some example paragraphs that evoke emotions.

3. PROFLUENCE:

Moving your story forward and keeping the reader engaged.

There are numerous ways to do this and some of these will be discussed.

For example plot points, creating anticipation, revealing a mystery, etc... Are all ways and methods to keep your reader interested.

-------------

Other Details:

1. Although not 100% necessary - it would be a very good idea to bring along a notepad and pen/pencil.

2. This will be a short session of 1 hour and 30 mins.

3. Please remember to bring a photo ID and scan it at the guest registration tablets at the front desk when you. If your photo ID does not successfully scan, please check in at the tablet as a guest of "Meetup Event".

4. Any questions please ask.

5. As the topic of writing style is huge it will concentrate on three aspects and will cover as much as possible in the short time available in this session.

6. Location:

WeWork 12 Hammersmith Grove
12 Hammersmith Grove London W6 7AP
April 18, 2019 5.30 PM to 7:00 PM

title: A social and chance to meetup with fellow writers
description:
This meetup is a casual social for writers who wish to meet other writers in a friendly atmosphere.

This meetup could be a spring-board for creating relationships with writers that you find common interests with, and potentially for feedback, support, brainstorming and all other matters that relate to writing.

There is no agenda, but to help guide the conversation for this meetup - please consider the three points below for discussion:

1. What writing are you working on?
2. When do you hope to have it finished by?
3. What are your next steps?

--------------------------

--- My plan is to create a mastermind group or potentially several mastermind groups could sprout from this meetup (and repeat meetups like it). ---

Although this is meetup is not a mastermind group itself, but a pre-cursor to meeting other writers that you find you have common interests with.

-------------------------

The word “mastermind” was coined by Napoleon Hill in the 1920s. Hill believed that when two people come together to solve a problem, their combined wisdom forms a “master mind.”

He urged budding entrepreneurs to form mastermind groups (or “alliances”, as he called them) where they could keep each other accountable to their goals and give each other advice about their projects.

The Inklings is one of the best-known mastermind groups formed by writers. Headed by C. S. Lewis and J. R. R. Tolkien, the group gathered on Thursday evenings at Lewis’s rooms in Magdalen College. Later on, they would also meet for lunch at a local Oxford pub called The Eagle and Child.

The members of the group came together to share ideas and receive feedback on the latest drafts of their novels. Tolkien, for example, read aloud from a manuscript that would eventually become The Lord of the Rings.

(The section above about mastermind groups was written by Nicole Bianchi).

title: Ghost Stories - How to write a short ghost story in the classic Jamesian style
description:
In the workshop, we will discuss ideas, structure and plot points that relate to classic victorian ghost stories and in particular those of M.R.James.

The aim will be for you to learn how to write in a Jamesian style and then in your own time proceed to write a short ghost story.

If you already have a lot of experience in this genre, please still feel to join and share your knowledge.

--------------------------------

Agenda:

The meetup will be a laid back workshop and participants will be encouraged to engage in the discussion.

1. A short introduction to the Jamesian style.

2. An overview of general approaches to making your writing suspenseful:
2.1 Limit the POV.
2.2 Style and form.
2.3 Dramatic irony.

Then the body of the meetup will be for all to discuss and come up with ideas following the points below - for your own ghost stories.

- We will stop halfway through for a short break of around 10 mins.

3. The Jamesian Style:
3.1 Location and setting.
3.2 The main protagonist.
3.3 An object.

I will bring some specific examples of characters and settings from some of James stories.

--------------------------------

To create the perfect Jamesian ghost story you will need the ingredients below:

1. A quaint, ancient setting. Such as a twee English country village, an estranged seaside town or a stately Abbey. James loved to utilise the antiquity of a colourful setting with an isolated atmosphere.

2. A lady or gentleman protagonist. Many of James’ characters are naive reserved scholars, who are often not convinced something strange is happening until the final climax of the story.

3. A pivotal antiquarian object. Whether an old book or an antique, the discovery of a mystery object that unlocks and attracts an unwelcome figure from beyond the grave is a signature mark of James’ stories.

-------------------------

The story that you produce will be after the meetup, will be at your own pace and in your own time, but it would be great to see your short stories, if you wish to share them, once they have been completed.

-------------------------

James was a lecturer at Cambridge University and at Christmas time he became well known for reading back his ghost stories.

He was master of the uncanny, the purveyor of the uncomfortable and a writer renowned for his atmospheric ghostly tales. It was also in Victorian times a tradition to tell ghost stories and one of the most famous ghost stories of all time was set in the Christmas period - that, of course, being "A Christmas Carol" by Charles Dickens.

Jameson ghost storytelling was straight down the line and revolved around the idea of real ghosts, not psychological illusions or paranoid affects of the human mind. So if you prefer writing psychological type ghost or horror stories then this workshop may not be for you.

- Just to note - although Jame's stories were published in the Edwardian period, he wrote and shared them primarily during at the end of the Victorian period.

--------------------------------

The writer M.R. James once said: “Two ingredients most valuable in the concocting of a ghost story are the atmosphere and the nicely managed crescendo.… Let us, then, be introduced to the actors in a placid way; let us see them going about their ordinary business, undisturbed by forebodings, pleased with their surroundings; and into this calm environment let the ominous thing put out its head, unobtrusively at first, and then more insistently, until it holds the stage.”

-------------------------

The owner of Frequency Cafe has kindly let us use this space for free. Although you don't have to, please do consider buying a coffee or something to eat if you can.

title: Open Readings - In partnership with the Barbican Library
description:
Come and join us in a friendly atmosphere for a chance to read out your written work - from your short stories to part of your novel, or any fictional/non-fictional work you would like to share. Each reading will be followed by constructive feedback and thoughts from fellow attendees.

For the attendees who wish to read their work, please just attend and volunteer at the time. We will try and accommodate as many readings as possible.

This session is an excellent opportunity to gauge feedback on your work and learn where you can improve.

Each reading will have a time limit of up to 10 minutes max in length.

- If you wish, please also feel free to just come along to listen and provide constructive feedback.

---------

Agenda: (1:30pm to 3:30pm)

1. Arrival 1.15pm to 1.30pm
1. Session start: 1.30pm
2. Short Introduction and summary of proceedings.
3. The first writer to give their reading.
5. Further readings.
6. Close and thanks.

---------

This session is being held in partnership with the Barbican Library, who have kindly offered to hold this event in partnership with the Barbican writers group.

They have also provided a space for this event to take place.

The readings will take place in the Arts library space.

title: Creativity Workshop for fiction writers: kickstart your imagination
description:
This writing workshop is for writers of all levels of experience who are interested in fiction (short stories, novels, screenplays, etc.). We will be exploring various methods of generating ideas and tapping into your creativity. The tools used will include freewriting, visual prompts, randomizers (i.e. story cubes) and more.

Throughout the day, the activities will build on each other so that when you leave you should have plenty of material to work with on your own if you wish. You will also have lots of new tricks and strategies that you can use in the future if you get creatively stuck or are searching for new ideas.

This workshop is perfect for anyone who is looking to start a new project, is battling writers block, or simply wants to explore their creative side (you don't have to be an experienced writer to join! beginners are more than welcome!)

Come with a notebook, pen, computer, whatever you prefer to write with -- and a willingness to play and explore!

Spaces are limited so please only RSVP if you can make it. If something comes up, no prob! Just change your RSVP so someone else can have your space.

We will be in the function room in the back of Artisan Coffee in Ealing Broadway.

Creating an impulsive or engaging feeling that draws in the reader. This can be subtle or have a great effect.

title: Build a free WordPress.Com Website - An online hub for you as a writer (Skype)
description:
Hi all,

- In this meetup, you will be taken through the process of setting up your own free WordPress website.

- This process will be using wordpress.com and will cover the setup of a simple website including a homepage, contact and blog page.

- This online workshop is suitable for those who have never used WordPress before or would consider themselves at a beginner level.

--------------------

PLEASE NOTE:

-- This workshop will take place over Skype.

-- There is a small charge for this meetup/workshop.

-- I will send you my skype address once you have signed up, or please contact me directly through meet-up for my skype address.

-- You will not need any coding skills for this workshop.

-- As this website will be provided for free from WordPress – the URL (website address) will have WordPress in the title. E.g. It will be – www.mysite.wordpress.com instead of www.mysite.com.

---------------------

It goes without saying that in the modern-day world a huge amount of communication and information is provided from the internet and accessed through mobile devices and desktop PCs.

By staking a space for yourself online you are creating a central point for where you can share and display your work. And also where you can promote your work and potentially build a community.

This will be a short 2-hour course and by the end of it, you will have a WordPress.com website and will have the basic knowledge to be able to go on and build similar Wordpress.com sites.

------------------
Agenda:

1. Introduction:
1.1 The difference between WordPress.com and Wordpress.org
1.2 Creating a clear vision for your website.
1.3 Listing the key requirements and prioritising.

2. Sourcing design assets and images.

3. Stage 1:
3.1 Setting up the site.
3.2 Choosing a template to start with.

4. Stage 2:
4.1 Initial configuration.
4.2 Adding pages.
4.3 Adding posts.
4.4 Adding a Menu and Customisation.

5. An Agile approach: Don’t aim to be perfect! Some of the best feedback you’ll get is when the site is live.

------------------

Any questions please ask.

(The course will be held by Chris Mitchell who has worked in technology and project management roles for over 10 years and who has built numerous websites, both large and small.)

title: Creative Writing Workshop: Write Away Those Cobwebs!
description:
This will be our first in-person (and SOCIALLY DISTANCED) creative writing workshop since you-know-when, perfect for anyone who's longing to shake off those lockdown cobwebs and let their imaginations run free.

This writing workshop will consist of various exercises and prompts intended to help you generate new ideas and tap into your creativity. You don't need to have anything you're already working on (though if you do, also cool), and you don't have to share your work with the group if you don't want to. Writers of all levels of experience are welcome (and If you've attended before, note that there will be no repeat exercises: all fresh material here!)

Throughout the session, the activities will build on each other so that when you leave you should have plenty of material to work with on your own if you wish. You will also have lots of new tricks and strategies that you can use in the future if you get creatively stuck or are searching for new ideas. This workshop is perfect for anyone who is looking to start a new project, is battling writer's block, or simply wants to explore their creative side (beginners are more than welcome!).

Come with a notebook, pen, computer (bearing in mind that we will be outdoors), whatever you prefer to write with -- and a willingness to play and explore!

Arrive at 2pm for a 2:15ish start. We will be meeting by the gazebo in Walpole Park (which is near the cafe and near-ish the pond). Bring something to sit on if you wish (i.e. pillow or blanket as we will be on the ground). We will have hand sanitiser, but bring your own if you can!

There are no refunds available for this event, but if something happens on the day please get in touch, we may be able to give you a place on a different workshop at a later date.

Again, we will be VERY STRICT ABOUT SOCIAL DISTANCING at this event. Masks are optional as we will be outdoors, but please maintain the recommended distance as much as possible.

See you then!!

title: Developing your Writing Style (Evocation and Show, Don't Tell) (Online)
description:
One of the key aspects of fiction writing is developing and using an adept and clear style of writing. There are many elements that go towards this, but for this meet-up, we will concentrate on:- 'Show, Don't Tell' and 'Evocation.'

This session will delve into these key elements that go towards an effective writing style.

-----------------

NOTE: This will be an interactive session online, so you will discuss and engage with other members of the meeting.

This session is suited more towards new writers, but is also open to those who are more experienced and looking for a refresh, or a discussion on these topics.

------------------

AGENDA:

1. Show, Don't Tell (Detail/Specifics).
2. Evocation (Evoking emotions).
3. Cultivation of a Paragraph (bringing your own example).

1. SHOW, DON' TELL:

One of the most commonly discussed aspects of writing style. We will discuss this and then try some examples. Starting with some basic 'tell' sentences and then developing them to see how they can be improved.

In this session, there will be around four or more sentences that will be given to the group for jumping-off points. Some time will be allowed for the group to chat and come up with suggestions for how the sentence(s) can be developed.

E.G.

- 'John walks down the street to his grandmother's house.'

Nothing wrong with the above sentence, but it may not be engaging with the reader.

Instead, try writing:

- 'Every step was like walking through mud, as sweat rolled down his cheeks and an impending feeling of doom saturated John’s mind, for he knew that soon he will be at his grandmother’s house.'

2. EVOCATION:

Evoking emotions. This is a sure-fire way to engage with your audience. There are many ways to do this and (perhaps worryingly at times) newspapers or websites often do this with great effect even though they are not writing fiction.

Creating an impulsive or engaging feeling that draws in the reader. This can be subtle or have a great effect.

We will discuss examples and ways of how to do this. Ways to do this could be show injustice, love, vengeance... etc..

We will also create a paragraph and use that to evoke emotions.

3. YOUR PARAGRAPH:

As part of this meet-up please prepare a paragraph on any subject you wish. (I will bring along one to discuss as well).

Then bring this to the meet-up and at the end of the workshop as a group we will look at this paragraph and discuss how (if possible) it can be built upon.

-----------------

Other Details:

1. This meetup will be held online and I will share the link nearer to the workshop time directly with those that sign up. I will most likely be using https://jitsi.org/ or Google Meet.

FYI - Jitsi is a super easy to use video conference tool and does not require an account to use.

2. I will share handouts via google docs at the start of the meeting - but I will need an email address to share these.

3. There are no refunds available for this event, but if you can't make it on the day please get in touch, we may well be able to give you a place on a different workshop at a later date.

title: Ghost Stories - How to write a short ghost story in the classic Jamesian style
description:
In the workshop, we will discuss ideas, structure and plot points that relate to classic victorian ghost stories and in particular those of M.R.James.

The aim will be for you to learn how to write in a Jamesian style and if you wish in your own time to proceed and write a short ghost story.

If you already have a lot of experience in this genre, please still feel to join and share your knowledge.

--------------------------------

Agenda:

1. A short introduction to the Jamesian style.

2. Before delving further into ghost stories a short look at ways to make your writing suspenseful:

2.1 Limit the POV.
2.2 Style and form.
2.3 Dramatic irony.

Then the body of the meetup will be for all to discuss and come up with ideas following the points below - for your own ghost stories.

Participants will be encouraged to engage in the discussion, so please feel free to add your thoughts and questions.

3. The Jamesian Style:
3.1 Location and setting.
3.2 The main protagonist.
3.3 An object.

I will bring some specific examples of characters and settings from some of James stories.

--------------------------------

To create the perfect Jamesian ghost story you will need the ingredients below:

1. A quaint, ancient setting. Such as a twee English country village, an estranged seaside town or a stately Abbey. James loved to utilise the antiquity of a colourful setting with an isolated atmosphere.

2. A lady or gentleman protagonist. Many of James’ characters are naive reserved scholars, who are often not convinced something strange is happening until the final climax of the story.

3. A pivotal antiquarian object. Whether an old book or an antique, the discovery of a mystery object that unlocks and attracts an unwelcome figure from beyond the grave is a signature mark of James’ stories.

-------------------------

The story that you produce will be after the meetup, will be at your own pace and in your own time, but it would be great to see your short stories if you wish to share them.

-------------------------

James was a lecturer at Cambridge University and at Christmas time he became well known for reading back his ghost stories.

He was master of the uncanny, the purveyor of the uncomfortable and a writer renowned for his atmospheric ghostly tales. It was also in Victorian times a tradition to tell ghost stories and one of the most famous ghost stories of all time was set in the Christmas period - that, of course, being "A Christmas Carol" by Charles Dickens.

Jameson ghost storytelling was straight down the line and revolved around the idea of real ghosts, not psychological illusions or paranoid affects of the human mind. So if you prefer writing psychological type ghost or horror stories then this workshop may not be for you.

- Just to note - although Jame's stories were published in the Edwardian period, he wrote and shared them primarily during at the end of the Victorian period.

--------------------------------

The writer M.R. James once said: “Two ingredients most valuable in the concocting of a ghost story are the atmosphere and the nicely managed crescendo.… Let us, then, be introduced to the actors in a placid way; let us see them going about their ordinary business, undisturbed by forebodings, pleased with their surroundings; and into this calm environment let the ominous thing put out its head, unobtrusively at first, and then more insistently, until it holds the stage.”

-------------------------

1. This meetup will be held online and I will share the link nearer to the workshop time directly with those that sign up. I will most likely be using https://jitsi.org/ or Google Meet.

FYI - Jitsi is a super easy to use video conference tool and does not require an account to use.

2. There are no refunds available for this event, but if you can't make it on the day please get in touch, we may well be able to give you a place on a different workshop at a later date.

title: Creative Writing Workshop: Plotting your story's emotional arc
description:
A story is so much more than Plot and Things That Happen.

A story is first and foremost about character and WHY the events of the plot matter to them.

This fun and highly informative creative writing workshop will seek to dispel common creative writing myths and help you to understand not only WHY you need to know your story's emotional arc, but HOW to go about achieving this and weaving emotional significance into every step of your story.

Having a solid emotional arc is essential for so many reasons: (1) It keeps readers hooked because they want to find out WHAT HAPPENS NEXT, (2) It makes YOU a better writer because you will know your characters intimately, making it less likely that you will lose steam or come up against the dreaded writers block, and (3) It means that your story will flow organically and naturally from start to finish, leading to a seamless and deeply satisfying end product.

We will start by thoroughly exploring what emotional arc means and why your story needs an emotional core. We will then guide you through the experience of building your story's emotional arc, and you will leave the workshop with a toolbox of tips, tricks, and exercises that you will be able to use again whenever you need.

This workshop is perfect for writers of all levels of experience, and it may be especially useful for those of you who are taking on NaNoWriMo! Come ready with a notebook, pen, computer, whatever you prefer to write with -- and a willingness to play and explore! Bring a work-in-progress you'd like to develop, or use this workshop to discover and build an entirely new project.

Enter the online meeting room from 2pm for a 2:15ish start. The meetup will be conducted on Zoom. Any questions about Zoom, just ask!

title: How to write a Classic - Jamesian Victorian Style - Ghost Story
description:
It was a Victorian tradition to tell ghost stories at Christmas time - A tradition that has now (unfortunately) faded away. There is nothing more entertaining than a good ghost story told around a crackling fire or cosy living room.

Hopefully, this workshop will inspire you to write and tell a few of your own ghost stories. - Around Christmas time.

------------------------------------

In the workshop, we will discuss ideas, structure and plot points that relate to classic Victorian ghost stories and in particular those of M.R.James.

If you have a lot of experience in this genre, please still feel to join and share your knowledge.

--------------------------------

Agenda:

1. A short introduction to the Jamesian style.

2. Before delving further into ghost stories a short look at ways to make your writing suspenseful:

2.1 Limit the POV.
2.2 Style and form.
2.3 Dramatic irony.

Then the body of the meetup will be for all to discuss and come up with ideas following the points below - for your own ghost stories.

Participants will be encouraged to engage in the discussion, so please feel free to add your thoughts and questions.

3. The Jamesian Style:
3.1 Location and setting.
3.2 The main protagonist.
3.3 An object.

I will bring some specific examples of characters and settings from some of James stories.

--------------------------------

To create the perfect Jamesian ghost story you will need:

1. A quaint, ancient setting. Such as a twee English country village, an estranged seaside town or a stately Abbey. James loved to utilise the antiquity of a colourful setting with an isolated atmosphere.

2. A lady or gentleman protagonist. Many of James’ characters are naive reserved scholars, who are often not convinced something strange is happening until the final climax of the story.

3. A pivotal antiquarian object. Whether an old book or an antique, the discovery of a mystery object that unlocks and attracts an unwelcome figure from beyond the grave is a signature mark of James’ stories.

-------------------------

James was a lecturer at Cambridge University and at Christmas time he became well known for reading back his ghost stories.

He was master of the uncanny, the purveyor of the uncomfortable and a writer renowned for his atmospheric ghostly tales. It was also in Victorian times a tradition to tell ghost stories and one of the most famous ghost stories of all time was set in the Christmas period - that, of course, being "A Christmas Carol" by Charles Dickens.

Jameson ghost storytelling was straight down the line and revolved around the idea of real ghosts, not psychological illusions or paranoid affects of the human mind. So if you prefer writing psychological type ghost or horror stories then this workshop may not be for you.

- Just to note - although Jame's stories were published in the Edwardian period, he wrote and shared them primarily during at the end of the Victorian period.

--------------------------------

The writer M.R. James once said: “Two ingredients most valuable in the concocting of a ghost story are the atmosphere and the nicely managed crescendo.… Let us, then, be introduced to the actors in a placid way; let us see them going about their ordinary business, undisturbed by forebodings, pleased with their surroundings; and into this calm environment let the ominous thing put out its head, unobtrusively at first, and then more insistently, until it holds the stage.”

-------------------------

1. This meetup will be held online and I will share the link nearer to the workshop time directly with those that sign up. I will be using https://jitsi.org/ or Google Meet.

2. There are no refunds available for this event, but if you can't make it on the day please get in touch, we may well be able to give you a place on a different workshop at a later date.

title: Get Started with a WordPress Website - An online Hub for you as a Writer
description:
Build a free WordPress.Com Website - An online hub for you as a writer:

- In this meetup, you will be taken through the process of setting up your own free WordPress website.

- This process will be using wordpress.com and will cover the setup of a simple website including a homepage, contact and blog page.

- This online workshop is suitable for those who have never used WordPress before or would consider themselves at a beginner level.

--------------------

PLEASE NOTE:

-- This workshop will take place online and the video link will be shared nearer the time of the meetup.

-- You will not need any coding skills for this workshop.

-- As this website will be provided for free from WordPress – the URL (website address) will have WordPress in the title.

E.g. It will be – www.mysite.wordpress.com instead of www.mysite.com.

---------------------

It goes without saying that in the modern-day world a huge amount of communication and information is provided from the internet and accessed through mobile devices and desktop PCs.

By staking a space for yourself online you are creating a central point for where you can share and display your work. And also where you can promote your work and potentially build a community.

This will be a short 2-hour course and by the end of it, you will have a WordPress.com website and will have the basic knowledge to be able to go on and build similar Wordpress.com sites.

------------------
Agenda:

1. Introduction:
1.1 The difference between WordPress.com and Wordpress.org
1.2 Creating a clear vision for your website.
1.3 Listing the key requirements and prioritising.

2. Sourcing design assets and images.

3. Stage 1:
3.1 Setting up the site.
3.2 Choosing a template to start with.

4. Stage 2:
4.1 Initial configuration.
4.2 Adding pages.
4.3 Adding posts.
4.4 Adding a Menu and Customisation.

5. An Agile approach: Don’t aim to be perfect! Some of the best feedback you’ll get is when the site is live.

------------------

Any questions please ask.

(The course will be held by Chris Mitchell who has worked in technology and project management roles for over 10 years and who has built numerous websites, both large and small.)

title: Open Readings (Online) - In partnership with the Barbican Library
description:
Open reading in partnership with the Barbican Library.

---

Join us in a friendly atmosphere for a chance to read out your written work - from your short stories to part of your novel, or any fictional/non-fictional work you would like to share. Each reading will be followed by constructive feedback and thoughts from fellow attendees.

- This session is an excellent opportunity to gauge feedback on your work and learn where you can improve.

- Each reading will have a time limit of up to 10 minutes max in length. (There will be a subtle alarm sound at the end of 10 mins to help keep the session moving forward in good time).

- There will also be the option to share your writing on screen so people can read along to it.

- For the attendees who wish to read their work, please just attend and volunteer at the time. We will try and accommodate as many readings as possible. (For this next session I am also allowing people to message me so I can put them into an order to see how well this works).

If you wish, please also feel free to just come along to listen and provide constructive feedback.

---------

Agenda: (10:30 am to 12:30 pm)

1. Session start: 10.30 am.
2. Short Introduction and summary of proceedings.
3. The first writer to give their reading.
5. Further readings.
6. Close and thanks.

---------

This session is being held in partnership with the Barbican Library, who have kindly offered to hold this event with their zoom account and in partnership with the Barbican writers group.

This event will be held using zoom and I will post the link once I have received it from the Barbican. I will email the password to those who sign up near the time of the event.

title: Creative Writing DEEP DIVE: The Secrets of Three-Act Structure
description:
This is the first in a series of DEEP DIVE creative writing workshops that will get you up close and personal with different fundamental aspects of the writing process. These workshops will help you to hone your creative wordsmithing skills as well as increase your understanding of what makes good writing and how to achieve it.

In this deep dive workshop, we will look at THREE-ACT STRUCTURE -- in other words, what a story needs in its beginning, middle, and end. We will go deep into the conventions here and also look at some examples of successful three-act structure in storytelling. We will demystify these rules of thumb as well as empower you to know when to break them, drawing from examples of writing that subverts, flaunts, or otherwise ignores the typical structure.

In addition to the information and examples provided, you can expect a number of practical prompts and exercises that will help you to become better acquainted with three-act structure so that you will be able to skillfully apply these techniques to your own projects. This highly informative and fun workshop will leave you with the understanding and the confidence to structure your own writing in a way that makes your story compelling, organic, and satisfying to an audience.

This workshop is perfect for writers of all levels of experience. Come ready with a notebook, pen, computer, whatever you prefer to write with -- and a willingness to play and explore! Bring a work-in-progress you'd like to develop, or use this workshop to discover and build an entirely new project.

Enter the online meeting room from 2pm for a 2:10ish start. The meetup will be conducted on Zoom. Any questions about Zoom, just ask!

There are no refunds available for this event, but if something happens on the day please get in touch, we may be able to give you a place on a different workshop at a later date.

See you then!!

title: Spectrum Meets ... Peter Newman!
description:
Peter Newman, author of gripping and evocative fantasy novels including The Vagrant and The Malice, will be our guest author at the inaugural Spectrum Meets... event, where we invite authors and industry professionals to share their experiences, wisdom and knowledge with aspiring writers.

Peter is perhaps best known for The Vagrant, which just won the David Gemmell Morningstar Award and was shortlisted for a British Fantasy Award, and its recently released sequel The Malice. He is also a lead writer for Albion Online, the fantasy MMO, and co-writes the Hugo-nominated / Alfie-winning Tea and Jeopardy Podcast.

Peter will be reading from his new book, and then a Q&A session will follow. You will also have the opportunity to get your books signed!

The event will cost £5/person, and will include refreshments and nibbles. All are welcome, however space is limited so book early!

EVENT INFO
Social meet & greet: 6:30 PM

Reading + Q&A: 7:30 PM

Book Signing: at the end!

This event is brought to you by Spectrum: London Science Fiction & Fantasy Writers' Group.

title: Spectrum Goes Rogue ... One!
description:
Spectrum heads out to see Star Wars: Rogue One!

Note: you should sign up by Thursday 6PM if you want to come ... you can cancel before then, but not after (as the ticket will be bought early to ensure we all get to sit close together or at worst in small groups).

3D theatre, Star seating. Tickets are £15 and will be bought/booked all together. I'm not including 3D glasses in case people already have them.

NOTE: TICKETS WILL BE PURCHASED ON THURSDAY NIGHT! If people register after that, I'll do my best to book them in as close to where the first group is sitting. So, ASAP as soon as you can!

The Cineworld in West India Quay is top shelf, big comfy seats. We'll head over to the pub afterwards for some food and pints as well. Only a few minutes walk from the DLR (West India or Westferry are the closest).

Should be a blast ... looks like this might be a real winner!

title: Spectrum Short Story Award Night
description:
The Spectrum Short Story Award Night will be a special critique session where all those lovely submitted stories (17 in all) will be critiqued and awards will be handed out for the favorites in each of five categories.

Note that to be eligible to attend this meeting, you will have had to have qualified to submit a story in the first place (i.e. been to a meeting in 2016 and had a chance to read the submitted stories). Stories will be critiqued in round-robin speed-date format, so that every submitted story will receive at least a few critiques. Critiques will be assigned to attendees a week before the meeting (2-3), so please sign up early.

Also, we'll be charging a small amount for this meeting to go towards the venue and the prize winners! Has always been a very fun night, so we look forward to seeing you there!

description:
Spectrum goes to see Logan, the farewell performance for Hugh Jackman's Wolverine and Patrick Stuart's Xavier. This looks to be a very much story- and character-driven movie, and pretty grimdark as well.

I will be booking tickets on Friday, so if you want to sit as a group, please book before then. I'll be booking for the 2D theatre, in the premium section (which are much more comfortable and well-positioned seats). The meetup fee (£13) is the price of the tickets.

group.name: London Science Fiction & Fantasy Writers' Group

title: Spectrum Novel Track ... First Meeting
description:
This will be the first meetup for our new Novel track. The meeting will revolve around discussing a suitable format going forward, looking at things like:

- meeting frequency

- critique format

- meeting format

- establishing reading/writing genres so that we can pair like-interest groups together

We'll send out a more detailed overview to the attendees before the meeting itself.

Note that the attendance requirements for this track will be more strict than our critique and other meetings. This is because there is a far greater commitment required in critiquing an entire novel (though it won't be as intensive as for a short story, i.e. don't expect to give or be given line item edits or per-page notes).

As such, the novel track meetups (including this one) will be restricted to participants who:

- have submitted and had their work critiqued at least once in the regular critique meetings

- are *actively* working on a novel (in process, complete, in revision, etc.). As spaces are likely to be tight, people who aren't actively contributing both content and critiques will likely be asked to give up their spot for somebody who is. We won't be militant about this, but we will be fair.

- are willing to commit to reading 5-10K/month (remembering that critiques for novels are not expected to be anywhere near as thorough as for short stories)

The idea behind this group is to be as much supportive/encouraging/inspiring as it is constructive (or maybe deconstructive).

So, if you want to contribute to the discussion of how we'll operate this group, join us on Mar. 15. Again, the above restrictions apply, so if you don't yet fit these requirements, please be patient and we'll find you a spot eventually!

group.name: London Science Fiction & Fantasy Writers' Group

title: Spectrum Novel Meetup
description:
The Spectrum Novel track is for writers working on ... well, novels. We meet once/month, discuss progress as a group, answer questions/solve dilemmas (generally plot problems, though maybe life/other as well) and then break off into structured micro-groups for critiques.

This meeting:

- everybody is asked to bring an elevator pitch of their novel, 100 words maximum. We did this off the cuff at the first meeting, lets see how we do when we have time to prepare (also, these are *hugely* important, so do take your time with it!)

- we'll be handing out the assigned micro-groups, which I'm sure will be an involved and exhausting experience

- we'll outline a general structure for micro-groups that will hopefully keep everybody productive and happy

-we'll break off into our new micro-groups for introductions and prep work for the meetings ahead

We typically start gathering at 6PM for food and/or a drink, with a start promptly at 7PM.

IMPORTANT: All novel track meetups are restricted to participants who have attended 2 or more of our regular critique meetings, no exceptions. Also, you must fill out the Novel Track Survey and be assigned to one of the micro-groups before attending (contact the organizers beforehand for details).

group.name: London Science Fiction & Fantasy Writers' Group

title: Spectrum Meets ... Den Patrick!
description:
For this Spectrum special event we will be hosting Den Patrick, author of the great Erebus Sequence and the War-Fighting Manuals, and co-creator of Super Relaxed Fantasy Club. He's training to be a therapist, which as writers we could all use a little of, and finally if not most importantly, he's a really nice guy!

Den has been a very important part of London's community of genre writers, and through SRFC has undoubtedly inspired many a writer to press on and complete their novels. He is also a guest lecturer at Brunel University for their creative writing course.

Den will be sharing his experiences with us on the trials and tribulations of writing novels, finding inspiration, the importance of community, among other wisdoms and truths. We'll be providing a selection of nibbles during the pre-gather chat, then Den will read a selection from his work and we'll follow with a question/answer period. All members are invited to attend.

title: Spectrum Novel Meetup
description:
The Spectrum Novel track is for writers working on ... well, novels. We meet once/month, discuss progress as a group, answer questions/solve dilemmas (generally plot problems, though maybe life/other as well) and then break off into structured micro-groups for critiques.

We typically start gathering at 6PM for food and/or a drink, with a start promptly at 7PM.

This meeting:

- everybody is asked to bring a Hollywood pitch of their novel, 20 words maximum. Should include (or entirely be) of the format "it's like X meets Y", aka "it's like Mad Max meets Last of the Summer Wine" or "imagine Soylent Green as a musical, with killer robots"

- if anybody has a quick-discuss novel/writing problem they'd like to present to the group before we break off, please forward them to me or Rachel (question/description should be less than 100 words)

- we'll break off into our new micro-groups for critiques afterward

IMPORTANT: All novel track meetups are restricted to participants who have attended 2 or more of our regular critique meetings, no exceptions. Also, you must fill out the Novel Track Survey and have been assigned to one of the micro-groups to attend (contact the organizers beforehand for details).

group.name: London Science Fiction & Fantasy Writers' Group

title: Critique meeting
description:
A critique meeting in the room upstairs at the Horse and Groom. As usual, you are welcome to arrive early and have a chat, a bite to eat and/or a drink before the meeting. General gathering starts around 18:00, meeting starts promptly at 19:00.

We should have two submissions to critique for this meeting - we will post them to the main Spectrum website as soon as they are ready.

If you are a new member, in order to access the submissions for this meeting, please register as a member on the main Spectrum website - www.spectrumwriters.com. Once your application has been processed you will be able to download the submissions from the website.

If there's a waitlist for the meeting and you're unable to attend, please remove your RSVP to allow other people to benefit from your place.

group.name: London Science Fiction & Fantasy Writers' Group

title: Spectrum Novel Meetup
description:
The Spectrum Novel track is for writers working on ... well, novels. We meet once/month, discuss progress as a group, answer questions/solve dilemmas (generally plot problems, though maybe life/other as well) and then break off into structured micro-groups for critiques.

We typically start gathering at 6PM for food and/or a drink, with a start promptly at 7PM.

- if anybody has a quick-discuss novel/writing problem they'd like to present to the group before we break off, please forward them to me or Rachel (question/description should be less than 100 words)

- try and have your submission up by the 7th, please

- if you submitted last time, make sure and delete your submission from the website

- we'll break off into our new micro-groups for critiques afterward

IMPORTANT: All novel track meetups are restricted to participants who have attended 2 or more of our regular critique meetings, no exceptions. Also, you must fill out the Novel Track Survey and have been assigned to one of the micro-groups to attend (contact the organizers beforehand for details).

group.name: London Science Fiction & Fantasy Writers' Group

title: Spectrum Social: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets
description:
A Spectrum social event: off to the movies! In this case, Luc Besson's awesome spectacle Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets.

It's a bit spread out as far as people's availability, but this seems the best fit.

Price includes the ticket. I'll be buying these no later than Thursday evening, so please RVSP by then if you want to sit with the group!

For those holding passes, let me know and I'll put you on the RSVP list so you get any meetup notifications sent out.

Hope to see you all there!

group.name: London Science Fiction & Fantasy Writers' Group

title: Spectrum Short Story Award Night!
description:
The Spectrum Short Story Award Night will be a special critique session where all those lovely submitted stories (16 in all) will be critiqued and awards will be handed out for the favorites in each of five categories.

Note that to be eligible to attend this meeting, you need to have qualified to submit a story in the first place (i.e. been to a meeting in 2017). Stories will be critiqued in round-robin speed-date format, so that every submitted story will receive at least a few critiques.

Critiques will be assigned to attendees a week before the meeting (2-3), so please sign up early!

Also, we'll be charging a small amount for this meeting to go towards the venue, an assortment of nibbles, and of course the prizes. Has always been a very fun night, so we look forward to seeing you there!

group.name: London Science Fiction & Fantasy Writers' Group

title: Spectrum Critique Meeting (ONLINE)
description:
A critique meeting for short stories and novel excerpts written by our members. We will be critiquing one to two pieces at this session.

Due to the ongoing pandemic, we are still hanging out on Discord (voice/audio only). Instructions on how to join our server can be found here: https://spectrumwriters.com/members/discord-info

We will post the new submission(s) for this event shortly. Please wait until we have confirmed the new submissions are live before downloading anything. To access them, you need to sign up on our website and download it from the Members area under 'Submissions', then 'Upcoming Meeting'.

New members are absolutely welcome - please feel free to come say hello and see how the group works. An overview of how the critique meetings are formatted can be found on our website: https://spectrumwriters.com/about/critique-meetings/

*** PLEASE NOTE: This is not an instant virtual meeting like Zoom. You'll need to create a Discord account and join our server, which runs all the time, and then join the Voice Chat at the time of the session. Please allow extra time to complete this ahead of the meeting. ***

If you are having trouble getting onto Discord, signing up on the website, or have any other questions, leave a comment here and one of the organisers will get back to you.

Lastly, if you are able to, please consider tossing us a coffee's worth of change towards our running costs - it will be hugely appreciated! https://ko-fi.com/spectrumwriterslondon

Hope to see you there!

group.name: London Science Fiction & Fantasy Writers' Group

title: Friday night write @ St James!
description:
Where better to write than London's (and supposedly Europe's!) largest bookshop? Come for a productive hour of writing in the beautiful Jermyn St Café before you begin your weekend.

Whatever you are working on - be it a book, essay, CV, annual report, taxes (want to do mine?) - you are welcome here! No one will see your work, or give you unsolicited advice. This is a group where we write quietly side by side - it is surprising how much more effective this is than doing it alone (also, when there's scones).

SCHEDULE:

17.30 - arrive, order yourself a drink or pastry, get set up

17.45 - quick intros: your name & goal for the session (if you want to share!)

17.50 - timer starts! 1 hour writing block begins

18.50 - quick recap: how'd it go?

Those who'd like are welcome to stay on and write. The cafe is open until 21.30 (noting our table is only reserved until 19.00).

WHERE: Jermyn St Café & Gallery on the mezzanine level of Waterstone's Piccadilly, at the long table in the back. I will have a sign on the table to identify us.

FAQ:
- Is it free? Yes! But please show your gratitude to our hosts by purchasing something to eat or drink.

- What if I arrive late? Don't worry about it! Come to the table, grab a seat, and quietly start your writing.

- Are there outlets? Unfortunately not at this venue - please come with your device fully charged, or bring some old school pen & paper.

- Is there wifi? Yes, but it is temperamental - please be prepared to work without it, or to use your phone as a hotspot.

- I can't make this time/location/week - will there be more? Yes! Keep your notifications on for this group; there will be more events scheduled at different times and venues.

- I'm shy/don't want to talk about my writing - should I still come? Yes! There will be no pressure to engage, or to talk about your work, although those who would like to are welcome to do so after the writing block ends.

I hope to see you there!

- Is it free? Yes! But please show your gratitude to our hosts by purchasing something to eat or drink.

- What if I arrive late? Don't worry about it! Come to the table, grab a seat, and quietly start your writing.

- Are there outlets? There is a limited number of outlets at this venue - please come with your device fully charged, or bring some old school pen & paper.

- Is there wifi? Yes, but it is temperamental - please be prepared to work without it, or to use your phone as a hotspot.

- I'm shy/don't want to talk about my writing - should I still come? Yes! There will be no pressure to engage, or to talk about your work, although those who would like to are welcome to do so after the writing block ends.

I hope to see you there!

title: Covent Garden: Write with team members from Shut Up & Write HQ!
description:
Dear writers,

A big hello from Shut Up & Write Headquarters!

Two members of our team have flown out to London from San Francisco, and we'd love to take this opportunity to meet more of you in person. We can get some writing done together, as well as answer any questions about what it might be like to host your own event as part of the official Shut Up & Write chapter in London.

SCHEDULE:
10:00: Introductions and Q&A
10:30: Start writing
11:30: Stop writing, and more Q&A if needed

What Should I Bring?
Whatever you need to be able to write!
Bring earbuds/earplugs if you want to block the cafe’s overhead music or the occasional conversation by other patrons.
There may not be outlets available so please come with your laptops pre-charged.

We look forward to meeting you!

~Malaika & Jeremy from the Shut Up & Write Team

title: Remote Write!
description:
Social isolation doesn't have to be isolating! Come back to this page at 18.00 tonight for our usual Monday evening writing session (instructions below). If enough people are keen to continue remotely, I will schedule more frequent sessions (there are only so many films on Netflix) and we can consider using a more interactive platform.

Please feel free to forward this page to anyone else (whether London-based or not) who might benefit from some creative interaction online.

SCHEDULE (all times GMT):

18.00 - sign in (by replying to the first comment thread I'll create below), get set up, make yourself some tea, change out of your PJs (optional)

18.15 - share your goal for the session (using second comment thread below)

18.20 - timer starts! 1 hour writing block begins

19.20 - quick recap: how'd it go? (using third comment thread below)

I hope you're all keeping well and hope to "see" you tonight!

title: Remote Write!
description:
Quarantine is an excellent time to sort paper clips, count ceiling dots and carry on with your writing project! Stay social with us during this period of social distancing.

We're trying a high-tech 1990s-style chatroom for this event - no account or special software needed, just click on this link at 18:00:

https://tlk.io/suaw26-3

Quarantine is an excellent time to sort paper clips, count ceiling dots and carry on with your writing project! Stay social with us during this period of social distancing.

***Early bird special - two writing blocks!*** Join us for both or either. We're using a high-tech 1990s-style chatroom for this event - no account or special software needed, just click on this link at 11:00 (or 12:30):

https://tlk.io/suaw6-5

Please feel free to forward this page to anyone else (whether London-based or not) who might benefit from some creative interaction online.

SCHEDULE (all times BST):

11.00 - sign in, get set up, make yourself some tea, change out of your PJs (optional)

11.15 - share your goal for the session(s)

11.20 - timer starts! 1 hour writing block begins

12.20 ------------tea/pee break!------------

12.30 - timer starts! 30 min writing block begins

13.00 - quick recap: how'd it go?

I hope you're all keeping well and hope to "see" you soon!

title: Virtual writers' room: Open day drop-in
description:
Come stop by the virtual writers' room! Writing blocks will be running ad hoc throughout the day; join as and when you'd like. Attendees are welcome to announce their own blocks if one isn't running when they enter, and are welcome to stay beyond the scheduled end time.

We're using a high-tech 1990s-style chatroom for the day - no account or special software needed, just click on this link when you'd like to join:

https://tlk.io/suaw24-5

For new attendees: This is a departure from our normally structured sessions! If you prefer a more disciplined approach, please join us for our standing Monday night session at 18:00 BST, or at any other "remote write" event scheduled during the week.
