title: How to Write a Movie in 8 Weeks!  (FREE Class with Pro Screenwriter Conor Kyle)
description:
**How to Write a Movie!**
This class breaks down Conor Kyle's process for writing a screenplay in eight weeks. It all starts with your logline. Bring up to 3 loglines or brand new movie ideas! Conor is requesting that students use newer, fresher ideas, and stay away from the magnum opuses you’ve been working on or thinking about for years.

The intention behind the bootcamp is not for you to write a perfect script, but instead to teach you the organization skills, discipline, and craft techniques that will set you on the path to becoming a professional screenwriter.

The 8-week bootcamp starts August 21 and continues weekly through October 9. Conor takes you from a blank page to the first draft of a complete feature screenplay, walking you through the entire process of conceiving, outlining, and writing a 90-120 page script.

***About the Instructor:***
**Conor Kyle** has written for Shudder's Creepshow (2019) and placed twice in the Nicholl Fellowship with his scripts “Peter and the Wolves” (quarterfinals, also Launchpad top 10) and The Tube (semifinals). His screenplays have also been featured on special sections of the annual Hit List, Young & Hungry List, Spec Book, and on Tracking Board’s “Best Writers of the Year” booklet. He writes everything from stage musicals to Westerns to horror movies. Follow Conor on **[Twitter](https://twitter.com/TheScriptCamp), [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCHTkV9mxO1_wqfUsoGe7mXg/videos)** and **[Twitch](https://www.twitch.tv/scriptcamp)**

**How to join the free class:**

* Hit the RSVP button
* Then join us on Discord: **[https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna](https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna)**

**How to join Conor's 8-week Screenwriting Bootcamp:**

* You can either purchase the full course “a la carte”: **[https://scriptcamp.net/classes/](https://scriptcamp.net/classes/)**
* Or start the free trial Unlimited Script Camp membership with access to over 70 hours of live classes, workshops and bootcamps every month, including the new Script Camp Writers Lab: **[https://scriptcamp.net/membership/](https://scriptcamp.net/membership/)**

***8-Week Feature Bootcamp course schedule:***

**Week 1: Why this story? (Aug 21)**
Now that you’ve narrowed down your high-concept idea, we will ask the simple questions: why this story? Why now? What is both timely and universal in your idea? We will begin to chisel away at the central dramatic question of your script, and design a plan to explore this theme from all angles. You’ll refine and polish your story’s premise, and begin the outlining process with your project sketchbook.

**Week 2: Outlining I – Story Beats (Aug 28)**
Now that you’ve selected your feature idea, we’ll look at the key building blocks of your story. Chiefly: how to structure and place key scenes, and begin to establish connective tissue between them.

**Week 3: Outlining II – Scene Cards (Sep 4)**
Time to organize your ideas into a much more detailed outline. These “scene cards” will each feature a key moment of your story, and you’ll organize your brainstormed sketches into a cohesive, page-by-page plan for your upcoming feature.

**Week 4: Beginnings (Sep 11)**
It’s time to get going on your feature! This class will feature a both a FAQ / troubleshooting session (where we address and fill holes in your outlines before you begin) and a lecture on first acts: everything from opening image to the act break. From this class on, you’ll have to write a few pages a day to keep up with the benchmarks and get optimal feedback on your script.

**Week 5: Transitions (Sep 18)**
You’ve finished the first 20-30 pages of your script, so this class focuses on your first act break. How do we diagnose whether we’ve done everything we need to do in act one? We’ll heavily emphasize a propulsive boost into the “fun and games” of your script’s second act, balancing B-stories, and more.

**Week 6: Second Act (Sep 25)**
This class follows us into the deep dark woods of your script: the second act. We’ll go over the creation of sequences and setpieces, and review how to find the fun in your premise and mine its full potential.

**Week 7: Escalation (Oct 2)**
Many newer writers begin to falter or repeat themselves in this section of a script, so we’ll focus on keeping up the energy and narrative push, as well as beginning to answer questions and pay off setups from earlier in the script. Danger and tension must ramp up significantly in this section, and we’ll make sure our scripts are doing just that.

**Week 8: Endings (Oct 9)**
In our eighth and final week, we will work through the difficult final act of your script. How do we conclude subplots? How can we leave the reader feeling satisfied with the ideal “unexpected yet inevitable” conclusion? By the end of this week you will complete your 90-120 page first draft!

***FAQ:***

**Q: I don’t have a script ready yet. Is it okay if I just join to listen and learn?**
A: Absolutely! This workshop is entirely free and everyone is welcome to join.

**Q: My writing is ____ genre, is that okay?**
A: Yes! Any genre is OK.

**Q: I’m worried that my script sucks, should I still bring it?**
A: This is a process. Nobody's script will be perfect. We’re here to support you, which means pointing out the parts that are awesome and providing honest feedback for improvement.

**Q: My script is not in standard screenwriting format.**
A: Please re-type your using screenwriting software before uploading it to the google form. If it is not in standard screenplay format, it’s difficult for readers to provide helpful feedback on the pacing and many other aspects of your script. description:

title: How to Write a TV Pilot in 6 Weeks! with Pro Screenwriter Conor Kyle (FREE)
description:
Ready to write a TV pilot? This free class provides an how to develop your pilot idea and write the script in six weeks. We’ll dive into the construction of your premise, characters and story world as you refine the concept for the project you will write during the intensive six-week TV Pilot Bootcamp. ***Bring your loglines and original show ideas!***

The complete six-week **TV Pilot Bootcamp** course meets weekly on Friday (US) / Saturdays (Australia/NZ). Pro screenwriter **Conor Kyle** takes you from blank page to the first draft of a complete original pilot screenplay. You’ll attend a two-hour class session each week in which we’ll walk through the entire process of conceiving, outlining, and writing an original TV pilot.

***About the Instructor:***
**Conor Kyle** has written for Shudder's Creepshow (2019) and placed twice in the Nicholl Fellowship with his scripts “Peter and the Wolves” (quarterfinals, also Launchpad top 10) and The Tube (semifinals). His screenplays have also been featured on special sections of the annual Hit List, Young & Hungry List, Spec Book, and on Tracking Board’s “Best Writers of the Year” booklet. He writes everything from stage musicals to Westerns to horror movies. You can view Conor's previous class videos on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/TheScriptCamp), [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCHTkV9mxO1_wqfUsoGe7mXg/videos) and [Twitch](https://www.twitch.tv/scriptcamp)

**How to enroll in the free class?**
• Hit the RSVP button
• Join us on Discord: [https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna](https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna)

**How to enroll in the complete 6-week TV Pilot Bootcamp:**
• You can either purchase the course *“a la carte”*: [https://scriptcamp.net/product/classes/](https://scriptcamp.net/product/classes/)
• Or start your free trial **Unlimited Script Camp** membership with access to over 70 hours of live classes, workshops and bootcamps every month, including the weekly Script Camp Writers Lab: [https://scriptcamp.net/membership/](https://scriptcamp.net/membership/)

***Complete 6-Week Bootcamp Course Schedule:***

**Week 1: Loglines & Sketchbook (Aug 26)**
We begin this course by zeroing in on the high concept core premise, and developing two separate loglines to express this idea. The first is the series logline, and the second is the pilot logline. These will act as guideposts to keep us on track through construction of your script. We’ll also start filling out our sketchbooks, brainstorming a few different episode ideas from our prospective first season, to get a sense of where your show should begin, and where it’s headed.

**Week 2: Story Beats (Sep 2)**
Now that you have a solid grasp on the basics of your show, you’ll begin sketching out the key characters, plot points, and set-pieces in your pilot episode. Whether you’re planning for a 30-minute or 60-minute episode, you’ll need to carefully structure and pace your outline to ensure that you’re delivering on the promise of your premise quickly and efficiently enough.

**Week 3: Scene Cards (Sep 9)**
Time to start getting concrete. This class focuses on nailing down every scene from your pilot as a “scene card,” which is essentially a synopsis for every single major moment in your show. ScriptCamp heavily emphasises this part of the process, and we will make an exhaustive roadmap through your entire story before starting pages next week.

**Week 4: Beginnings (Sep 16)**
Now is when you’ll put pen to paper and begin drafting pages. You’ll have to write an act a week in order to keep up with the group’s milestones, and this is the first of three weekly check-ins in which we’ll evaluate your progress, troubleshoot issues, and give feedback.

**Week 5: Second Act (Sep 23)**
You’re in the thick of your script, and this class will feature both a short lecture on second acts and setpieces, as well as a lot of feedback on your in-progress pages. The goal is to keep your energy and momentum up as you approach the finale of your story, so we’ll ensure that your pacing, plot progression, and character arcs are all taking the reader in the right direction.

**Week 6: Endings (Sep 30)**
Time to finish strong. We’ll again diagnose issues with your in-progress scripts, and discuss crafting the ideal “unexpected but inevitable” finale. Plus, where do we go from here? Once the script is done, we’ll discuss show bibles, contests and fellowships, and all the steps on the long road toward those coveted TV writing jobs. But more importantly, congratulations: by the end of week 6 you will have finished a complete pilot script!

title: Script Camp Writers Lab (Paid Class)
description:
The Script Camp Writers Lab is an intensive weekly script development session where Conor Kyle and other pro screenwriters are available to help you work through specific problems with your project.

Through one-on-one chats and group discussion, lab participants engage in a rigorous process that helps you get past whatever issues you encounter during the outlining and writing process.

How to join the Writers Lab:

title: How to Write a Movie! Feature Screenwriting Bootcamp: Week 1 (FREE)
description:
**Week 1: Why this story? (Aug 21)**
Now that you’ve narrowed down your high-concept idea, we will ask the simple questions: why this story? Why now? What is both timely and universal in your idea? We will begin to chisel away at the central dramatic question of your script, and design a plan to explore this theme from all angles. You’ll refine and polish your story’s premise, and begin the outlining process with your project sketchbook.

The intention behind the bootcamp is not for you to write a perfect script, but instead to teach you the organization skills, discipline, and craft techniques that will set you on the path to becoming a professional screenwriter.

The 8-week bootcamp starts August 21 and continues weekly through October 9. Conor takes you from a blank page to the first draft of a complete feature screenplay, walking you through the entire process of conceiving, outlining, and writing a 90-120 page script.

***About the Instructor:***
**Conor Kyle** has written for Shudder's Creepshow (2019) and placed twice in the Nicholl Fellowship with his scripts “Peter and the Wolves” (quarterfinals, also Launchpad top 10) and The Tube (semifinals). His screenplays have also been featured on special sections of the annual Hit List, Young & Hungry List, Spec Book, and on Tracking Board’s “Best Writers of the Year” booklet. He writes everything from stage musicals to Westerns to horror movies. Follow Conor on **[Twitter](https://twitter.com/TheScriptCamp), [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCHTkV9mxO1_wqfUsoGe7mXg/videos)** and **[Twitch](https://www.twitch.tv/scriptcamp)**

**How to join the free class:**

* Hit the RSVP button
* Then join us on Discord: **[https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna](https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna)**

**How to join Conor's 8-week Screenwriting Bootcamp:**

* You can either purchase the full course “a la carte”: **[https://scriptcamp.net/classes/](https://scriptcamp.net/classes/)**
* Or start the free trial Unlimited Script Camp membership with access to over 70 hours of live classes, workshops and bootcamps every month, including the new Script Camp Writers Lab: **[https://scriptcamp.net/membership/](https://scriptcamp.net/membership/)**

***8-Week Feature Bootcamp course schedule:***

**Week 1: Why this story? (Aug 21)**
Now that you’ve narrowed down your high-concept idea, we will ask the simple questions: why this story? Why now? What is both timely and universal in your idea? We will begin to chisel away at the central dramatic question of your script, and design a plan to explore this theme from all angles. You’ll refine and polish your story’s premise, and begin the outlining process with your project sketchbook.

**Week 2: Outlining I – Story Beats (Aug 28)**
Now that you’ve selected your feature idea, we’ll look at the key building blocks of your story. Chiefly: how to structure and place key scenes, and begin to establish connective tissue between them.

**Week 3: Outlining II – Scene Cards (Sep 4)**
Time to organize your ideas into a much more detailed outline. These “scene cards” will each feature a key moment of your story, and you’ll organize your brainstormed sketches into a cohesive, page-by-page plan for your upcoming feature.

**Week 4: Beginnings (Sep 11)**
It’s time to get going on your feature! This class will feature a both a FAQ / troubleshooting session (where we address and fill holes in your outlines before you begin) and a lecture on first acts: everything from opening image to the act break. From this class on, you’ll have to write a few pages a day to keep up with the benchmarks and get optimal feedback on your script.

**Week 5: Transitions (Sep 18)**
You’ve finished the first 20-30 pages of your script, so this class focuses on your first act break. How do we diagnose whether we’ve done everything we need to do in act one? We’ll heavily emphasize a propulsive boost into the “fun and games” of your script’s second act, balancing B-stories, and more.

**Week 6: Second Act (Sep 25)**
This class follows us into the deep dark woods of your script: the second act. We’ll go over the creation of sequences and setpieces, and review how to find the fun in your premise and mine its full potential.

**Week 7: Escalation (Oct 2)**
Many newer writers begin to falter or repeat themselves in this section of a script, so we’ll focus on keeping up the energy and narrative push, as well as beginning to answer questions and pay off setups from earlier in the script. Danger and tension must ramp up significantly in this section, and we’ll make sure our scripts are doing just that.

**Week 8: Endings (Oct 9)**
In our eighth and final week, we will work through the difficult final act of your script. How do we conclude subplots? How can we leave the reader feeling satisfied with the ideal “unexpected yet inevitable” conclusion? By the end of this week you will complete your 90-120 page first draft!

title: Script Camp Table Reads: Features, TV Pilots & Shorts (FREE)
description:
**Complete Feature/Pilot Table Reads - Submissions Now OPEN!**

Join us for **Feature/Pilot/Short Table Reads**! Sign up to submit your complete Feature Film screenplay, TV Pilot, or short!

The deadline to submit your script is **Friday at midnight!**

Everyone is welcome to join, whether you want to read a part or just listen in!

**How to attend?**
⦁ This event is free and everyone is welcome, whether you want to read a part or just listen in.
⦁ Space is limited, so be sure to hit the RSVP button
⦁ Then join us on Discord at [https://discord.gg/RxuueacNQV](https://discord.gg/RxuueacNQV)

**How to Submit Your Script:**
⦁ If you have not already done so, be sure to join us on Discord: [https://discord.gg/RxuueacNQV](https://discord.gg/RxuueacNQV)
⦁ Everyone can submit any short screenplay/excerpt (up to 5 pages) to the table reads, using this google form. Please include your Discord username.
**5 Page Table Reads Submission Form**: [https://forms.gle/eWTvToafZduiT8aa7](https://forms.gle/eWTvToafZduiT8aa7)
⦁ If you would like to submit your **Feature** (up to 125 pages) or **TV Pilot** (up to 80 pages), you must earn the @TableReader role by participating in table reads or providing helpful feedback to other members. Then complete this google form. Please include your Discord username. **Feature/TV Pilot Submission Form:** [https://forms.gle/h6PL66RBB8zS9Nie9](https://forms.gle/h6PL66RBB8zS9Nie9)

*Please submit your script by midnight on Friday! Keep in mind, your script must be in standard screenplay format.*

***FAQ:***

**Q: I don’t have a script ready yet. Is it okay if I just join to listen and learn?**
A: Absolutely! This workshop is entirely free and everyone is welcome to join.

**Q: My writing is ____ genre, is that okay?**
A: Yes! Any genre is OK.

**Q: I’m worried that my script sucks, should I still bring it?**
A: This is a process. Nobody's script will be perfect. We’re here to support you, which means pointing out the parts that are awesome and providing honest feedback for improvement.

**Q: My script is not in standard screenwriting format.**
A: Please re-type your using screenwriting software before uploading it to the google form. If it is not in standard screenplay format, it’s difficult for readers to provide helpful feedback on the pacing and many other aspects of your script. Here’s a list of some free screenwriting software options you can use:

Writer Duet free trial version (no watermark, max 3 scripts) [https://www.writerduet.com/script/](https://www.writerduet.com/script/)
Writer Solo (separate software made by Writer Duet, free, no watermark, unlimited scripts) [https://writersolo.com/](https://writersolo.com/)
Fade In Free version (small watermark, unlimited scripts) [https://www.fadeinpro.com/page.pl?content=download](https://www.fadeinpro.com/page.pl?content=download)
Kit Scenarist (no watermark, unlimited scripts) [https://kitscenarist.ru/en/index.html](https://kitscenarist.ru/en/index.html)
Highland 2 free version (watermark / mac only, unlimited scripts) [https://apps.apple.com/us/app/highland-2/id1171820258?ls=1&mt=12](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/highland-2/id1171820258?ls=1&mt=12)
Drama Queen (unlimited scripts) [https://dramaqueen.info/dramaqueen-free-lifetime-en/?lang=en](https://dramaqueen.info/dramaqueen-free-lifetime-en/?lang=en)
Trelby (no watermark, unlimited scripts) [https://www.trelby.org/download/](https://www.trelby.org/download/)
Arc Studio Pro (no watermark, max 2 scripts) [https://www.arcstudiopro.com/pricing](https://www.arcstudiopro.com/pricing)
Scripto (no watermark, unlimited scripts, max 3 collaborators) [https://www.scripto.live/](https://www.scripto.live/)
Final Draft (60 days free trial) [https://trial.finaldraft.com/](https://trial.finaldraft.com/)
Prewrite (no watermark, max 1 script) [https://prewrite.com/](https://prewrite.com/)

description:

We’ll dive into the construction of your premise, characters and story world as you refine the concept for the project you will write during the intensive six-week TV Pilot Bootcamp. ***Bring your loglines and original show ideas!***

The complete six-week **TV Pilot Bootcamp** course meets weekly on Friday (US) / Saturdays (Australia/NZ). Pro screenwriter **Conor Kyle** takes you from blank page to the first draft of a complete original pilot screenplay. You’ll attend a two-hour class session each week in which we’ll walk through the entire process of conceiving, outlining, and writing an original TV pilot.

***About the Instructor:***
**Conor Kyle** has written for Shudder's Creepshow (2019) and placed twice in the Nicholl Fellowship with his scripts “Peter and the Wolves” (quarterfinals, also Launchpad top 10) and The Tube (semifinals). His screenplays have also been featured on special sections of the annual Hit List, Young & Hungry List, Spec Book, and on Tracking Board’s “Best Writers of the Year” booklet. • Join us on Discord: [https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna](https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna)

**How to enroll in the complete 6-week TV Pilot Bootcamp:**
• You can either purchase the course *“a la carte”*: [https://scriptcamp.net/product/classes/](https://scriptcamp.net/product/classes/)
• Or start your free trial **Unlimited Script Camp** membership with access to over 70 hours of live classes, workshops and bootcamps every month, including the weekly Script Camp Writers Lab: [https://scriptcamp.net/membership/](https://scriptcamp.net/membership/)

***Complete 6-Week Bootcamp Course Schedule:***

**Week 1: Loglines & Sketchbook (Aug 26)**
We begin this course by zeroing in on the high concept core premise, and developing two separate loglines to express this idea. The first is the series logline, and the second is the pilot logline. These will act as guideposts to keep us on track through construction of your script. We’ll also start filling out our sketchbooks, brainstorming a few different episode ideas from our prospective first season, to get a sense of where your show should begin, and where it’s headed.

**Week 2: Story Beats (Sep 2)**
Now that you have a solid grasp on the basics of your show, you’ll begin sketching out the key characters, plot points, and set-pieces in your pilot episode. Whether you’re planning for a 30-minute or 60-minute episode, you’ll need to carefully structure and pace your outline to ensure that you’re delivering on the promise of your premise quickly and efficiently enough.

**Week 3: Scene Cards (Sep 9)**
Time to start getting concrete. This class focuses on nailing down every scene from your pilot as a “scene card,” which is essentially a synopsis for every single major moment in your show. ScriptCamp heavily emphasises this part of the process, and we will make an exhaustive roadmap through your entire story before starting pages next week.

**Week 4: Beginnings (Sep 16)**
Now is when you’ll put pen to paper and begin drafting pages. You’ll have to write an act a week in order to keep up with the group’s milestones, and this is the first of three weekly check-ins in which we’ll evaluate your progress, troubleshoot issues, and give feedback.

**Week 5: Second Act (Sep 23)**
You’re in the thick of your script, and this class will feature both a short lecture on second acts and setpieces, as well as a lot of feedback on your in-progress pages. The goal is to keep your energy and momentum up as you approach the finale of your story, so we’ll ensure that your pacing, plot progression, and character arcs are all taking the reader in the right direction.

**Week 6: Endings (Sep 30)**
Time to finish strong. We’ll again diagnose issues with your in-progress scripts, and discuss crafting the ideal “unexpected but inevitable” finale. Plus, where do we go from here? Once the script is done, we’ll discuss show bibles, contests and fellowships, and all the steps on the long road toward those coveted TV writing jobs. But more importantly, congratulations: by the end of week 6 you will have finished a complete pilot script!

title: Script Camp Writers Room (FREE)
description:
During each Writers Room session, we simply gather here to connect remotely and write together at the same time. This supports us in building a regular writing discipline. You are welcome to join us and see if this helps your writing process.

Please note that no one will read or critique your writing in this session. Writers Room sessions are a safe space for screenwriters to work on their craft. We gather here solely in order to write our screenplays during the scheduled time.

Great time to get your logline ready for the upcoming bootcamp, or polish off your pages for the Script Swap & Table Reads!

**Schedule:**
• First 15 minutes: Greetings & introductions / socializing
• Remainder of the 4 hour session: Everyone writes in quiet, with hourly 5 minute break to check in.
• You can join later or leave early at any time - no need to attend the full 4 hour session.

**How to join the Writers Room?**
• The Writers Room is free to join, everyone is welcome!
• Just hit the RSVP button
• Then hop in the voice channel here: [https://discord.gg/KGyUqXu2dZ](https://discord.gg/KGyUqXu2dZ)

title: How to Write a Movie! Feature Screenwriting Bootcamp: Week 2 (Paid Class)
description:
**Week 2: Outlining I – Story Beats (Aug 28)**
Now that you’ve selected your feature idea, we’ll look at the key building blocks of your story. Chiefly: how to structure and place key scenes, and begin to establish connective tissue between them.

The intention behind the bootcamp is not for you to write a perfect script, but instead to teach you the organization skills, discipline, and craft techniques that will set you on the path to becoming a professional screenwriter.

The 8-week bootcamp starts August 21 and continues weekly through October 9. Conor takes you from a blank page to the first draft of a complete feature screenplay, walking you through the entire process of conceiving, outlining, and writing a 90-120 page script.

***About the Instructor:***
**Conor Kyle** has written for Shudder's Creepshow (2019) and placed twice in the Nicholl Fellowship with his scripts “Peter and the Wolves” (quarterfinals, also Launchpad top 10) and The Tube (semifinals). His screenplays have also been featured on special sections of the annual Hit List, Young & Hungry List, Spec Book, and on Tracking Board’s “Best Writers of the Year” booklet. He writes everything from stage musicals to Westerns to horror movies. Follow Conor on **[Twitter](https://twitter.com/TheScriptCamp), [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCHTkV9mxO1_wqfUsoGe7mXg/videos)** and **[Twitch](https://www.twitch.tv/scriptcamp)**

**How to join Conor's 8-week Screenwriting Bootcamp:**

* You can either purchase the full course “a la carte”: **[https://scriptcamp.net/classes/](https://scriptcamp.net/classes/)**
* Or start the free trial Unlimited Script Camp membership with access to over 70 hours of live classes, workshops and bootcamps every month, including the new Script Camp Writers Lab: **[https://scriptcamp.net/membership/](https://scriptcamp.net/membership/)**
* Then join us on Discord: **[https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna](https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna)**

***8-Week Feature Bootcamp course schedule:***

**Week 1: Why this story? (Aug 21)**
Now that you’ve narrowed down your high-concept idea, we will ask the simple questions: why this story? Why now? What is both timely and universal in your idea? We will begin to chisel away at the central dramatic question of your script, and design a plan to explore this theme from all angles. You’ll refine and polish your story’s premise, and begin the outlining process with your project sketchbook.

**Week 2: Outlining I – Story Beats (Aug 28)**
Now that you’ve selected your feature idea, we’ll look at the key building blocks of your story. Chiefly: how to structure and place key scenes, and begin to establish connective tissue between them.

**Week 3: Outlining II – Scene Cards (Sep 4)**
Time to organize your ideas into a much more detailed outline. These “scene cards” will each feature a key moment of your story, and you’ll organize your brainstormed sketches into a cohesive, page-by-page plan for your upcoming feature.

**Week 4: Beginnings (Sep 11)**
It’s time to get going on your feature! This class will feature a both a FAQ / troubleshooting session (where we address and fill holes in your outlines before you begin) and a lecture on first acts: everything from opening image to the act break. From this class on, you’ll have to write a few pages a day to keep up with the benchmarks and get optimal feedback on your script.

**Week 5: Transitions (Sep 18)**
You’ve finished the first 20-30 pages of your script, so this class focuses on your first act break. How do we diagnose whether we’ve done everything we need to do in act one? We’ll heavily emphasize a propulsive boost into the “fun and games” of your script’s second act, balancing B-stories, and more.

**Week 6: Second Act (Sep 25)**
This class follows us into the deep dark woods of your script: the second act. We’ll go over the creation of sequences and setpieces, and review how to find the fun in your premise and mine its full potential.

**Week 7: Escalation (Oct 2)**
Many newer writers begin to falter or repeat themselves in this section of a script, so we’ll focus on keeping up the energy and narrative push, as well as beginning to answer questions and pay off setups from earlier in the script. Danger and tension must ramp up significantly in this section, and we’ll make sure our scripts are doing just that.

**Week 8: Endings (Oct 9)**
In our eighth and final week, we will work through the difficult final act of your script. How do we conclude subplots? How can we leave the reader feeling satisfied with the ideal “unexpected yet inevitable” conclusion? By the end of this week (Oct 16) you will complete your 90-120 page first draft!

title: Script Camp Table Reads: Features, TV Pilots & Shorts (FREE)
description:
**Complete Feature/Pilot Table Reads - Submissions Now OPEN!**

Join us for **Feature/Pilot/Short Table Reads**! Sign up to submit your complete Feature Film screenplay, TV Pilot, or short!

The deadline to submit your script is **Friday at midnight!**

Everyone is welcome to join, whether you want to read a part or just listen in!

**How to attend?**
⦁ This event is free and everyone is welcome, whether you want to read a part or just listen in.
⦁ Space is limited, so be sure to hit the RSVP button
⦁ Then join us on Discord at [https://discord.gg/RxuueacNQV](https://discord.gg/RxuueacNQV)

**How to Submit Your Script:**
⦁ If you have not already done so, be sure to join us on Discord: [https://discord.gg/RxuueacNQV](https://discord.gg/RxuueacNQV)
⦁ Everyone can submit any short screenplay/excerpt (up to 5 pages) to the table reads, using this google form. Please include your Discord username.
**5 Page Table Reads Submission Form**: [https://forms.gle/eWTvToafZduiT8aa7](https://forms.gle/eWTvToafZduiT8aa7)
⦁ If you would like to submit your **Feature** (up to 125 pages) or **TV Pilot** (up to 80 pages), you must earn the @TableReader role by participating in table reads or providing helpful feedback to other members. Then complete this google form. Please include your Discord username. **Feature/TV Pilot Submission Form:** [https://forms.gle/h6PL66RBB8zS9Nie9](https://forms.gle/h6PL66RBB8zS9Nie9)

*Please submit your script by midnight on Friday! Keep in mind, your script must be in standard screenplay format.*

***FAQ:***

**Q: I don’t have a script ready yet. Is it okay if I just join to listen and learn?**
A: Absolutely! This workshop is entirely free and everyone is welcome to join.

**Q: My writing is ____ genre, is that okay?**
A: Yes! Any genre is OK.

**Q: I’m worried that my script sucks, should I still bring it?**
A: This is a process. Nobody's script will be perfect. We’re here to support you, which means pointing out the parts that are awesome and providing honest feedback for improvement.

**Q: My script is not in standard screenwriting format.**
A: Please re-type your using screenwriting software before uploading it to the google form. If it is not in standard screenplay format, it’s difficult for readers to provide helpful feedback on the pacing and many other aspects of your script. Here’s a list of some free screenwriting software options you can use:

Writer Duet free trial version (no watermark, max 3 scripts) [https://www.writerduet.com/script/](https://www.writerduet.com/script/)
Writer Solo (separate software made by Writer Duet, free, no watermark, unlimited scripts) [https://writersolo.com/](https://writersolo.com/)
Fade In Free version (small watermark, unlimited scripts) [https://www.fadeinpro.com/page.pl?content=download](https://www.fadeinpro.com/page.pl?content=download)
Kit Scenarist (no watermark, unlimited scripts) [https://kitscenarist.ru/en/index.html](https://kitscenarist.ru/en/index.html)

Drama Queen (unlimited scripts) [https://dramaqueen.info/dramaqueen-free-lifetime-en/?lang=en](https://dramaqueen.info/dramaqueen-free-lifetime-en/?lang=en)
Trelby (no watermark, unlimited scripts) [https://www.trelby.org/download/](https://www.trelby.org/download/)
Arc Studio Pro (no watermark, max 2 scripts) [https://www.arcstudiopro.com/pricing](https://www.arcstudiopro.com/pricing)
Scripto (no watermark, unlimited scripts, max 3 collaborators) [https://www.scripto.live/](https://www.scripto.live/)
Final Draft (60 days free trial) [https://trial.finaldraft.com/](https://trial.finaldraft.com/)
Prewrite (no watermark, max 1 script) [https://prewrite.com/](https://prewrite.com/)

In this group we support each other to achieve our writing goals as we develop our comedy TV pilot projects and share comedy writing techniques. The group meets weekly on Mondays (3pm ET / 2pm CT / 12pm PT / 8pm London) and Wednesdays (10am ET / 9am CT / 7am PT / 3pm London).

**How to Join the Group?**

* Note this group is for intermediate to advanced writers. Ideally you have already written at least one TV pilot.
* Please fill out this sign-up form to join the Comedy Pilot Writers Group: [https://forms.gle/bAbnM58cToqUhnKt7](https://forms.gle/bAbnM58cToqUhnKt7)
* Then hop in the voice channel on Discord: [https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna](https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna)

Contact [@bob](https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna) on the Script Camp Discord if you have any questions about the **Comedy Pilot Writers Group.**

If you're interested in starting your own writers group, here's the form to request a new Script Camp writers group: [https://forms.gle/TrHtLVMZdCTpMTvL9](https://forms.gle/TrHtLVMZdCTpMTvL9)

title: Script Camp Writers Room (FREE)
description:
During each Writers Room session, we simply gather here to connect remotely and write together at the same time. This supports us in building a regular writing discipline. You are welcome to join us and see if this helps your writing process.

Please note that no one will read or critique your writing in this session. Writers Room sessions are a safe space for screenwriters to work on their craft. We gather here solely in order to write our screenplays during the scheduled time.

Great time to get your logline ready for the upcoming bootcamp, or polish off your pages for the Script Swap & Table Reads!

**Schedule:**
• First 15 minutes: Greetings & introductions / socializing
• Remainder of the 4 hour session: Everyone writes in quiet, with hourly 5 minute break to check in.
• You can join later or leave early at any time - no need to attend the full 4 hour session.

**How to join the Writers Room?**
• The Writers Room is free to join, everyone is welcome!
• Just hit the RSVP button
• Then hop in the voice channel here: [https://discord.gg/KGyUqXu2dZ](https://discord.gg/KGyUqXu2dZ)

title: Advanced Screenwriters Lab (FREE)
description:
Welcome to the **Advanced Lab**! We are a group of writers serious about improving at the craft. We meet weekly to share our work for feedback and discuss writing techniques.

This is a place for advanced students and emerging writers to continue their journeys by developing new projects on a regular basis and revising completed scripts. You should already have a firm handle on screenwriting fundamentals, with multiple screenplays completed.

**How to join the Advanced Lab?**

* Please complete this sign-up form: [https://forms.gle/w9LJcwqD3MsbYBny5](https://forms.gle/w9LJcwqD3MsbYBny5)
* Then join us on Discord: [https://discord.gg/4Rfkv6MEJ8](https://discord.gg/4Rfkv6MEJ8)

If you have any questions or difficulty completing the form, contact [@fehabhab](https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna) or [@nacho](https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna) on Discord or email [classes@scriptcamp.net](mailto:classes@scriptcamp.net)

title: Script Camp Writers Lab (Paid Class)
description:
The Script Camp Writers Lab is an intensive weekly script development session where Conor Kyle and other pro screenwriters are available to help you work through specific problems with your project.

Through one-on-one chats and group discussion, lab participants engage in a rigorous process that helps you get past whatever issues you encounter during the outlining and writing process.

How to join the Writers Lab:

• You can either purchase the session “a la carte”: https://scriptcamp.net/classes/
• Or start your free trial Unlimited Script Camp membership (US$49/month, includes over 60 hours of live classes, workshops and all the bootcamps every month, plus the weekly Writers Lab): https://scriptcamp.net/membership/
• Then hop on the Script Camp discord server, and get some help with your project: https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna

title: London Writers Cafe June Meetup
description:
This will be the very first Meetup for London Writers Cafe! We've chosen All Bar One on Dean Street as its central and we can discuss future places to meet on our first night!

This is our first opportunity to get to know each other, talk about writing, discuss writers resources and get some inspiration from each other. Look forward to seeing you all!!

title: London Writers Cafe Hyde Park Meetup
description:
Everyone!

Ok, the next meetup will be in Hyde Park! Hopefully the weather will be good, if not, I'm going to arrange an alternative location for us.

Right, I thought it would be a good idea to meet at the Bandstand near the Dell at the Hyde Park entrance. There are some good facilities round here and plenty of space for us! (A map is attached).

If you would like some feedback from the other members, bring some work with you and perhaps we could do read throughs for each other.

Hope you can all make it and I look forward to seeing you all.

PS. REMEMBER TO BRING SOMETHING TO DRINK AND FOOD IF YOU FANCY!

Bohemia

For more information, see https://www.royalparks.gov.uk/docs/park_maps/hyde_park.pdf

title: London Writers Cafe Meetup
description:
CHANGE OF DAY TO WEDNESDAY 6TH SEPTEMBER!!

Hello Everyone!!

Our next London Writers Cafe Meetup will be at 6.30pm onwards on Wednesday September 6th 2006 at The Carpenters Arms pub near Marble Arch.

We have our own room upstairs which will be excellent for our group! We can have readings, discussions and a good chat without being disturbed. Also the bar has a good range of beers and food is available too.

Please feel free to bring your 'Writing' with you!

Its quite central and very easy to get to. Please see below for directions etc.

Do contact me via email if you have any questions or get me on my Mobile: 07941 471563.

I look forward to seeing you all there!

Bohemia.

title: London Writers Cafe Meetup!
description:
Hello Everyone!!

Our next London Writers Cafe Meetup will start around 6:30pm to 7pm on Tuesday October 10th 2006.

The venue is The Carpenters Arms pub near Marble Arch, which will now be our regular location for these meetups as we have a room upstairs just for us!

For this meetup we are asking people to write up to A MAXIMUM OF 500 words on the subject of 'Sex' (Good starting point eh)! Remember, not too long as we will end up reading them into the wee small hours!!

Rules:

This can be drama, poetry, comedy, fiction, non-fiction, anything you like, even a song!
DONT put your name on it, USE A PSEUDONYM (spare those blushes).
All of the group will be reading each others work (sigh of relief)
May even be a prize for the best piece????

Please feel free to bring any other writing which you would like to share with the group too!

Also we have a Guest Speaker at this event! Emma Stroud the Artistic Director of Abandon Theatre will be joining us for a chat, giving us an insight into her work, particulary her interest in new writing.

I look forward to seeing you all there!

Bohemia.

description:

Happy New Year to you all!

Our next London Writers Cafe Meetup will start at 6:30pm on Tuesday 16th January 2007.

The venue is The Carpenters Arms pub near Marble Arch and we have a room upstairs just for us!

For this meetup I'm inviting you (if you want to) to bring a piece of work to the group. Something under 500 WORDS or an extract from something larger would be great.

Don't worry about reading or performing your own work, quite often we read each others.

It can be poetry, short story, factual, a song, anything you like but remember, not too long as we will end up reading them into the wee small hours!!

There is no guest speaker at this meeting. Instead I want to dicuss forthcoming events throughout the year, the possibility of meeting more regularly, talking about our aspirations, our current projects and future ideas.

It's also a good opportunity to get to know you all and socialise.

I look forward to seeing you all there!

Bohemia.

title: London Writers Cafe Meetup for 6th Feb is back on!
description:
Everyone!

I'm pleased to announce we are still going to have a meetup on Tuesday 6th February 2007. All thanks to Hugh, who found a venue for us and checked it out. Big Thanks Hugh!!

Details as follows:

The venue is The Pitcher and Piano at Holborn and we have the back room on the main floor. We start at 6:30pm!

For this meetup I'm inviting you (if you want to) to bring a piece of work to the group. Something under 500 WORDS or an extract from something larger would be great.

It can be poetry, short story, factual, a song, anything you like, just make sure you keep to the word limit so we have plenty of time for feedback and dicussion.

The subject will be 'LOVE' aaahhhhh, ain't that nice? Don't worry about reading or performing your own work, quite often we read each others.

So come and join us for drinks, discuss your work and meet other writers. You will be warmly welcomed.

I look forward to seeing you all there!

Bohemia.

Directions:

From the Holborn underground station, turn south on Kingsway (left out of the underground station main exit) and go approx. 200 meters. Pitcher and Piano is on the left at 42 Kingsway.

title: EVENT - Guest Speaker Simon Trewin - Literary Agent
description:
Everyone,

THIS EVENT IS NOW FULL. ANY PLACES WHICH BECOME AVAILABLE, I WILL CONTACT THOSE ON THE WAITING LIST!!

Many thanks.

Bo

'm pleased and very excited to announce this new Guest Speaker event which will take place on Tuesday 20th February at 7pm. I would like to introduce Simon Trewin from PFD, one of the leading literary and talent agents in Europe.

The event will take place in the conference room at NESTA (my place of work) and will start with Simon discussing the role of an Agent and about his work. This will follow with a Q&A session for you. It should wrap up at about 9pm.

Please note, this event has a maximum of 40 places only, so please make sure you RSVP. If you change your mind at any time, please amend your RSVP to free up a place for someone else.

The event will start at 7:30pm prompt, so please aim to get to the venue at 7pm.

Some info about Simon Trewin......

EVERYTHING YOU EVER WANTED TO ASK ABOUT GETTING AN AGENT AND GETTING PUBLISHED......BUT NEVER DARED ASK

Literary Agent Simon Trewin from Europe's leading literary and talent agency Peters, Fraser and Dunlop talks candidly about the Do's and Don'ts of taking the first step from prose to publication. Leave your pre-conceptions outside and come prepared for a lively interactive sessions with plenty of opportunities for questions - from the basic to the pretentious.

Simon Trewin clients include Jeremy Dyson, Mike Gayle, Danny Wallace, Scarlett Thomas, Andrew Miller and Steven Hall.

Details of how to get to NESTA are below:

NESTA
1 Plough Place
London
EC4A 1DE

Switchboard:
020 7438 2500

Plough Place is located between Fetter Lane and New Fetter Lane

Nearest tubes:
Chancery Lane (Exit 3) - 4mins
Farringdon - 8mins
Aldwych - 12 mins
Holborn - 13mins

Buses:
8, 17, 25, 45, 46, 242, 341 or 521 to Holborn Circus

MAP and DIRECTIONS: https://www.nesta.org.... (https://www.nesta.org.uk/about/contact_us/location_map.aspx)

title: London Writers Cafe Meetup 13th March 2007
description:
Hello Everyone

Our next London Writers Cafe Meetup will start around 6:30pm on Tuesday 13th March 2007.

The venue is The Carpenters Arms pub near Marble Arch and we have a room upstairs just for us!

For this meetup I'm inviting you (if you want to) to do a piece of work with the title - 'Beware The Ides of March - or Mad as a March Hare' as March is a time of Madness supposedly!! Sascha's Idea - I think it's a good one!

But you have to include these words in your work:

March, pots, scum, tea, eyes, lava, dragon, stick, paper, pepper, baby, water, tongue, wrong, slick, darkness and painter.

REMEMBER THE WORD LIMIT IS 500.

Don't worry about reading or performing your own work, quite often we read each others.

It can be poetry, short story, factual, a song, anything you like but remember, not too long as we will end up reading them into the wee small hours!!

I look forward to seeing you all there!

title: London Writers Cafe - Prose Unplugged!
description:
Hello Everyone

Our next London Writers Cafe Meetup will start around 6:30pm on Thursday 26th April 2007.

The venue is The Carpenters Arms pub near Marble Arch and we have a room upstairs just for us!

PROSE UNPLUGGED!

Right you lot, we are going to have a bit of a 'stand up to the mic' session this week.

What I'd like you to do, (if you want to) is to prepare a piece on the topic of 'COMPLAINING'.

We had the pleasure of hearing James and his piece about London Underground which was hilarious, so I thought I want some more of that! Now its your turn!

It can be anything you like, poetry, short story, a song! Try and stick to UNDER 500 words. This is your opportunity to let us hear your stuff!

If you don't fancy performing your own work, there are plenty of us who are willing to get up there read for you. Such a bunch of performers!

Afterwards there will be the necessary socialising......of course!

I look forward to seeing you all there! Any questions, just email me!

Bohemia.

title: London Writers Cafe Meetup - Guest Speaker & Social Event
description:
Hello Everyone

Come and meet Nick Wastnage our Guest Speaker for this Event on Tuesday May 8th 2007 starting at 7pm

Nick is the author of several books, his first being the Electronic Conspirator about a man who fakes his own death, scams millions from the Internet and re-invents himself in a another part of the world!

For a full biography and other information about Nick, check out his website at www.nickwastnage.com

The evening will begin with Nick talking about his work and how he got published. I'm sure you will all have many questions for him too!

Afterwards a good bit of socialising!

I look forward to seeing you all there! Any questions, just email me!

description:
Hello Everyone

We're back! The next meetup will be on Thursday 20th September 2007.

I shall be there from 6:30 onwards and we normally kick off at around 7:30pm

The venue is The Carpenters Arms pub near Marble Arch and we have a room upstairs just for us!

THEME: Actors

Tell us your thoughts on the luvvies.....

This can be in a poem, short story or perhaps a song! Anything you like. Remember, you don't have to bring any work with you at all, just come along and hang out with us and listen to what others have written!

IMPORTANT - PLEASE KEEP THE WORD COUNT TO A MAXIMUM OF 500 WORDS!!

Everyone will have about 5- 7 mins reading their work which will give us all time to discuss and feedback.

Don't worry about reading or performing your own work, quite often we read each others.

Our evenings are always followed by much socialising and many trips to the bar, so please come and join us.

I look forward to seeing you all there!

Bohemia.

Details:

Click on the link under More Information to see the venue and a Map.

How to find it:
Turn right out of the tube and keep walking till you get to Edgware Road. Go up Edgware Road and about 2 Minutes on your right is Seymour Street, look across and you'll see Seymour Place. The Carpenters arms should be in sight!

OR

Turn right out of the tube and then right again up Great Cumberland Street. Turn left at Seymour Street, cross it and then right, up Seymour Place. You'll see the pub a short way up on your right.

For more information, see https://www.fancyapint... .

title: London Writers Cafe - October Meetup!
description:
Hello Everyone

The next meetup will be on Thursday 25th October 2007 at 7pm. Guy will be hosting this meetup and he aims to put the "ass" back into Assistant Organiser!

This week's topic is Money Money Money! Who's got it? Who wants it? Who gives and Who gets? Root of all evil or source of all happiness?

Stuck for ideas? Why not take some inspiration from these pioneering poets:

There's nothing wrong with letting the girls know that you're money and that you want to party. - Vince Vaughan

If you wana look good and not be bummy, girl you better give me that money - Ol' Dirty Bastard

Money, it's a hit, don't give me that do goody good bullshit - Pink Floyd

The venue is The Carpenters Arms pub near Marble Arch and we have a room upstairs just for us!

This can be in a poem, short story or perhaps a song! Anything you like. Remember, you don't have to bring any work with you at all, just come along and hang out with us and listen to what others have written!

IMPORTANT - PLEASE KEEP THE WORD COUNT TO A MAXIMUM OF 500 WORDS!!

Everyone will have about 5- 7 mins reading their work which will give us all time to give you feedback if you want it.

Don't worry about reading or performing your own work, someone else is always willing to perform for you!

Our evenings are always followed by much socialising and many trips to the bar, so please come and join us.

I look forward to seeing you all there!

Guy

title: Bohemia's Last Writers Meetup!
description:
Hello Everyone

I have decided to step down as Organiser of the London Writers Cafe as I want to concentrate on my Theatre work and writing. So this will be my last meetup!

However, your new organiser will be Guy, who will be taking over from December and will whip you all into shape. He will be just brilliant!

So, lets have a good old pre-christmas do on Thursday 29th November at the Carpenters Arms at 7pm. We have a room upstairs just for us!

The subject for you all is 'What I hate about Christmas' (How festive).....I want to hear about your christmas nightmares, throwing mince pies at your granny and the time you showed your knickers at the office party! You've all done it......

This can be in a poem, short story or perhaps a song! Anything you like. Remember, you don't have to bring any work with you at all, just come along and hang out with us and listen to what others have written!

IMPORTANT - PLEASE KEEP THE WORD COUNT TO A MAXIMUM OF 500 WORDS!!

Our evenings are always followed by much socialising and many trips to the bar, so please come and join us.

I look forward to seeing you all there!

Bohemia

title: Writer's Café Winter Bonanza!
description:
Our first meet-up for the year!

Brave the winter chill, and help to usher in the glorious new LWC regime at our time-honoured venue, The Carpenter's Arms. For those unfamiliar with the pub, it's at 12 Seymour Place, right around the corner from Marble Arch tube station.

For a map, click here (https://www.allinlondon.co.uk/mapping/map.php?pc=W1H+7NE)

We'll be rolling in from 7pm, but things probably won't get going till 7.30 or 8, depending on turn-out. Still, get in early for nibbles and contraband shop-bought red wine! The Writer's Group is upstairs, so just navigate your way through the hoardes of rowdy public servants propping up the bar, up the trecherous staircase, through the dank, unlit corridors to our glorious creative sanctuary!

The topic for our inaugural 2008 meet-up is "Secrets". So think of a short story, poem, performance piece or anything else that fits the topic. Note, for first-timers, the topic is applied very loosely!

It could be about secret pasts, secret lovers, or a yearning paean to the discontinuation of the Cadbury Secret bar. There's no word limit, so just bring whatever you're comfortable with sharing.

We normally read out our own work, but if you'd rather remain anonymous, get in touch with me directly through Meetup.com and I'll arrange to have one of our many fine public-speakers read it out for you.

Any questions, please email me: guy *underscore* kerr *at* hotmail.com (email removed due to swarms of Burkina Faso bankers offering millions)

Cheers and hope to see you all there!

Guy

title: London Writers Cafe Tuesday Shindig!
description:
Hi guys, apologies over the delay in scheduling our next meet up. We've had some dramas with our favourite pub, The Carpenters Arms, which is no longer our little secret and has been booked out by all kinds of wacky groups (London Chess Society, anyone?).

So....we've moved our meet up night to Tuesday, 29th April. Hopefully the proximity to the start of the working week won't dissuade our staunch squadron of writers from attending! And it's still at our favourite little not-so-underground-anymore pub, The Carpenters Arms. 12 Seymour Place, a stone's throw from Marble Arch tube and Oxford Street Primark. Click here for a map (https://www.allinlondon.co.uk/mapping/map.php?pc=W1H+7NE)

The theme this time around is Climbing. Could be Social Climbing, Mountain Climbing, Climbing Plants, or just the eternal struggle to climb from one's bed each morning! Please note, the topic is applied very loosely and is just a guide! Your writing can come in many forms, poem, short story, puppet show, up to you! Please try to keep it to under 10 minutes in length, unless you're really good :)

The official start time is 8, but I'll be there just after 7 preparing everything. The Writer's Group is upstairs, so just navigate your way through the hoardes of rowdy public servants propping up the bar, up the trecherous staircase, through the dank, unlit corridors to our glorious creative sanctuary!

Once again, any questions, please email me: guy *underscore* kerr *at* hotmail.com. And apologies for the delay once again, hopefully you're all chomping at the bit to step up and share your work with the world!

Cheers and hope to see you all there!

Guy

title: First meetup of 2009
description:
The new meetings will have a slightly different format to the old ones.

First, there will be time-slots that people can use either to get feedback on a short piece of writing, or to describe a challenge they are facing (plot difficulties, etc) and get suggestions on that. From the poll (https://www.meetup.com/londonwriterscafe/polls/164322/), there is equal interest in both.

Second, there will be no set themes for the readings. I see the primary aim of the group as helping people with their existing work, so priority will be given to those who want feedback on a live project they are working on. Although I'll post a suggested theme each month, this is only for those who are not working on something of their own, and those readings will take a lower priority (ie. we'll come onto them if we have time).

The suggested theme, as befits a new year, is 'new beginnings'. But please, if you are working on something of your own, bring that instead.

The format will be time slots of 15 minutes, which are yours to use as you please. For example, you could do a 5-minute reading and have time for 10 minutes of feedback, or present a plot problem in 2 minutes and have 13 minutes of suggestions. It's entirely up to you, but remember that the more of your time you spend talking, the less time there is left for feedback and input!

The group will run for 2.5 hours, which will allow 10 time-slots. If more than 10 people request a slot, priority is given to those who want input on their own work. If there are more than 10 of those, names will be picked out of a hat (metaphorically speaking; I don't actually own a hat ...).

Payment by Paypal must be made when you RSVP. Funds are used for meetup fees, with any balance going into a pool to buy drinks for the assistant organisers.

This first meeting will run from 7.30-10pm to allow time for the volunteer co-organisers to meet beforehand; future meetings will run from 7-9.30pm.

The Shooting Star is less than 5 mins walk from Liverpool Street station, on the central Line:
https://www.pubandbar-... (https://www.pubandbar-network.co.uk/pubs/directions_london_liverpool%20st_shooting%20star_356.html)
Take the Bishopsgate exit from the main rail concourse, cross the road, turn left and Catherine Wheel Alley is 2nd right. The pub is about 100 metres down on the right-hand side, and we meet in the function room downstairs

Take the Bishopsgate exit from the main rail concourse, cross the road, turn left and Catherine Wheel Alley is 2nd right. The pub is about 100 metres down on the right-hand side, and we meet in the function room downstairs. Please arrive in time to buy a drink at the upstairs bar first so we can start promptly at 7pm.

title: March meeting
description:
The London Writers Cafe is a chance to either get feedback on a short piece of writing, or to describe a challenge you are facing (plot difficulties, writers' block, etc) and get suggestions on that.

There are no set themes for the readings as the primary aim of the group is helping people with their existing work. Priority will thus be given to those who want feedback on a live project. Although I'll post a suggested theme each month, this is only for those who are not working on something of their own, and those readings will take a lower priority (ie. we'll come onto them if we have time).

The suggested theme for March is 'Memories'. But please, if you are working on something of your own, bring that instead.

The format is time slots of 20 minutes, which are yours to use as you please. For example, you could do a 10-minute reading and have time for 10 minutes of feedback, or present a plot problem in 5 minutes and have 15 minutes of suggestions. It's entirely up to you, but remember that the more of your time you spend talking, the less time there is left for feedback and input!

The group will run for 2-2.5 hours, which will allow around six time-slots. If fewer people request slots, we'll be able to spend more time on feedback. If more people request a slot, priority is given to those who want input on their own work. If we still have too many, it'll be first-come, first-served, so don't be shy. :-)

After the formal part of the meeting, we move upstairs for drinks.

Places are limited, so please RSVP Yes and click the 'Pay by paypal' link to secure your place.

The Shooting Star is less than 5 mins walk from Liverpool Street station, on the central Line:
https://www.streetmap.... (https://www.streetmap.co.uk/newmap.srf?x=533427&y=181615&z=0&ar=Y)
Take the Bishopsgate exit from the main rail concourse, cross the road, turn left and Middlesex Street is 2nd right. The pub is about 100 metres down on the right-hand side, and we meet in the function room downstairs. Please arrive before 7pm so you have time to buy a drink at the upstairs bar beforehand, so we can start promptly at 7pm.

To encourage people to arrive on time, slots can only be booked on arrival and will be on a first-come, first-served basis.

title: April meeting
description:
WHAT?
A monthly get-together for London writers who want input on their work.

The meeting takes the form of six time-slots of 20 minutes. You can use this slot in whatever way would help your writing. You might want to:
- read (or bring) a short piece of writing and get feedback on it
- describe a plot problem and get input on it
- get ideas on how to break through writers' block
- or something else entirely

If you are doing a reading, bear in mind that your total slot is 20 minutes, so I recommend your reading is an absolute maximum of 10 minutes, to allow sufficient time for feedback. For poetry, or any work where it can be important to see the printed format of the piece, I recommend bringing along 20 copies of the piece so that we can see it as well as hear it.

WHO?
Anyone who is currently writing, or would like to be.

HOW?
Slots are booked on the night on a first-come, first-served basis. Please arrive before 7pm if you would like to book one. I am there from 6.45pm.

There are no themes for these meetings - just bring whatever you are currently working on.

WHERE?
The Shooting Star is less than 5 mins walk from Liverpool Street station, on the central Line.
*** Meetup's map is wrong, so please follow these directions ***
Take the Bishopsgate exit from the main rail concourse, cross the road, turn left and Middlesex Street is 2nd right. The pub is about 100 metres down on the right-hand side, and we meet in the function room downstairs.

WHEN?
Please arrive before 7pm so you have time to buy a drink at the upstairs bar beforehand and we can start promptly at 7pm. (This hasn't ever happened yet, but I'm a hopeless optimist.)

The formal part of the meeting runs until approximately 9.15pm. At that point, we move upstairs to the bar for general chat and the consumption of liquid sustenance.

IMPORTANT:
Places are limited, so if you RSVP 'Yes' and then find you cannot make it, please change your RSVP to 'No' as soon as you know - and by the night before at the latest. If you RSVP 'Yes' and then fail to show up, you are denying a place to a fellow member who would love to have been there. For this reason, no-shows are suspended from the group.

(Meetup fees for the year have already been covered, so there will be no charge for the rest of the year. I have, however, never been known to refuse a drink!)

title: How to get published
description:
This meeting is for those who have finished writing an unpublished book. The main focus of the evening will be on finding a publisher for a novel, and priority will be given to those who have written a novel.

Speakers will be:
Maria McCarthy: https://www.mariamccar... (https://www.mariamccarthy.co.uk)
Katherine Bling: https://www.singleholi... (https://www.singleholic.com)
Lisa Goll: worked in marketing for publishers (HarperCollins, Harlequin) for 6 years
We are also hoping that an editor from a publisher will be speaking

When you have RSVP'd Yes, you are asked to make a £10 donation to Unicef to secure your place:
https://www.justgiving... (https://www.justgiving.com/how-to-get-published)

Please click on the justgiving link, make your donation then edit your RSVP to include 'Donated' in the comments field here. (To do this, click 'Changed your mind about attending?', leave it as Yes and add your comment.)

Please note that places are limited to 35, and it's now first-come, first-served. Once 35 people have donated, all remaining Maybe RSVPs will be changed to No and the event will be closed.

- get ideas on how to break through writers' block
- or something else entirely

If you are doing a reading, bear in mind that your total slot is 20 minutes, so I recommend your reading is an absolute maximum of 10 minutes, to allow sufficient time for feedback. For poetry, or any work where it can be important to see the printed format of the piece, I recommend bringing along 20 copies of the piece so that we can see it as well as hear it.

WHO?
Anyone who is currently writing, or would like to be.

HOW?
Slots are booked on the night on a first-come, first-served basis. Please arrive before 7pm if you would like to book one. I am there from 6.45pm.

Please bring a piece with you to read even if you think you don't want a slot - it's not uncommon for people to change their minds when they see how friendly we are. :-)

WHERE?
The Shooting Star is less than 5 mins walk from Liverpool Street station, on the central Line.
Meetup's map is wrong, so please follow these directions:
Take the Bishopsgate exit from the main rail concourse, cross the road, turn left and Middlesex Street is 2nd right. The pub is about 100 metres down on the right-hand side, and we meet in the function room downstairs.

WHEN?
Please arrive before 7pm so you have time to buy a drink at the upstairs bar beforehand, so we can start promptly at 7pm. (This hasn't ever happened yet, but I'm a hopeless optimist.)

The 'formal' part of the meeting runs until approximately 9.15pm. At that point, we move upstairs to the bar for general chat and the consumption of liquid sustenance.

title: LWC meetup - Monday nights
description:
London Writers Cafe is on again...

LWC is a friendly get-together for London writers who want input, encouragement or feedback on their work. It's open to all writers; those who have just started to those who have had work published.

BTW - At this one, I'll be doing a quick session on online marketing techniques every writer can use. This will include; websites to post your work and build a following, how to start and use a blog, search engine marketing, social networks and how to find your audience.

Then we'll get back to regular schedule programming...

The meeting consists of six time-slots of 20 minutes. You can use this slot in whatever way would help your writing.

You might want to:
- read (or bring) a short piece of writing and get feedback on it
- describe a plot problem and get input on it
- get ideas on how to break through writers' block
- hear about writing events, news and website tools to use
- network with other writers

Please bring ten copies for group members to share. If you don't have access to a printer, don't worry - please email it to me and I'll print copies for you.

If you are doing a reading, bear in mind that your total slot is 20 minutes, so I recommend your reading maximum of 10 minutes and allowing sufficient time for group feedback.

Slots are booked on the night on a first-come, first-served basis. Please email me asap if you'd like a spot. We get booked up fast these days!

Costs: £2 per session; paying by cash on the night or PayPal is set up when you RSVP.

Location:
The Shooting Star is less than 5 mins walk from Liverpool Street station, on the central Line.

Directions: Take the Bishopsgate exit from the main rail concourse, cross the road, turn left and Middlesex Street is 2nd right. The pub is about 100 metres down on the right-hand side, and we meet in the function room downstairs.

Please call or text me on 07967175578 if you need directions.

Looking forward to seeing everyone again :)

best,
Lisa (LWC Crowd Controller)

title: LWC meetup - Thursday nights with special publishing talk!
description:
Special guest speaker at London Writers' Cafe!

Ex-publisher and journalist turned novelist and scriptwriter, Susan Oudot (https://www.meetup.com/londonwriterscafe/members/12052691/), will be joining us to talk about the publishing process and markets for scripts.
I'll be extending the attendance limit to 35 members so please invite guests.

This meeting will be focused on Susan's talk but we will also have a little time to read or discuss current projects too.

London Writers' Cafe is a monthly get-together for London writers who want input on their work.
Attendees can reserve a time-slot of roughly 10 minutes each to read out their work and then 10 minutes for feedback.

If you don't have access to a printer - please email it to me and I'll print copies for you.

Looking forward to seeing everyone again :)
Lisa

Costs: £2 per session. Please pay by Paypal or let me know that you'll be bringing cash by email.

title: Getting published talk with guest authors plus Q&A
description:
A special event comes to the London Writer's Cafe!

Come along to hear talks from three successfully published authors; Sue Moorcroft, Karen Mahoney and Leigh Russell. We'll also have an fiction editor from HarperCollins UK followed by a panel discussion of Q&As from the audience.
This event aims to unveil some of the most common myths around getting published and tips from those who have made it

A bit more about our guest authors:
Sue Moorcroft (https://www.suemoorcroft.com/)
In her own words: I'm a writer. I spend most of the week - and part of the weekend, and also some evenings - writing, mainly romantic fiction. The family are used to me and no-one ever suggests I get A Proper Job.

Karen Mahoney (https://kazmahoney.com/)
In her own words: I write mostly for young adults, but have a number of projects underway and am always looking to challenge myself with new things. Visit the Books section to learn more about my forthcoming publications and works in progress. My first YA novel, The Iron Witch, will be published in the US in February 2011 and in Australia, March 2011.

Leigh Russell (https://leighrussell.blogspot.com/)
CUT SHORT, her first novel, has broken sales records in bookshops around the UK. A schedule of her other appearances can be found on her publisher's website.
In her own words: You may have heard me interviewed on one of many BBC Radio stations, or seen me featured or quoted in a newspaper. I am a member of the Curzon Group and post regularly on their blog. ROAD CLOSED, the second in the series, will be published in June 2010.

Laura Deacon, Fiction Editor
We'll also have Laura Deacon, editor at Blue Door Books (https://www.harpercollins.co.uk/about-harpercollins/Imprints/blue-door/Pages/Blue-Door.aspx), talking about the submission and publishing process. She'll also be there to answer questions from guests from an editorial perspective.

Spaces will be capped at 40 people so please RSVP early.
The normal meetup time has changed to 6:30 so we have enough time to get through the talks and get to question time. As a courtesy to the speakers, please be on time.

Please feel free to invite friends to this meetup and share the event on your social networks, if you have them :)

Active members of LWC will be given first priority. A £6.50 charge for this event will be to cover costs of the speakers attending. Please pay by PayPal when you RSVP or email me that you'd rather pay on the night in cash.

Any questions, please get in touch by email. Hopefully, this event will be just as successful as the last one!

Location and direction details:
The Shooting Star is less than 5 mins walk from Liverpool Street station, on the central Line.
Take the Bishopsgate exit from the main rail concourse, cross the road, turn left and Middlesex Street is 2nd right. The pub is about 100 metres down on the right-hand side, and we meet in the function room downstairs.

title: LWC meetup with special guest - Jill McGivering
description:
Special guest: Jill McGivering is a BBC foreign news journalist who’s specialised in Asia for more than 20 years. She’s been the BBC Correspondent in Hongkong, Delhi and Washington – and is now based in London but reporting frequently from the region.

Her first novel, THE LAST KESTREL, is set in Helmand Province in Afghanistan and draws on her own experiences there.
Browse The Last Kestral on Amazon UK

title: LWC meetup - Thursday nights
description:
New - come along to LWC for Thursday night fun. My thanks to everyone who liked this idea.

London Writers' Cafe is a monthly get-together for London writers who want input on their work.
Attendees can reserve a time-slot of roughly 10 minutes each to read out their work and then 10 minutes for feedback.

You can use this slot in whatever way would help your writing.

You might want to:
- read (or bring) a short piece of writing and get feedback on it
- describe a plot problem and get input on it
- get ideas on how to break through writers' block
- or something else entirely

Slots are booked on the night on a first-come, first-served basis. Please email me (lisagoll@hotmail.com) if you'd like to read so I can reserve your space. If possible, please bring copies for group members as this gives better feedback.

If you don't have access to a printer - please email it to me and I'll print copies for you.

Looking forward to seeing everyone again :)
Lisa

Costs: £2 per session; paying by cash or PayPal is set up when you RSVP.

Location:
The Shooting Star is less than 5 mins walk from Liverpool Street station, on the central Line.
Meetup's map is wrong, so please follow these directions:

title: Which Stories Make the Best Screen Sensations with Agent Hannah Weatherill
description:
Agent Hannah Weatherill joins us to share what makes a novel fit for the big screen and how agents work with film and TV producers all over the world to find the next screen sensation.

For debut writers and authors, the landscape of film and TV production can seem a bit of a mystery but Hannah's experience of working and reading for the industry to find the hottest new talent means we'll know a lot more after this event. If you're thinking that your novel or short story would make an excellent film or Netflix series, come along and find out more about how your future agent could make that happen!

Hannah and I will talk for about an hour and then open up to questions from all of you. Hannah's happy to answer any general questions about submitting to her and her colleagues at Northbank Talent during the Q&A too.

Hannah is responsible for Northbank’s fiction representation, spanning all genres of adult fiction. She also heads up our book-to-screen rights business, representing film & tv rights both for Northbank’s clients and on behalf of selected third party literary agencies. Hannah has extensive experience of the book, film & tv markets both in the UK and internationally, having previously worked as a literary scout for the UK market on behalf of production companies and foreign language publishers and as both an editor and translator.

**Northbank Talent Management** is a talent and literary agency based in central London representing thought leaders, broadcasters, writers and content creators across all media throughout the world. Their team has decades of collective experience in the publishing, broadcast, brand licensing and corporate speaking industries which makes for a powerful offering in full-service talent representation. **They are actively seeking new clients and welcome all submissions whether from debut or established talent.** View the submission guide here: https://www.northbanktalent.com/contact/

TICKETS: £18 and please follow the steps to pay via PayPal when you RSVP. NOTE: Refunds will only be provided if the meetup is cancelled by us. No exceptions. We cannot offer credit for another session if you decide not to attend on the day. Please change your status to NOT GOING if you no longer plan to attend. We often have people on the waiting list and we'd hate for them to miss out.

title: *Central* Creative Writing Workshop (In Person)
description:
In these fiction writing workshops, we have 3-4 writers reading their work aloud for editorial feedback, advice and encouragement. You're very welcome to come along to listen as you'll not be asked to contribute to the group feedback until you decide to do so. Most writers come along to a few sessions before offering feedback, commenting or requesting to read. Observe first and contribute whenever you want to, that's completely all right by us. You'll be surprised by how much you can learn by listening to others' work and feedback.

For people reading, pieces must be 3,500 words or less as you'll have 15-20mins reading time and 10mins of group feedback (30mins total) and all discussion is moderated by your host. We ensure that all writing feedback is constructive and respectful and we've been running these workshops as a safe place for writers since 2006.

If you'd like to read, please post a comment below. Spots are given on a first ask, first given basis with a couple of reserve spots. You must have booked your place before making a request to read.

If you are reading, please bring 5-10 copies of your pages so members can make additional editing notes for you during the reading. Please notify us by commenting below if you have to pull out of reading after your place has been confirmed. Pulling out too many times may result in us refusing your next request to read.

TICKETS: £8.50 and please follow the steps to pay via PayPal when you RSVP

NOTE: Refunds will only be provided if the meetup is cancelled by us. No exceptions. We cannot offer credit for another session if you decide not to attend on the day. Please change your status to NOT GOING if you no longer plan to attend. We often have people on the waiting list and we'd hate for them to miss out.
