title: Special Creative Writing Workshop (In Person) for First Timers Only
description:
**A creative writing workshop exclusively for writers who have NEVER BEEN to any of our other events before, please feel welcome!** We're putting on this event for any writer who finds it comforting to know that everyone there is a newbie like them. We understand how daunting it can be to enter a group where others know each other so we're trying this out!
In this workshop, we invite two first-timers attending to read a piece of their work (up to 3,000 words) for feedback, advice and encouragement from the rest of the group. We can offer feedback on any storytelling form - part of a novel, short stories, screenplays or scripts - so long as it is under the word count. All feedback is constructive and respectful and moderated by your host. We've been holding these sessions as a safe space for writers of all kinds since 2006.

An example of what constructive feedback looks like: *'I liked this section for its energy, but have you thought about pacing it differently in this bit? I found it lagged because of too many adjectives.**'***
We always refer to what's on the page to give specific examples on the strengths and weaknesses of the storytelling or writing. Feedback is never personal nor offered without some evidence wherever possible.

You're very welcome to come along to listen, as you'll not be asked to contribute to the group feedback until you decide to do so. Observe first and contribute whenever you want to, that's completely all right by us. You'll be surprised by how much you can learn by listening to others' work and feedback.

For people reading, pieces must be 3,000 words or less as you'll have 35mins in total to read your piece and hear the feedback from the group. For the rest of the time, we'll spend talking about our writing projects, struggles and goals, so this session will be more relaxed than our regular workshops. Normally, we'll gather in the bar after the session for a few drinks and a chat too.

**If you'd like to read at this workshop,** please post a (the) comment below (in the event discussion) *'I'd like to read'* and we'll confirm. Spots are given on a first ask, first given basis, with a reserve spot in case someone drops out. If you are reading, please bring 5-10 copies of your pages so the others can make additional notes and comments for you during the reading. Please notify us ASAP by commenting below if you have to pull out of reading after your place has been confirmed.

You must have booked your place before making a request to read.

TICKETS: £8.50 and please follow the steps to pay via PayPal when you book your place. T&Cs NOTE: This event is for first timers only and we can see who is a first-timer or not. Refunds will only be provided if the meetup is cancelled by us. No exceptions. We cannot offer credit for another session if you decide not to attend on the day. Please change your status to 'not going' if you no longer plan to attend.

Location: Williamsons Tavern is located in a courtyard off Bow Lane in Cheapside, closest tube station is Bank. Address: 1 Groveland Ct, London EC4M 9EH. Come to the basement room downstairs.

title: Meet the Children's Publisher: Elaine Bousfield of ZunTold Publishing (Online)
description:
Drop in to this exclusive discussion and Q&A with Elaine Bousfield of Zuntold Publishing, a new-ish publisher based in Manchester, as she talks about publishing middle grade and young adult fiction that supports mental health and her relentless search for new talent.

Elaine's plan is to publish books that emphasise some aspect of our mental health which means she's actively looking for new authors writing books with a story, character or setting that tackles or touches on the issues around our mental wellbeing, capacity and behaviour. Ideally, beautifully written stories with a lot of heart. If you think your book might be a good fit please do come along and find out more.

[ZunTold](https://www.zuntold.com/index.php?route=information/information&information_id=8) is an independent publishing company, based in Manchester, focusing on publishing good fiction to support mental health and wellbeing. They publish Middle Grade and YA fiction and love working with established voices as well as debut authors. Their authors have been nominated for literary prizes, including the Carnegie Medal, and won prestigious awards too, like the Lancashire Book of the Year Award, chosen solely by young people aged 13-14 years of age. They regularly work with agented authors, but, twice a year, they open our doors to unagented authors of Young Adult (YA) in June and Middle Grade in December. They don't publish picture books at the present time.

This workshop is suitable for writers of all levels.

Costs: £10 per person. Follow the steps to pay via PayPal when you RSVP and refunds will only be offered if the meetup is cancelled by admin. After you RSVP you'll see a link in the event location box. Just click on this at the time and date of the workshop. Google Meets will then automatically connect your computer to the session. Google meets works best with Chrome, so use this browser if possible.

Try the official Meetup app to receive last-minute updates and notifications about our events as they happen to your phone: **https://www.meetup.com/apps/**

title: Getting started with fiction writing
description:
Writing coach and editor, Karen, gets down to basics in this online session. In response to requests for more help for beginners, these sessions will cover elements of writing stories including plot, character development, dialogue, setting, the language of different styles and genres and much more.
The sessions are designed primarily for people starting their journey of writing short stories or novels, but all writers are welcome.

Come ready to take notes and learn in a fun, informal and informative session.
Bring questions - there will be 30 minutes of Q & A at the end.

title: Writers talking about writing
description:
This is a group meeting for writers of all levels of experience to come together and talk about writing.
We can talk about our successes and challenges.
We can talk about our work in progress, or new ideas.
We can talk theory, craft, experience and more.

We may have specific topics such as setting and world-building, plot, dialogue, character development, or others. Or we may just respond to questions in the group. Come along and find out more.

Come and join your fellow writers for an enjoyable hour of writerly chat.

Looking forward to seeing you there.

description:
Writing coach and editor, Karen, gets down to basics in this online session. In response to requests for more help for beginners, these sessions will cover elements of writing stories including plot, character development, dialogue, setting, the language of different styles and genres and much more.
The sessions are designed primarily for people starting their journey of writing short stories or novels, but all writers are welcome.

Come ready to take notes and learn in a fun, informal and informative session.
Bring questions - there will be 30 minutes of Q & A at the end.

title: Writers talking about writing
description:
This is a group meeting for writers of all levels of experience to come together and talk about writing.
We can talk about our successes and challenges.
We can talk about our work in progress, or new ideas.
We can talk theory, craft, experience and more.

We may have specific topics such as setting and world-building, plot, dialogue, character development, or others. Or we may just respond to questions in the group. Come along and find out more.

Come and join your fellow writers for an enjoyable hour of writerly chat.

Looking forward to seeing you there.

title: Writing Meetup
description: All you need to bring is an idea and something to write on. You are responsible for the purchase of your own food or drink.

title: Writing Meetup
description:
All you need is an idea and something to write on! Since this is an evening writing session, you might want to consider bringing headphones to block out background noise.

We'll start off the meeting with introductions to welcome any new writers (in addition to any questions or comments you might have). Then, we'll get cracking!

I know this event isn't exactly 2 weeks after the first. I'm on vacation from October 5 - 21 and won't be available to run the event until I'm back.

Please note: Everyone is responsible for their own food and drink. Depending on number of responses the venue may change.

title: Writes & Bites
description:
Writes & Bites gives us writers the opportunity to discuss anything and everything writing! It is a 100% social event, so no laptops, pens or paper. Just bring your wonderful self and any questions or topics you want to cover.

The format of the evening will vary. We will start off rather organized with a specific writing question or concern. If a few folks start discussing something of interest, while others take the conversation somewhere else, that's fine! The main purpose of this event is to socialize with other writers.

You are responsible for your own food and drink.

title: Writing Meetup
description:
For this meeting, all you need is an idea and something to write on! All skill levels and genres of writing are welcome.

We'll start off the meeting with introductions and a bit of a chat (which usually runs about 30 minutes). Then, we'll start writing for about 1 - 1.5 hours and will end with some time for questions, comments, etc.

I will attempt to arrive early to grab a table so that we can all sit together. When you arrive, just look for the woman with long blondish hair, black rimmed glasses, and a Canadian accent. (Most of us will also have laptops out or pen and paper).

See you there! :)

All members are responsible for their own food and drink.

title: Writing Meetup
description:
Join us for the first writing meet-up of 2019!

For this meeting, all you need is an idea and something to write on. All skill levels and genres of writing are welcome.

We'll start off the meeting with introductions and a bit of a chat (which usually runs about 30 minutes). Then, we'll start writing for about 1 - 1.5 hours and will end with some time for questions, comments, etc.

See you there! :)

(All members are responsible for their own food and drink.)

title: Writing Feedback Meetup
description:
Our Writer's Feedback Meetup gives you the chance to share your work with other writers/readers. All genres of writing are welcome. If you simply want to read and provide writers with feedback, please join this meetup!

We've got a DropBox folder where I will upload excerpts for the meetup. The idea is that readers will download and read the work prior to the event in order to give in depth feedback. If you wish to participate, I will need your email address to send you the link. You can send me a direct message with that info. If I have your email info already I'll send the link (if you plan on joining us).

One of our members has already graciously offered to go first, but there's space for 1 - 2 more writers! First come first serve, so please indicate your interest in the comments.

Excerpt Guidelines:
- Kindly forward your excerpt to me by January 7th to give everyone enough time to read it by January 17th.
- Try to keep the excerpt at around 3000 words (12 - 13 pages double spaced). There is, of course, some flexibility to this (for example, you have a chapter that's 15 pages or a short story closer to 4000 words, etc.).
- What kind of feedback are you looking for? Provide this info in a comment. It will help us readers to know what to focus on.

Looking forward to giving this a go . . . see you there!

IMPORTANT NOTES: Feedback MUST be constructive. If you read a member's work it is understood that it is confidential and you will not share that members work publicly (or elsewhere). All members are responsible for their food and drink.

title: Book Launch Party!
description:
Come join me in celebration of the release of my third novel . . .

As some of you know, I'm releasing the third book in my series at the beginning of June. While I did a lot of work on this one while living in Canada, I also put in a lot of work during our writing meetups!

Your support and friendship has meant so much to me in my short time here, so I would really love to share and celebrate its release with you all.

Friends and family are absolutely welcome, but please do let me know if you plan to bring a guest(s). I don't want anyone to miss out on cake! :)

title: Writing Meetup
description:
For this meeting, all you need is an idea and something to write with (laptop, or pen and paper). All skill levels and genres of writing are welcome. In this meeting, we do not set writing exercises or suggest themes - attendees are free to work on (or start) any writing project of their choice. It's your space and time to use as you wish.

We'll start off the meeting with introductions and a bit of a chat (which usually runs about 30 minutes). Then, we'll start writing for about 1 - 1.5 hours and will end with some time for questions, comments, and an opportunity to share what you've written with the group if you wish (though this is by no means expected - we also hold regular, more formal, feedback meetings).

See you there!

(All members are responsible for their own food and drink.)

title: Writing Feedback Meetup
description:
Our Feedback Meetings give you the chance to share your work with other writers. All genres welcome. We have time for two pieces each month. First come first served, so please indicate your interest in the comments below or send me a message. Members are also welcome to just read and provide feedback - you don't have to submit something in order to turn up!

We've got a central folder where I will save the pieces. This enables people to download and read prior to the meeting.

* Please forward your work to me at least a week before the meeting date. This will ensure everyone has time to read it.
* The word limit is c3,000, although there is some leeway: no one will get too worried if your article/chapter/short story/whatever is in fact 3,500 words...
* Please indicate what kind of feedback you'd like. This could be something specific, such as comments on the plot or use of language, or perhaps general such as whether people feel it's finished or needs more work.

IMPORTANT: Feedback must be constructive. Members' work is confidential and must NOT be shared outside the group.

title: Writing Feedback Meetup
description:
***Submission Deadline - Monday 11 November***

Our Feedback Meetings give you the chance to share your work with other writers. All genres welcome. We have time for two pieces each month. First come first served, so indicate your interest in the comments below or send me a message.

Members are also welcome to attend simply to provide feedback. We have a central folder for the pieces, which enables attendees to download and read prior to the meeting.

**Please send me your work at least two weeks (a week for attendees to read the pieces, and a week's leeway for me to find a replacement if someone drops out) before we meet. Please also be aware the deadline is STRICT and if you miss it you may lose your slot and have to be critiqued another time. I apologize if that sounds harsh, but it's not meant to. Rather, it's just the most efficient way to organize these sessions! Thank you**

* The nominal word limit is 3,000, although there is some margin: no one will begrudge you a few hundred more if they're needed to complete your article/chapter/short story!
* Please indicate what feedback you'd like. This could be specific, such as comments on the plot or use of language, or general such as whether or not people feel it needs more work.

IMPORTANT: Feedback must be constructive. Members' work is confidential and must NOT be shared outside the group.

title: Writing Meetup
description:
We haven't had a daytime meeting for a while now, so in the run up to Christmas I thought we'd give it a try for those who cannot make it in the evenings.

For this meeting, all you need is an idea and something to write with (laptop, or pen and paper). All skill levels and genres of writing are welcome. In this meeting, we do not set writing exercises or suggest themes - attendees are free to work on (or start) any writing project of their choice. It's your space and time to use as you wish.

We'll start off the meeting with introductions and a bit of a chat (which usually runs about 30 minutes). Then, we'll start writing for about 1 - 1.5 hours and will end with some time for questions, comments, and an opportunity to share what you've written with the group if you wish (though this is by no means expected - we also hold regular, more formal, feedback meetings).

See you there!

(All members are responsible for their own food and drink.)

title: Writes & Bites
description:
Writes and Bites gives us writers the opportunity to discuss anything and everything writing! It is a 100% social event, so no laptops, pens or paper. Just bring your wonderful self and any questions or topics you want to cover.

The format of the evening will vary. We might start off rather organized with a specific writing question or concern. If a few folks start discussing something of interest, while others take the conversation somewhere else, that's fine! The main purpose of this event is to socialize with other writers.

(Members are responsible for their own food and drink.)

title: Writing Feedback Meetup
description:
***Submission Deadline - Monday 03 February***

Our Feedback Meetings give you the chance to share your work with other writers. All genres welcome. We have time for two pieces each month. First come first served, so indicate your interest in the comments below or send me a message.

Members are also welcome to attend simply to provide feedback. We have a central folder for the pieces, which enables attendees to download and read prior to the meeting.

**Please send me your work at least two weeks (a week for attendees to read the pieces, and a week's leeway for me to find a replacement if someone drops out) before we meet. Please also be aware the deadline is STRICT and if you miss it you may lose your slot and have to be critiqued another time. I apologize if that sounds harsh, but it's not meant to. Rather, it's just the most efficient way to organize these sessions! Thank you**

* The nominal word limit is 3,000, although there is some margin: no one will begrudge you a few hundred more if they're needed to complete your article/chapter/short story!
* Please indicate what feedback you'd like. This could be specific, such as comments on the plot or use of language, or general such as whether or not people feel it needs more work.

IMPORTANT: Feedback must be constructive. Members' work is confidential and must NOT be shared outside the group.

title: Online Writing Meetup
description:
WE'RE BACK!!

This is our first online meeting of the Caversham Writers. We are going to try and replicate as best we can the format of our regular writing meetups (see below). To do so, I will end the Zoom component of the meeting after 20 to 30 minutes so that we can all write for an hour without the feeling of being spied upon through our webcams! I will then restart the Zoom meeting and you will be able to rejoin using the same link.

What to expect:
For this meeting, all you need is an idea and something to write with (laptop, or pen and paper). All skill levels and genres of writing are welcome. In this meeting, we do not set writing exercises or suggest themes - attendees are free to work on (or start) any writing project of their choice. It's your space and time to use as you wish.

We'll start off the meeting with introductions and a bit of a chat (which usually runs about 30 minutes). Then, we'll start writing for about an hour and will end with some time for questions, comments, and an opportunity to share something about what you've written with the group if you wish (though this is by no means expected - we also hold regular, more formal, feedback meetings.)

title: Online Writing Meetup
description:
Prompt Night!

We are going to try and replicate as best we can the format of our regular writing meetups (see below). To do so, I will end the Zoom component of the meeting after 20 to 30 minutes so that we can all write for an hour without the feeling of being spied upon through our webcams! I will then restart the Zoom meeting and you will be able to rejoin using the same link.

What to expect:
We'll start off the meeting with introductions and a bit of a chat (which usually runs to about 30 minutes).
I will then introduce a writing prompt for us all to follow, a jumping off point to act as a guide for the writing session. What you do with it, where you go with it, is entirely up to you!
We'll write for about an hour, after which we can talk about where our writing took us and maybe share some of what we produced. No pressure, though - only share whatever you feel comfortable with.

title: Online Writing Meetup
description:
Work In Progress!
This meeting is a chance for you to work on (or start) a project of your own.

We are going to try and replicate as best we can the format of our regular writing meetups (see below). To do so, I will end the Zoom component of the meeting after 20 to 30 minutes so that we can all write for an hour without the feeling of being spied upon through our webcams! I will then restart the Zoom meeting and you will be able to rejoin using the same link.

What to expect:
We'll start off the meeting with introductions and a bit of a chat (which usually runs to about 30 minutes).
In this meeting, we do not set writing exercises or suggest themes - attendees are free to work on (or start) any writing project of their choice. It's your space and time to use as you wish.
We'll write for about an hour, after which we can talk about where our writing took us and maybe share some of what we produced. No pressure, though - only share whatever you feel comfortable with.
(We do have a more formal feedback meeting that you can submit pieces to for review - check our upcoming events for more details.)

title: Bookshare Night - Online
description:
"If you want to be a writer, you must do two things above all others: read lot and write a lot." Stephen King, On Writing.

We cover writing in other regular meetings, in this one we invite you to share what you're reading now, or tell us about a favourite book.

This meeting replaces our 'Writes & Bites' evening, in which we went for a meal out and discussed all things to do with writing and much else besides. A frequent topic was what books we’d read and that is what we’ll be concentrating on tonight.

Many of us have been fascinated by the copiously filled bookcases behind the interviewees that we’ve seen during lockdown so we thought we’d ask you to bring a book along and introduce it to us. If you haven’t got the actual book just the name and author are fine. Give us a brief description of what it is about and anything else you want to say about it - what it meant to you, or what the writing was like.

Then we will open it up to a brief discussion- has anyone else read it, what did they get out of it or did they not get on with it. Does it remind us of other books. Would we like to read it? We’ll keep the time for each book to about ten minutes and any extra time at the end for more discussion. Do bring your own snacks and drink.

Happy reading 📖! Irene

title: Ask the Author! Meet novelist Anita Frank
description:
Anita Frank is a Berkshire based author of historical fiction and we are delighted that she has agreed to come and talk to the group about both the writing and publishing process.

* To start off, Anita will give us a short reading from her latest novel.
* We'll then have a Q & A, where I'll put some questions to Anita about her writing process and her experience of getting published.
* Then it's your turn! You can ask Anita any questions that I've forgotten to ask.

Anita's debut novel, The Lost Ones, is a Gothic mystery set during the First World War: [https://uk.bookshop.org/a/3002/9780008341237](https://uk.bookshop.org/a/3002/9780008341237)

For her second book, The Return, Anita brings us a tale of love and secrets from the Second World War: [https://uk.bookshop.org/a/3002/9780008341282](https://uk.bookshop.org/a/3002/9780008341282)

\*\*Special offer: Alex from Fourbears is giving Caversham Writers members a 15% discount on Anita's books on the night.

title: Writeshare Night - Read Your Work To The Group (online event)
description:
In this event members have the opportunity to read out their work to the rest of the group and get some instant feedback.

What to expect: We shall take turns to introduce and read out our writing (10 minutes maximum) and then have a short while for some helpful responses and encouragement. Anyone that doesn't get a turn this time we will prioritize for the next one.

What do I read to the group? Anything you have written - a work in progress; a first draft; a finished piece. Anything that you'd like to share and get some immediate responses to.

Do I submit my work in advance? No, the object of the exercise is to get an immediate first impression response from members after you read the piece out.

The aim is to encourage our writing by having this space to share it and getting some spontaneous responses. We ask as always that this should be constructive and positive. It will be great to hear what we’re all working on.

Please note this will not be the same as our more formal feedback sessions where we submit a more substantial piece (up to 3000 words) in advance, giving everyone a chance to study it properly and give considered and detailed feedback.

title: Prompt-Write Night (online event)
description:
Join us for this writing session where we set a prompt or theme for members to follow and discuss afterwards - you don't have to be in Caversham, or even the UK, to join us online. In these online writing events we follow the format of our regular writing meetups (see below).

To do so, I will end the Zoom component of the meeting after 20 to 30 minutes so that we can all write for an hour without the feeling of being spied upon through our webcams! I will then restart the Zoom meeting and you will be able to re-join using the same link.

What to expect: We'll start off the meeting with introductions and a bit of a chat (which usually runs to about 30 minutes). I will then introduce a writing prompt for us all to follow, a jumping off point to act as a guide for the writing session. What you do with it, where you go with it, is entirely up to you! We'll write for about an hour, after which we can talk about where our writing took us and maybe share some of what we produced.

No pressure, though - only share whatever you feel comfortable with. (We do have a more formal feedback meeting that you can submit pieces to for review - check our upcoming events for more details.)

title: Writes & Bites - an in person social event!
description:
A new venue for us, as requested by several members! This is our regular social event for members to meet and chat over a meal at a local Caversham/Reading restaurant. We'll typically talk about all things writing, so feel free to raise any questions you might have about your own, or each other's, writing projects.

There is no agenda for this meeting - no laptops, pens or paper required. It is just a chance for us to get to know each other a little better, to meet new members, or to get reacquainted with those we haven't seen in a while.
Members are responsible for their own food and drink.

title: Get to know each other & critiquing meetup
description: For the first meetup of Greenwich Writer's Group, we will meet at Gypsy Moth pub, which is by Cutty Sark tube station. Meet-ups are friendly and welcoming and each person is encouraged to bring along an extract of their work to receive constructive feedback. Each person is also encouraged to bring along a suggestion about a writing competition, opportunity or useful tip to share with the rest of the group.

title: Critiquing meetup
description:
After a great first meet up, it seems like a critiquing meetup at The Spanish Galleon would be a good idea (a quieter venue than the Gypsy Moth!). - If you would like your work to be emailed to attending members in advance for a more indepth critique, please email it to me zefstathiou@gmail.com and I will distribute it.
- If you'd prefer to just present your work to the group on the day, that's fine, but please bring copies. There will be a sign on the table stating Greenwich Writers.

title: Critiquing meetup
description: Please email an extract of your creative writing to zefstathiou@gmail.com by Friday 31st October so that I can distribute it to other members ahead of the meetup in order to give them a chance to reflect and come up with detailed feedback. We will then meet at The Spanish Galleon (opposite Cutty Sark) on Wednesday 5th November for a few drinks and to discuss each other's work and provide constructive feedback.

title: Critiquing meetup
description:
We are holding a friendly and constructive critiquing meetup on Tuesday 18th of November. Please send an extract of your writing (no more than around 2,500 words) to zefstathiou@gmail.com by Saturday the 14th and I will distribute it to everyone in the group to give us all a chance to reflect and come up with decent feedback.
We meet at The Spanish Galleon pub, opposite Cutty Sark station in Greenwich. We sit in the conservatory bit at the back. Note: The £5 charge goes towards covering the meetup organizer fees.

title: Critiquing meetup
description:
We are holding a friendly and constructive critiquing meetup on Wednesday the 3rd of December. Please send an extract of your writing (no more than around 2,500 words) to zefstathiou@gmail.com by Saturday the 29th and I will distribute it to everyone in the group to give us all a chance to reflect and come up with decent feedback.
We meet at The Spanish Galleon pub, opposite Cutty Sark station in Greenwich. We sit in the conservatory bit at the back. Note: The £5 charge goes towards covering the meetup organizer fees.

description: Please email an extract of your creative writing to zefstathiou@gmail.com by Sunday the 14th December so that I can distribute it to other members ahead of the meetup in order to give them a chance to reflect and come up with detailed feedback. We will then meet at The Spanish Galleon (opposite Cutty Sark) on Wednesday 17th for a few drinks and to discuss each other's work and provide constructive feedback.

title: Writing together meetup
description:
Rather than critiquing eachother's work, we will just meet in The Spanish Galleon, bring our laptops (or notepads if you're feeling retro) and write together.

We will gather in the conservatory-style area at the back of the pub.

title: Critiquing meetup
description: Please email an extract of your creative writing to zefstathiou@gmail.com by Sunday 4th Januaryso that I can distribute it to other members ahead of the meetup in order to give them a chance to reflect and come up with detailed feedback. We will then meet at The Spanish Galleon (opposite Cutty Sark) on Wednesday 7th January for a few drinks and to discuss eachother's work and provide constructive feedback.

title: Critiquing meetup
description: Please email an extract of your creative writing to zefstathiou@gmail.com by Sunday 18th January so that I can distribute it to other members ahead of the meetup in order to give them a chance to reflect and come up with detailed feedback. We will then meet at The Spanish Galleon (opposite Cutty Sark) on Wednesday 21th January for a few drinks and to discuss eachother's work and provide constructive feedback.

title: Writing together meetup
description:
Having held our first writing together meetup earlier in the month, it seems like it would be a good idea to hold these meetups regularly as we all managed to get some decent work done.

The idea is that we meet in the conservatory area at the back of The Spanish Galleon opposite Cutty Sark in Greenwich and bring our laptops or notebooks and just write together.

Note: As we're spending quite a while in the pub, they do like us to buy food. We don't have a proper group meal but if you fancy a sandwich or desert at some point during the writing session, then you can order one.

title: Synopsis critiquing meetup
description: Rather than critiquing sections of each other's novels, at this meetup, we will discuss the synopsis of our plots, to determine whether the pacing is effective, the action gripping, if the ending is satisfying, etc. Please send your synopsis to zefstathiou@gmail.com by Saturday the 31st Jan so that I can share it with the rest of the group ahead of the meetup.

title: Critquing meetup
description:
Please email an extract of your creative writing to zefstathiou@gmail.com by Sunday 8th February so that I can distribute it to other members ahead of the meetup in order to give them a chance to reflect and come up with detailed feedback. We will then meet at The Spanish Galleon (opposite Cutty Sark) on Wednesday 11th February for a few drinks and to discuss eachother's work and provide constructive feedback.

We'll critique the first six extracts that come through as there usually isn't time to critique any more than that.

title: Writing together meetup
description:
The idea is that we meet in the upstairs area of The Spanish Galleon opposite Cutty Sark in Greenwich and bring our laptops or notebooks and just write together. Writing can be a bit lonely, so this way we make it more sociable and also force ourselves to get on with it!

Note: As we're spending quite a while in the pub, they do like us to buy food. We don't have a proper group meal but if you fancy a sandwich or desert at some point during the writing session, then you can order one.

title: Critiquing meetup
description:
Please email an extract of your creative writing to zefstathiou@gmail.com by Sunday 22nd February so that I can distribute it to other members ahead of the meetup in order to give them a chance to reflect and come up with detailed feedback. We will then meet at The Spanish Galleon (opposite Cutty Sark) on Wednesday 25th February for a few drinks and to discuss eachother's work and provide constructive feedback.

We'll critique the first six extracts that come through as there usually isn't time to critique any more than that.

title: Writing together
description:
The idea is that we meet in the upstairs area of The Spanish Galleon opposite Cutty Sark in Greenwich and bring our laptops or notebooks and just write together. Writing can be a bit lonely, so this way we make it more sociable and also force ourselves to get on with it! We all just work on our own projects- no set writing exercises or anything.

Note: As we're spending quite a while in the pub, they do like us to buy food. We don't have a proper group meal but if you fancy a sandwich or desert at some point during the writing session, then you can order one.

title: Critiquing meet up
description:
The purpose of this meeting is to provide and receive critique on extracts of your creative writing, whether you're working on a novel, screenplay, poetry, a memoir or short story, etc. We share our extracts via email ahead of the meeting to give us all a chance to read the work in our own time and reflect upon it, to come up with valuable critique.

You will find us in the conservatory area at the back of the pub. Please email your extract (approx 3000 words or under) to zefstathiou@gmail.com by Sunday 8th February so that I can share your work with the rest of the group.

title: Write together
description:
The idea is that we meet up to write our own work in company.

We have changed the venue for our bi-weekly writing session. Spanish Galleon is pretty busy on Saturdays and can be fairly distracting so hopefully the Dial Arch with prove a better, more peaceful venue.

Just bring your laptop/notebook and enjoy a companionable afternoon with fellow authors.

The Dial Arch Pub is in Woolwich. here is the link http://www.dialarch.com/

title: Write together
description: The idea is that we meet up and write together - working on and focusing on our own projects but in convivial company.

title: Critiquing meetup
description:
The purpose of this meeting is to provide and receive critique on extracts of your creative writing, whether you're working on a novel, screenplay, poetry, a memoir or short story, etc. We share our extracts via email ahead of the meeting to give us all a chance to read the work in our own time and reflect upon it, to come up with valuable critique.

You will find us in alcove to the right of the entrance. Please email your extract (approx 3000 words or under) to zefstathiou@gmail.com by Saturday before the meetup so that I can share your work with the rest of the group. I'll share the first 4 extracts I receive.

When discussing each extract, we will go round the group, giving each person the opportunity to share their thoughts and feedback. This way we ensure that we stay focused, everyone has a chance to provide input, and the quality of critique is really thorough.

The group is friendly and relaxed, so please don't feel nervous about sharing your work if you are new!

description: We cannot book our normal table in the alcove as apparently there is a Rugby World Cup going on. Can the first person there try to grab a big table in the main pub room preferably next to a socket!

description: We cannot book our normal table in the alcove as apparently there is a Rugby World Cup going on. Can the first person there try to grab a big table in the main pub room preferably next to a socket!

title: Researching new venues
description: Our current venue for meetups, Dial Arch, is proving quite noisy with sports often being played loudly on TV so we're going to research new places to meet on Thursday night. There are a couple of new pubs opening in Woolwich Arsenal which we are going to check out to see if they are more suitable. Let's meet in front of the Dial Arch.

title: In person Critiquing session at The Equitable in Woolwich.
description:
This will be an in person critiquing session. We'll be back upstairs in The Equitable in Woolwich for this one.
https://woolwichequitable.com/

Based on our experience in our last in person session, we will only critique three extracts.

I will send out the extracts on the Sunday before the session to those who sign up.

The purpose of this meeting is to provide and receive critique on submitted extracts of members' creative writing, whether they're working on a novel, screenplay, poetry, a memoir or short story, etc. We share our extracts via email ahead of the meeting to give us all a chance to read the work in our own time and reflect upon it so as to be able to provide useful critique.

If you are new to the group we ask that you participate in at least two of the critiquing sessions before you submit work for review so that you get to know us and have a good understanding of how we operate. This will help you to get the most from a critique of your own work.

title: Bring your laptop, and work on your own material in convivial company
description:
This meetup is still free. You will be refunded if you attend. The £2 is simply to dissuade people from signing up and not attending.

The venue is the Snug in the Woolwich Equitable; turn left once you come into the pub and you should find us in the separate room there.

You don't have to bring a laptop. Use a pen and paper or clay tablet and stylus if that's what works for you.

title: Write for your Life - writing session
description:
In advance of Monday's session, please have a think about something that has inspired you or helped you (self-help or otherwise). A book, a saying, a film, a song. We'll share these and maybe use some of them as prompts during our writing session.

In Write for your Life writing sessions, we'll use prompts to explore things like motivation, dreams and hopes, procrastination and much more. Workshops will be active, fun and occasionally stop us in our tracks.

Writing can be insightful, and we might share things we write (always optional), but please note, this is not a therapy group and isn't suitable for replacement of individual/group therapeutic work.

group.name: Write for your Life - Creative Group Journaling

title: Write for your Life - writing session for self reflection
description:
*Spaces often come up at the last minute so feel free to ping me if you're feeling spontaneous!*

We use free writing and discussion to explore different topics and themes around how we live our lives. This combination of writing and sharing never fails to connect those taking part in the joys and challenges of being human. It can also be a lot of fun and a great creative outlet.

Workshops are great for stress relief, personal reflection, uncovering different perspectives and sometimes surprising insights. It’s also a lovely way to celebrate your ‘you’-ness.

No writing talent, knowledge or experience - and definitely no grammar - is required.

The group will be limited to eight people, so please can I ask you to decline if you're no longer able to make it so someone else can attend. Many thanks!

Writing can be insightful, and we might share things we write (always optional), but please note, this is not a therapy group and isn't suitable for replacement of individual/group therapeutic work.

About me
I'm passionate about sharing life writing and encouraging people to help (and be OK with) themselves using this powerful tool. I am a coach and facilitator and use writing to help uncover sometimes surprising, but always useful perspectives and insights.

More info at: cpsdayoff.com

group.name: Write for your Life - Creative Group Journaling

title: Write for your Life Coaching Group
description:
A weekly coaching group to step off the merry-go-round and take a look at where you are in life and look at things you might want to start, stop, change or accept. Each week we’ll use writing exercises (no experience required) and discussion to dig into the area you’d like to look at. What you focus on is entirely up to you: work, creative endeavours, interests, purpose, relationships, finance, anything really. This doesn’t have to be about hard goals and knowing exactly what you want. group.name: Write for your Life - Creative Group Journaling

title: New Year Workshop - Create your theme for the year
description:
Spaces still available if you're free last minute...

To book - please follow the link and sign up directly on Eventbright: https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/write-for-your-life-new-year-workshop-create-your-theme-for-the-year-tickets-52863815094

This is a fun workshop where we’ll use guided writing exercises including free writing (no experience required) and discussion to reflect back and look forward, helping us to set our intention for the year ahead.

This workshop isn’t about creating resolutions or goals, though these do have their place. It’s more about capturing a feeling or a tone that can guide our decisions and help us feel that, whilst we might not always be behind the wheel, we’re at least in the front of the car. I've been using annual themes for nearly 10 years now and I can say that they have really helped me.

Free writing is a great tool for uncovering new insights and perspectives and a lovely way to celebrate your ‘you-ness’. No writing talent, knowledge or experience – and definitely no grammar – is required.

Details
Date: 12 January 2019
Time: 1-4pm
Cost is £25.00 (includes tea, coffe and biscuits)
Venue: Vauxhall Gardens Community Centre is less than a five minute walk from the tube/train/bus station.

There will be a maximum of 12 people at the workshop but as tickets are being booked through Eventbrite, I'll update the number of available slots as I go along, so the number here to sign up will change. I hope that makes sense.

group.name: Write for your Life - Creative Group Journaling

title: Write for your Life - writing session for self reflection
description:
**Write for your Life - writing session for self reflection' week day workshops are free of charge in January. Cost will be £5 from February 2019**

We use free writing and discussion to explore different topics and themes around how we live our lives. This combination of writing and sharing never fails to connect those taking part in the joys and challenges of being human. It can also be a lot of fun and a great creative outlet.

Workshops are great for stress relief, confidence, and uncovering different perspectives and sometimes surprising insights. It’s also a lovely way to celebrate your ‘you’-ness and realise that you're never alone when you have a pen in your hand.

No writing talent, knowledge or experience - and definitely no grammar - is required.

For more information and upcoming workshops, please go to cpsdayoff.com.

The group will be limited to eight people, so please can I ask you to decline if you're no longer able to make it so someone else can attend. Many thanks!

Writing can be insightful, and we might share things we write (always optional), but please note, this is not a therapy group and isn't suitable for replacement of individual/group therapeutic work.

About me
I'm passionate about sharing life writing techniques including free writing, encouraging people to help (and be OK with) themselves and know that we’re never alone if we have a pen in our hand. I am a coach and facilitator and use writing to help uncover sometimes surprising, but always useful perspectives and insights.

More info at: cpsdayoff.com

Write for your Life - writing session for self reflection

About me

group.name: Write for your Life - Creative Group Journaling

title: Coaching Group for ANYONE who wants to write ANYTHING
description:
This session we'll be taking a look at 'Why?' Why we write, why we don't write and what we might do about it. There will be time to share what we're working on as well as a little time to do some writing after the session, if you'd like.

"Write Anyway"

Does this sound familiar? "I’m not a writer because":
• I haven’t written a book
• I don’t have a ‘process’/I have no discipline
• I've got nothing new to say
• I didn’t always know I wanted to be a writer
• I don’t write every day
• I’m rubbish at grammar
• Who do I think I am? I’m not good enough
• I’m not a creative person/I’m not allowed to be creative
• I can’t be a writer because I’m a *insert day job title here*
• People will mock/criticise/*insert your favourite insult here*

This coaching group is for ANYONE who wants to write ANYTHING. It’s about building confidence and finding out what's in the way of you writing/continuing to write and sharing your writing with others, if that’s what you want. It’s not about literary appraisal, writing technique or grammar.

A book, a letter, a blog, a journal, a sit com, a self-help book or a poem, whatever it is you want to write, I’ll help you to look at what's in the way and empower and encourage you to get/continue writing, and build the confidence to keep writing.

We’ll use free writing, discussion and a healthy dose of encouragement to explore different topics and themes around writing and creativity. We'll look at what your blocks are and come up with ways to move forward. There will be time at the end to continue your own writing if you'd like.

It doesn’t matter whether you’re standing at the station waiting for your writing journey to start, or are well into it with a packed lunch and a comfy seat. We can all benefit from a bit of encouragement and taking the time to invest in ourselves and our creativity.

"You will doubt yourself for not being good enough and have nothing new to say, Write anyway." (inspired by the Paradoxical Commandments)

Coaching Meetups will be £5 for a limited period. If you are unable to pay the fee, do drop me a line and we can sort something out.

About me
I’m a Life Coach and Facilitator, passionate about free writing, whether for self-reflection or to encourage writing itself.

I’ve been free writing for over five years and run regular workshops and coaching groups in London, for writing and for life.

I currently write Dear Lucy. Letters from one friend to another about every day life.

More info at: cpsdayoff.com

group.name: Write for your Life - Creative Group Journaling

title: Is Life Coaching for me? - Free/no obligation session
description: If you've ever thought about hiring a Life Coach, or want to find out what Life Coaching could do for you, come along and have your questions answered. Absolutely no obligation (this is not a sales pitch, it comes from a genuine desire for me to help people understand what help might be available for them). As well as answering your questions, there will be time to explore a little what you might like help with. I'll talk a little about the difference between coaching, mentoring, psychotherapy and counselling, how coaching normally works (length of session/duration/fees), and how to go about finding a coach. Feel free to come along or ask me any questions at cpsdayoff@gmail.com.

"You will doubt yourself for not being good enough and have nothing new to say, Write anyway." (inspired by the Paradoxical Commandments)

Coaching Meetups will be £5 for a limited period. If it's difficult for you to pay for any reason, do drop me a line and we can sort something out.

About me
I’m a Life Coach and Facilitator, passionate about free writing, whether for self-reflection or to encourage writing itself.

I’ve been free writing and coaching for over five years and run regular workshops and coaching groups in London, for writing and for life.

I currently write Dear Lucy. Letters from one friend to another about every day life and the Accidental Sabbatical.

More info at: cpsdayoff.com

group.name: Write for your Life - Creative Group Journaling

title: Write for your Life - writing session for self reflection
description:
Come along for fun writing exercises and discussion, for self-reflection and creativity.

Write for your Life - writing session for self reflection

We use free writing and discussion to explore different topics and themes around how we live our lives. This combination of writing and sharing never fails to connect those taking part in the joys and challenges of being human. It can also be a lot of fun and a great creative outlet.

Workshops are great for stress relief, confidence, and uncovering different perspectives and sometimes surprising insights. It’s also a lovely way to celebrate your ‘you’-ness and realise that you're never alone when you have a pen in your hand.

No writing talent, knowledge or experience - and definitely no grammar - is required.

For more information and upcoming workshops, please go to cpsdayoff.com.

Writing can be insightful, and we might share things we write (always optional), but please note, this is not a therapy group and isn't suitable for replacement of individual/group therapeutic work.

If you are unable to pay the fee, do drop me a line and we can sort something out.

I’ve been free writing for over five years and run regular workshops and coaching groups in London, for writing and for life.

I currently write Dear Lucy. Letters from one friend to another about every day life.

group.name: Write for your Life - Creative Group Journaling

title: Introduction to Creative Group Journaling/Life-writing
description:
Register in advance for this meeting:
https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZYtcO2rpjIuHNCYiLtIJ43Iroop2O48tmzy

After registering, you will receive a confirmation email containing information about joining the meeting.

Come along and experience the joy and value of writing and sharing with others at this free taster session. Journaling is incredibly useful and has many, many benefits. Journaling with others takes things to another level. As well as the accountability of writing with other people, we tend to write differently; often more, than we would on our own. Sharing is at the core of this session (in pairs). It doesn't have to be what you wrote word for word, it could just be how the exercise was for you and anything noteworthy you'd like to share. The writing prompts will help you to surface new insights and ideas, giving you clues as to what needs to happen in your life to get you where you want to be, or just to make it more enjoyable. Best of all, no writing talent, knowledge or experience - and definitely no grammar - is required.

This session will:

* A chance to 'try before you buy' (my other workshops)
* Give you some time, just for you
* Give you the opportunity to do some writing (from prompts)
* Give you some headspace, perspective and insight
* Connect you to yourself and others.
* Give you a lovely shared experience with like minded souls

It’s creative, supportive and fun, so why not come along and give it a go. You'll leave with some insights, some headspace and satisfaction of an hour well spent, in good company.

PLEASE NOTE you'll need to register via the Zoom link - this is for security purposes. Thank you.

These session are free, but if you'd like to buy me a coffee (or a Ko-fi!) click here: https://ko-fi.com/cpsdayoff thanks!

I've been running writing workshops and coaching for over three years and run regular sessions giving people the opportunity to write, grow and have fun together. If you'd like to chat about anything I offer, feel free to book in some time to chat: https://calendly.com/cpsdayoff/time-with-cp?

You can find more info at https://www.cpsdayoff.com/

group.name: Write for your Life - Creative Group Journaling

title: Journal/Write together - space to work on your own projects
description:
Give yourself some time and space to do some writing (anything - any level). There will be a little time to share what we're each working on and time to ask for help if needed but the main purpose of this session is to actually do some writing.

Register in advance for this meeting:
https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZ0odeyrqDguHtFs5GDYkSqxh8MUzAOUI1in
After registering, you will receive a confirmation email containing information about joining the meeting.

Just being with other people (in whatever format!) can really help to get your pen underway. Anyone, any level, writing anything is absolutely welcome. It might be blurb for your website, a novel, a blog, a book for your child, a poem, anything.

These sessions will always be free, but if you'd like to buy me a coffee (or a Ko-fi!) click here: https://ko-fi.com/cpsdayoff
thanks!

thanks!

Hope to see you there!

group.name: Write for your Life - Creative Group Journaling

title: Write for your Life - Creative Group Journaling
description:
It’s like journaling, but with other people! Trust me, it’s fun, energising, inspiring, supportive, rewarding and creative too.​

Journaling with others takes things to another level. As well as the accountability of writing with other people, we tend to write differently; often more, than we would on our own.

We use free-writing prompts to get writing. It could be a new season, a painting or National Penguin Day that we take for our inspiration in this session. It’s all just a place to start and then explore what comes through in our writing, whether that's creative, straight journaling or a combination of both.

Writing and sharing (always optional) never fails to connect those taking part in the joys and challenges of being human. It can also be a lot of fun and a great creative outlet.

Best of all, no writing talent, knowledge or experience - and definitely no grammar - is required.

Sessions are great for stress relief, building confidence, and uncovering different perspectives and sometimes surprising insights. It’s also a lovely way to celebrate your ‘you’-ness and realise that you're never alone when you have a pen in your hand.​

This session will:

* Give you some lovely 'you time' to connect with yourself, and others
* Get you writing - journaling/creative/both
* Give you headspace, perspective and insight
* Give you a lovely shared experience with like- minded souls

I've been running writing workshops and coaching since 2018 and run regular sessions giving people the opportunity to write, grow and have fun together. If you'd like to chat about anything I offer, feel free to book in some time to chat: https://calendly.com/cpsdayoff/time-with-cp?

You can find more info at https://www.cpsdayoff.com/

group.name: Write for your Life - Creative Group Journaling

title: Permission to be creative!
description:
Think you’re not creative? I’m here to tell you that you are, regardless of your job title. In this short talk, aimed at building your creative confidence, I’ll remind you how you're creative, every day - at work and at home - when it comes to ideas and solutions. I'll talk about what it means to have a creative mindset and why it’s important.

You’ll leave with permission to be creative, the courage to solve problems and take on opportunities and hopefully, the confidence to begin your own creative projects.

Register in advance for this meeting:
https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZctdOCsqz0pGtLGv9YdeyWh3hTeinYc9iQS
After registering, you will receive a confirmation email containing information about joining the meeting.

I've been running creative writing and journaling workshops/coaching since 2018 and run regular sessions giving people the opportunity to write, grow and have fun together. If you'd like to chat about anything I offer, feel free to book in some time to chat: https://calendly.com/cpsdayoff/time-with-cp?

To find out more about how I enable and encourage people to be creative, go to https://www.cpsdayoff.com/

Also takes place on the following dates:
Thursday, 8 September, 12.30 - 1pm

group.name: Write for your Life - Creative Group Journaling

title: Coach yourself with a Pen - at work and at home
description:
**Takes place on 21 and 28 September. Both dates run** **from 6.30 to 8pm.**
Early bird £39 until 25 July 2022. Normal price £49.

**Coach yourself with a Pen - at work and at home**
Using techniques from creative writing, journaling, and coaching, you'll connect to yourself more deeply and work through your own live example. You'll leave feeling inspired and energised with some clear next steps and a set of new tools.

You may just have some fun too whilst tapping into your creativity, which will build your creative confidence. Everyone is creative when it comes to ideas and solutions and these tools will empower you to make the most of bigger opportunities and goals you'd like to achieve.

Bringing out your creativity is not only good for your wellbeing and your career (it's one of the most important skills companies need according to LinkedIn and other studies), but it can also give you meaning, help you to solve problems, be more curious about the world around you and ultimately, have a more enjoyable life and feel more confident.

The tools I'll introduce you to are easy to use, accessible 24/7, playful, creative and great for creating headspace, surfacing new perspectives and facing fear and anxiety to help you get what you want in your life. No experience, interest and definitely no grammar are required.

These tools are also great for divergent thinking and are really well suited for Design Thinking and Agile ways of working, whether for innovation or reaching goals. They can work with small or large challenges or goals and are suitable for all levels.

**Session one, 21 September**, will be about getting to the bottom of what's happening and what it is you want to achieve/overcome.
**Session two, 28 September**, will be all about looking forward to what you want and where you want to be.

Zoom details are revealed once you book.

I've been running writing workshops and coaching since 2018 and run regular sessions giving people the opportunity to write, grow and have fun together. If you'd like to chat about anything I offer, feel free to book in some time to chat: https://calendly.com/cpsdayoff/time-with-cp?
You can find more info at https://www.cpsdayoff.com/

*You're never alone with a pen.*

*Photo by Fabio Comparelli on Unsplash*

Sharing is at the core of this session (in pairs). It doesn't have to be what you wrote word for word, it could just be how the exercise was for you and anything noteworthy you'd like to share. The writing prompts will help you to surface new insights and ideas, giving you clues as to what needs to happen in your life to get you where you want to be, or just to make it more enjoyable. Best of all, no writing talent, knowledge or experience - and definitely no grammar - is required.

This session will:

* A chance to 'try before you buy' (my other workshops)
* Give you some time, just for you
* Give you the opportunity to do some writing (from prompts)
* Give you some headspace, perspective and insight
* Connect you to yourself and others.
* Give you a lovely shared experience with like minded souls

It’s creative, supportive and fun, so why not come along and give it a go. You'll leave with some insights, some headspace and satisfaction of an hour well spent, in good company.

group.name: Write for your Life - Creative Group Journaling

title: <<ONLY £12 PER SESSION>> POD 1 .  5-Week BEGINNERS' Course + PUBLICATION
description:
The full price for this course is £60. That's equivalent to £12 for each two-hour session (+ at the end of the 5 weeks, you will have the opportunity to publish your work and receive ongoing feedback on The New Machine's website, for FREE).

...

Pod No. 1 (beginners) 5-week short story course

[There will only be 6 places in a Pod. Regular creative writing classes consist of between 10 – 15 people. A 6-person pod ensures you will each receive closer attention to the details of your work. You will never have to read your work in front of the group – it will merely be discussed by the group in a friendly, constructive manner (a manner consistent with a blueprint for critique that I will set out in week 3). Each session will last for approx. 2 hours + there will be a very short piece of homework, designed to ensure that you’re progressing nicely throughout the course. By the end of the 5th week you will have produced a final edit of a short story you’ve been working on and have the opportunity to publish it on the New Machine’s website]

Week 1 - Point of view

We will be looking here at the relationship between the reader and the narrator. You will learn what it means to write in the 1st, 2nd and 3rd person (+ variations). I will introduce you to some the textual nuances that authors deploy within these narrative modes. You’ll then have an opportunity to explore this yourself, in writing.

In this session we will be looking at excerpts from: Brett Easton Ellis, Chimamanda Ngoze Adichie, Elizabeth Gaskell and JM Coetzee.

Week 2 - Style/tone and dialogue

In the second week, we will examine three different narrative styles. You will have an opportunity to emulate these in a writing exercise. We will then discuss dialogue and explore this using a free writing technique. In this session we will be looking at excerpts from: Charles Dickens, Katherine Mansfield and Albert Camus.

Week 3 – Character development and plot

This session will help you generate ideas for characters and plot. You will be begin to see your own short story emerging.

The homework will be to write a 2000-word short story based on everything you’ve learned so far.

Week 4 - How to critique

We will look at a short story here together and learn how to critique it in terms of its themes, its character development(s), its style/type of narration, its plot and structure, its dialogue, etc. You will learn to distinguish what you think is effective and what needs work in other peoples’ writing (this will in turn inform your own writing and allow you to proceed with more clarity).

Week 5 - Feedback

Here you will receive a compassionate critique of your work, and will partake in a discussion of other peoples’ work (+ you will have an opportunity to take your story away with you, produce a final edit, and publish it on The New Machine’s website).

title: ONLY £10 - CREATIVE IDEAS MACHINE (2 HOURS)
description:
Hi there,

If you're free this Saturday (29th July) please sign up and come along to the first of many stand-alone writing workshops in Waterloo. The workshop will be very small, so please book your space quickly if you'd like to attend.

Together we'll be generating:

1. Ideas for dialogue
2. Ideas for plot
3. Ideas for style

This is a class for beginners through to intermediate level writers. *Note: this is NOT a course, just a 2-hour session this Saturday.

Please feel free to txt me on 07534 981 636 if you have any concerns at all - I'd love to hear from you.

All the best,

Sean

We will be looking here at the relationship between the reader and the narrator. You will learn what it means to write in the 1st, 2nd and 3rd person (+ variations). I will introduce you to some the textual nuances that authors deploy within these narrative modes. You’ll then have an opportunity to explore this yourself, in writing.

In this session we will be looking at excerpts from: Brett Easton Ellis, Chimamanda Ngoze Adichie, Elizabeth Gaskell and JM Coetzee.

Week 2 - Style/tone and dialogue

In the second week, we will examine three different narrative styles. You will have an opportunity to emulate these in a writing exercise. We will then discuss dialogue and explore this using a free writing technique. In this session we will be looking at excerpts from: Charles Dickens, Katherine Mansfield and Albert Camus.

Week 3 – Character development and plot

This session will help you generate ideas for characters and plot. You will be begin to see your own short story emerging.

The homework will be to write a 2000-word short story based on everything you’ve learned so far.

Week 4 - How to critique

We will look at a short story here together and learn how to critique it in terms of its themes, its character development(s), its style/type of narration, its plot and structure, its dialogue, etc. You will learn to distinguish what you think is effective and what needs work in other peoples’ writing (this will in turn inform your own writing and allow you to proceed with more clarity).

Week 5 - Feedback

Here you will receive a compassionate critique of your work, and will partake in a discussion of other peoples’ work (+ you will have an opportunity to take your story away with you, produce a final edit, and publish it on The New Machine’s website).

title: POD-101: THE ADVANCED COURSE
description:
The full price for this course is £60. That's equivalent to £12 for each two-hour session (+ you will have multiple opportunities to receive feedback on your work. At the end of the 5 weeks, you will also have the opportunity to PUBLISH PART OF YOUR WORK and receive ongoing feedback on The New Machine's website, for FREE).

POD-101: “THE ADVANCED COURSE”

The aim of this course is for you to plan and write a novel.

Week 1. (Planning your novel)

In the first week, you’ll be generating an idea for your novel. You will then flesh-out/develop this idea using a narrative arc. This arc will ensure that you’re able to produce a compelling and dynamic story for whomever your readership is intended to be. You can take the arc home, develop and/or discard it, depending on your personal preference. Either way, the arc is an essential aspect of good storytelling, and the strategy you receive here will benefit your writing immensely.

Week 2. (Narrative Perspective + Chapters 1 & 2)

In the second week, you’ll be invited to plan your first two chapters, in greater depth. You will also partake in a creative writing exercise that will help you decide which narrative perspective (and which tense) to write your novel in.

Week 3. (Dialogue + Chapters 3, 4 & 5)

In the third week, you’ll be invited to plan and/or write your next three chapters. You will also partake in a creative writing exercise that will ensure you’re using dialogue effectively in your work.

Week 4. (Feedback + Chapters 6, 7 & 8)

In the fourth week, you will receive feedback for up to 3000 words of the writing you have done so far. You will also be invited to plan and/or write your next three chapters.

Week 5. (Feedback + Chapters 9 & 10 + Re-visiting the arc)

In the final week, you will plan and/or write your 9th & 10th chapter. You will also re-visit the narrative arc you made for your work at the beginning of the course. This will enable you to consolidate a final first draft or plan for your entire novel.

***Note: your novel may not be precisely 10 chapters. This is, of course, entirely up to you. POD-101/THE ADVANCED COURSE is here to provide you a 5-week structure within which to complete as much of your novel as possible. If you’re extremely motivated, you may finish an entire first draft. Most people, however, will produce an entire plan/outline + only *some* of their first draft. Either way, POD-101 will be running on a rolling basis. So you will have the opportunity to RSVP again for the next 5-weeks, and continue working on your novel. To avoid the workshop becoming stale and un-productive, participants should not sign up for more than two consecutive POD-101’s.

If you would like to do this course, but you have some questions, please contact the organiser first, by texting 07534 981 636.

title: Day of Writing (Exclusively for People on a Course with TNM)
description:
Hi guys,

This is an event for those of you who are currently on a course with The New Machine (Creative Writing). It is not compulsory. It's just an opportunity for you to meet up with the rest of the group and make sure you get some writing done.

I won't be teaching anything here; there won't be any exercises. Just a block of 3 hours for us to sit together in a quiet café and get some work done towards our short stories and novels.

If you do decide to come, please come prepared to write. I will be giving us a timed 45 minute window, followed by a 15 minute break, to ensure progress. You can chat to each other during the breaks, but it would be great to stick to writing for the time allotted to it, so that we don't distract each other.

I hope to see lots of you there!

All the best,

Sean

title: POD-1: WRITE + PUBLISH YOUR FICTION IN 5 WEEKS!!!  <<£10 DISCOUNT>>
description:
£10 DISCOUNT!!!

The full price for this course is usually £60. That's equivalent to £12 (but only £10, this time) for each two-hour session (+ you will have multiple opportunities to receive feedback on your work and, at the end of the 5 weeks, you will also have the opportunity to PUBLISH YOUR WORK and receive ongoing feedback on The New Machine's website, for FREE).

If you would like to do this course online, it's ONLY £40!!! But please contact the organiser first, by texting 07534 981 636.

**********

THIS COURSE WILL HAVE A BREAK OVER XMAS. SO THE DATES OF THE SESSIONS WILL BE: 7th Dec, 14th Dec, 21st Dec---BREAK---4th Jan, 11th Jan.

**********

...

Pod No. 1 (beginners/intermediate) 5-week short story course

[There will only be 6 places in a Pod. Regular creative writing classes consist of between 10 – 15 people. A 6-person pod ensures you will each receive closer attention to the details of your work. Each session will last for approx. 2 hours + there will be a very short piece of homework, designed to ensure that you’re progressing nicely throughout the course. By the end of the 5th week you will have produced a final edit of a short story you’ve been working on and have the opportunity to publish it on the New Machine’s website]

Week 1 - Point of view

We will be looking here at the relationship between the reader and the narrator. You will learn what it means to write in the 1st, 2nd and 3rd person (+ variations). I will introduce you to some the textual nuances that authors deploy within these narrative modes. You’ll then have an opportunity to explore this yourself, in writing.

In this session we will be looking at excerpts from: Brett Easton Ellis, Chimamanda Ngoze Adichie, Elizabeth Gaskell and JM Coetzee.

Week 2 - Style/tone and dialogue

In the second week, we will examine three different narrative styles. You will have an opportunity to emulate these in a writing exercise. We will then discuss dialogue and explore this using a free writing technique. In this session we will be looking at excerpts from: Charles Dickens, Katherine Mansfield and Albert Camus.

Week 3 – Character development and plot

This session will help you generate ideas for characters and plot. You will be begin to see your own short story emerging.

The homework will be to write a 2000-word short story based on everything you’ve learned so far.

Week 4 - How to critique

We will look at a short story here together and learn how to critique it in terms of its themes, its character development(s), its style/type of narration, its plot and structure, its dialogue, etc. You will learn to distinguish what you think is effective and what needs work in other peoples’ writing (this will in turn inform your own writing and allow you to proceed with more clarity).

Week 5 - Feedback

Here you will receive a compassionate critique of your work, and will partake in a discussion of other peoples’ work (+ you will have an opportunity to take your story away with you, produce a final edit, and publish it on The New Machine’s website).

title: POD-101: WRITE A NOVEL IN 5-WEEKS!
description:
The full price for this course is £60. That's equivalent to £12 for each two-hour session (+ you will have multiple opportunities to receive feedback on your work. At the end of the 5 weeks, you will also have the opportunity to PUBLISH PART OF YOUR WORK and receive ongoing feedback on The New Machine's website, for FREE).

POD-101: “THE ADVANCED COURSE”

The aim of this course is for you to plan and write a novel.

Week 1. (Planning your novel)

In the first week, you’ll be generating an idea for your novel. You will then flesh-out/develop this idea using a narrative arc. This arc will ensure that you’re able to produce a compelling and dynamic story for whomever your readership is intended to be. You can take the arc home, develop and/or discard it, depending on your personal preference. Either way, the arc is an essential aspect of good storytelling, and the strategy you receive here will benefit your writing immensely.

Week 2. (Narrative Perspective + Chapters 1 & 2)

In the second week, you’ll be invited to plan your first two chapters, in greater depth. You will also partake in a creative writing exercise that will help you decide which narrative perspective (and which tense) to write your novel in.

Week 3. (Dialogue + Chapters 3, 4 & 5)

In the third week, you’ll be invited to plan and/or write your next three chapters. You will also partake in a creative writing exercise that will ensure you’re using dialogue effectively in your work.

Week 4. (Feedback + Chapters 6, 7 & 8)

In the fourth week, you will receive feedback for up to 3000 words of the writing you have done so far. You will also be invited to plan and/or write your next three chapters.

Week 5. (Feedback + Chapters 9 & 10 + Re-visiting the arc)

In the final week, you will plan and/or write your 9th & 10th chapter. You will also re-visit the narrative arc you made for your work at the beginning of the course. This will enable you to consolidate a final first draft or plan for your entire novel.

***Note: your novel may not be precisely 10 chapters. This is, of course, entirely up to you. POD-101/THE ADVANCED COURSE is here to provide you a 5-week structure within which to complete as much of your novel as possible. If you’re extremely motivated, you may finish an entire first draft. Most people, however, will produce an entire plan/outline + only *some* of their first draft. Either way, POD-101 will be running on a rolling basis. So you will have the opportunity to RSVP again for the next 5-weeks, and continue working on your novel. To avoid the workshop becoming stale and un-productive, participants should not sign up for more than two consecutive POD-101’s.

If you would like to do this course, but you have some questions, please contact the organiser first, by texting 07534 981 636.

description:
Hi guys,

This is an event for those of you who are currently on a course with The New Machine (Creative Writing). It is not compulsory. It's just an opportunity for you to meet up with the rest of the group and make sure you get some writing done.

I won't be teaching anything here; there won't be any exercises. Just a block of 3 hours for us to sit together in a quiet café and get some work done towards our short stories and novels.

I hope to see lots of you there!

All the best,

Sean

P.S. as there will be other people around, you may wish to bring earphones, to cut out the background noise.
