title: DAY OF POETRY (beginners and intermediate level) ***SPECIAL PRICE - £15***
description:
[The Day of Poetry is normally £20. This time it is £15 for the 4 hour session, so that's only £3.75 per hour!!!]

********************************************************************************************

Hi there,

If you're a poet (or if you'd like to be!) please RSVP and come along to The New Machine's "DAY OF POETRY".

If you're a complete beginner, no problem. Throughout the 4-hour session, we'll be learning the poetry basics, from scratch. Things like:

• Line breaks

• Stanza formation

• Rhythm

• Free verse

We will be looking at poetry by Samuel Beckett, Sharon Olds, Margaret Atwood, Frank O'Hara, Langston Hughes, Matsuo Basho, and William Shakespeare.

By the end of the day, you'll have a small handful of your own poems, either complete or to take home and work on.

If you're an intermediate level poet, this workshop will also be enormously beneficial to you. We'll be generating ideas together and you'll have the fixed structure of the day to compel your progress!

Any questions, don't hesitate to ask (either reply here or text Sean on: 07534 981 636).

Hope to see you soon! :)

title: Novel Beginnings - How to Start Your Story + food, drink, and a FREE book!
description:
[BOOK YOUR SPOT AT www.writeandpint.com/workshops]

...

***"It’s such a confidence trick, writing a novel. The main person you have to trick into confidence is yourself. This is hard to do alone". – Zadie Smith***

...

Let's get together and learn how to write the perfect beginning.

Whether you've already written your novel/short story or you're starting something afresh, this is the perfect workshop to hone your style, tone, tempo, and general approach.

We'll be looking at everybody from Zadie Smith to John Cheever, Francois Sagan to Katherine Mansfield, Chimamanda Ngoze Adichie to Jorge Luis Borges.

We'll be looking at what agents and publishers might want from the opening chapter.

We'll be setting you up with some fun, exciting writing exercises, to make sure you get the chance to finesse your approach and leave with something new and brilliant, ready to take home and edit.

First of all though, we'll be ordering teas, coffees and brunch, before we settle in for a warm-up exercise, to get our imaginations flowing.

No experience of writing is necessary for this workshop.

No pressure to read or share your work with the group.

Just sit back, listen, learn, read, write, eat, drink, and come away full of new knowledge and expertise in the art of writing.

***"The scariest moment is always just before you start". – Stephen King***

So please feel free to text us on 07534 981 636 if you have any questions at all - we'll be more happy to help :)

title: Business Book Writing
description:

Anything and everything about writing your business book, and an opportunity to meet other business authors.

title: In-person Writers' Meet-up
description:
This meet-up is for writers in Bromley, whether you are published, working on a project, or just getting started.

It is open to people living in the town of Bromley and nearby surroundings.

The group is for anyone who enjoys writing: all are welcome. Similarly, any kind of writer can join. Poetry, fiction, non-fiction, memoir, academic...

At the meeting you can:

\- discuss your journey as a writer
\- swap and critique work
\- find accountability buddies and critical friends
\- simply get some writing done\!

If you're interested in being a host and helping run this group, please send me a message! :)

title: Writing Children’s Fiction
description:
Sutton Writers are very pleased to have children’s book author and children’s book editor Lil Chase join us. Her books regularly receive 5-star reviews on Amazon and include "Boys for Beginners", "Secrets, Lies and Locker 62" as well as "The Boys' School Girls" series. Visit her online at: http://www.lilchase.com .

**********

The full annual membership fee is currently £26 and is due in September of each year.

This covers admission to each monthly meeting, in-house competitions, attendance at workshops and a monthly newsletter. This represents very good value particularly for those who participate in the free workshops where they can benefit from the knowledge and expertise of other writers.

You can pay to become a member at the first main meeting you attend but if you want to check us out first, occasional visitors pay £4.00 on the door.

The country/online membership fee is currently £13. This entitles you to attend two meetings per year and to enter all competitions.

title: Social Media for Writers
description:
Do you use social media? Ever wondered what’s in it for you as a writer? In this session, Sutton Writers’ members Kirsteen & Kat are going to discuss the various forms of social media that are useful for writers and tips for using them effectively to help you progress as a writer. We’ll also talk about blogs: what’s the point of them, how to make one and how to use it.

**********

The full annual membership fee is currently £26 and is due in September of each year.

The country/online membership fee is currently £13. This entitles you to attend two meetings per year and to enter all competitions.

title: Finding a Literary Agent and a Publishing House
description:
Sutton Writers are very pleased to welcome back Fiona Harper, award winning romance novelist, for her second visit this year. Fiona will be talking about the process of finding an agent and a publisher - some of the pitfalls and advice from someone who has been through it firstly as an unpublished writer, and then again once published.

Fiona's first book was published in 2006 and she now has twenty-four published books under her belt. She started her career writing heartfelt but humorous romances for Mills & Boon, but now writes romantic comedies and feel-good women’s fiction for Harper Collins, as part of their HQ imprint. She is a previous winner of the Joan Hessayon New Writers’ Scheme Award, has had five books shortlisted for a RoNA Award and won the ‘Best Short Romance’ at the Festival of Romance three years’ running! Visit her online at: http://www.fionaharper.com/home .

**********

You can attend your first meeting free of charge.

title: Winter Quiz and Prose and Poetry Slam
description:
Please join us for the Sutton Writers 2017 Winter Quiz and Prose and Poetry Slam.

Sutton Writers are very pleased to announce a poetry and prose slam combined with a fun literary quiz. Our occasional slams are always lively affairs, and a good opportunity to share your work in a supportive and ever so slightly competitive arena.

Poems, short stories and non-fiction – whatever you’ve got, so long as you can perform it within a time limit of four minutes.

We'll announce a winner at the end of the night. Quiz rounds will be between slam performances and we'll try and fit in as many as possible on the night.

Please feel free to bring some of your favourite seasonal food and drink this month too!

**********

title: Writing Crime Fiction
description:
Sutton Writers are very pleased to have crime fiction author Adam Baron join us. His first four crime books make up the Billy Rucker series and his latest is a new venture: Blackheath. He is currently Associate Professor and MA Course Director in Creative Writing at Kingston University. Visit him online at: http://www.kingston.ac.uk/staff/profile/dr-adam-baron-29/ for the full list of his publications.

**********

title: Write Together
description:
It can sometimes be hard to motivate ourselves to write. Sometimes we need a change of scenery and some creative energy in the air. If you’re feeling this, and want to make progress, come along to our Write Together session on Wednesday 31st January!

Bring yourself, your laptop/paper and pen, buy a drink and sit amongst your fellow writers (in creative silence!) to get some work done on your own current project.

This isn’t a social gathering, a collaborative project, or a workshop. We won’t be chatting or reading each other’s work to give feedback, just sitting together to work individually on our own projects.

If you’re bringing a laptop, make sure it’s fully charged as there may not be plugs available. Then grab yourself a drink and join us!

If you’d like to come, we will be in the Cock & Bull pub at the top of Sutton high street (venue TBC) from 7.30pm. Please RSVP on Meetup so Kat knows how big a table to book.

Hope to see you there!

title: Performing Your Own Work (An Interactive Workshop)
description:
Sutton Writers are very pleased to have John Wheeler, a multi slam-winning performance poet join us. John is also a teacher of many years standing and has developed a workshop that is non-judgemental and supportive for writers of both poetry and prose. It is full of activities that explain how to make the most of opportunities and avoid mistakes including how to make the most of your voice, what to do with a microphone, and how to use those empty places - pauses.

Most writers are performers - whether they want to be or not. You may think that you have written your short story for a magazine or journal. Then someone asks you read it at a meeting or festival and suddenly you are a performer.

**********

title: Haiku Poetry Workshop
description:
Sutton Writers are pleased to run a double event this month. The first part of the evening will be an introduction by Roger to Scrivener word processing software that is tailor-made for long writing projects. The second part of the evening will be a Haiku Poetry Workshop run by Christine. Christine has been developing and exploring the Haiku form at her Sutton Writers workshops as well as with The Haiku Foundation and the British Haiku Society.

description:

title: AGM and Writing Workshop led by Nicky Singer
description:
Sutton Writers are very pleased to have novelist, dramatist and librettist Nicky Singer join us. Her debut children’s novel – Feather Boy -won the Blue Peter Award and was adapted for film (BAFTA winner for Best Children’s Drama). Her adaptation of Knight Crew (a gangland re-telling of the King Arthur legend) premiered at Glyndebourne and her first original play Island was staged at the National Theatre. Her work is translated into 28 languages. It was on a recent working trip to the Sudan that she got the idea for her new novel The Survival Game (a road movie about migration) forthcoming July 2018. Nicky will use the workshop to show how you can craft fiction from your own life. You can find more about her work at www.nickysinger.com.

title: Who Needs Agents?
description:
Sutton Writers are very pleased to have Guy Rose of FRA Literary Agents join us in conversation with FRA client and Sutton Writers member Simon Woodham.

Maybe you prefer to do it all yourself via Amazon Kindle et al, but if you haven't given up on the dream of getting published in the old-fashioned way, finding an agent is surely on your 'to do' list.

With profit margins squeezed as big outlets discount to compete, many traditional publishers don't have the resources to deal fairly with huge numbers of unsolicited submissions, and look to literary agents as their front line defence. Simply, an agent can fast-track your manuscript on to the desk of the right commissioning editor who will give it serious consideration.

And then there's negotiating the advance, contracts, sale of TV and film rights... all the stuff that can keep you from getting on with your next book/script/poetry collection/play!

But how do you find an agent? How do you know what they're looking for? How do you know what you should be asking them?

Guy Rose of FRA Literary Agents has three decades of experience, representing authors of books, film and TV scripts and stage plays. In conversation with FRA client and Sutton Writers member Simon Woodham, he'll be giving us an insider's view on the current state of publishing and more. And there will be time for you to put your own questions during and after the discussion.

**********

title: Winsome Pinnock, Playwright
description:
Sutton Writers are very pleased to have playwright Winsome Pinnock join us. Winsome Pinnock is an award winning British playwright of Jamaican heritage. Winsome has had over 15 plays produced and won lots of awards, including the Thames Television Award for best play of the year. She was the first black woman to have a play produced at the National Theatre with Leave Taking in 1988. The Guardian described her as “the godmother of black British playwrights.” Not only is she an illustrious playwright but she’s also a senior lecturer at Kingston University. Winsome is a truly inspirational figure and we look forward to her talk.

**********

title: Writing Session
description:
It can sometimes be hard to motivate ourselves to write. Sometimes we need a change of scenery and some creative energy in the air. If you’re feeling this, and want to make progress, come along to our next Writing Session!

Bring yourself, your laptop/paper and pen, buy a drink and sit amongst your fellow writers (in creative silence!) to get some work done on your own current project.

This isn’t a social gathering, a collaborative project, or a workshop. We won’t be chatting or reading each other’s work to give feedback, just sitting together to work individually on our own projects.

If you’re bringing a laptop, make sure it’s fully charged as there may not be plugs available. Then grab yourself a drink and join us!

If you’d like to come, we will be in the Cock & Bull pub at the top of Sutton high street. Please RSVP on Meetup so Paul knows how big a table to book.

Hope to see you there!

title: Annie Kenney: A Suffragette's story in 100 words
description:
Sutton Writers are very pleased to have Lucy Furlong join us to talk about the amazing Annie Kenney and the 100 DAYS project, which has highlighted so many stories and given new perspectives into people's lives during the First World War.

In partnership with the Imperial War Museum, the 100 DAYS project engaged 100 volunteer writers from 26 Characters Ltd, a not-for-profit organisation representing a diverse group of people who share a love of words. Each writer created a 100 word piece (a centena) inspired by and based on the life of a real individual who experienced the First World War. The centenas are being released daily, from 5th August to 12th November, each day showcasing the work of different members of the Partnership.

Lucy Furlong chose Annie Kenney, the only working class suffragette on the board of the Women's Social and Political Union (WSPU). Her challenge was to give Annie her voice, and in 100 words, show her vital contribution to women getting the vote in 1918.

Lucy Furlong's centena was published on August 11th, along with a film of her reading her poem in the Peace Garden at the Imperial War Museum.

Web link here:

http://www.1914.org/armistice-100-days/centenas/votes-for-women-by-lucy-furlong/

**********

title: Winter Quiz and Prose and Poetry Slam
description:
Please join us for the Sutton Writers 2018 Winter Quiz and Prose and Poetry Slam.

Sutton Writers are very pleased to announce a poetry and prose slam combined with a fun literary quiz. Our occasional slams are always lively affairs, and a good opportunity to share your work in a supportive and ever so slightly competitive arena.

Poems, short stories and non-fiction – whatever you’ve got, so long as you can perform it within a time limit of four minutes.

We'll announce a winner at the end of the night. Quiz rounds will be between slam performances and we'll try and fit in as many as possible on the night.

Please feel free to bring some of your favourite seasonal food and drink this month too!

title: Writing Session
description:
It can sometimes be hard to get the motivation, or even just the time, to write. Sometimes we need a change of scenery and some creative energy in the air. If you’re feeling this, and want to make progress, come along and sit among your fellow writers at this writing session hosted by Sutton Writers member Lauren McMenemy.

These sessions do exactly what they say on the tin: you sit, and you write. It's protected time for creativity, with the bonus of having others in the same boat alongside you. You won't be reading out any work - you can keep it totally to yourself - and there won't be any guest speakers. This is really just about getting words on a page.

Bring yourself, your laptop/paper and pen, buy a drink and get some work done on your own current project. If you don't have something on the go, Lauren will have some writing prompts and tools available for you to play around with - you never know, they might just inspire your next work of art!

Look for a table of writerly types - we'll be the ones with laptops at a pub! - and come and say hi. Stay for the whole session, or pop in for as long as you can, but please RSVP so Lauren knows how many to book a table for. Contact her or Sutton Writers via meetup if you have any questions.

title: Podcasting for Writers
description:
Podcasts have been around for a long time, but have grown hugely popular in recent years thanks to such narrative-driven podcasts as Serial and Welcome to Nightvale. The format holds plenty of scope for creativity, whether for fiction writers, journalists, essayists or even poets.

Join Chris Hawton, host of The All-New Adventures of the Doctor Who Book Club Podcast, and Andy Mallon, editor of the Man Booker Prize podcast, to hear more about what it takes to put a podcast together, how writers can harness the format, and even look at the podcasts helping writers to get better at their craft.

**********

title: Writing Historical Fiction
description:
Sutton Writers is pleased to welcome Alison Weir, the eminent historian and historical novelist and the President of Sutton Writers as our March speaker.

Alison is the biggest-selling female historian (and the fifth best-selling historian) in the United Kingdom since records began in 1997. She has published twenty-three titles and sold more than 2.7 million books - over a million in the UK and more than 1.7 million in the USA. She is now working on two concurrent series of books: Six Tudor Queens, comprising six novels on the wives of Henry VIII (with associated e-books), and England's Medieval Queens, a quartet of historical works of non-fiction. A further series of books will be announced next year.

title: Sarah Hobbs:  A talk about writing and self-publishing her poetry.
description:
Sutton Writers is pleased to have Sarah Hobbs join us to talk about writing and self-publishing her poetry.

Sarah is a poet from South London and she has now published four collections of poetry. She also performs across the open mic scene in London and hosts "Word Search – LIVE" on the 2nd Wednesday of each month at the Shinner Sudtone pub in Sutton.

Her books cover a varied range – ‘Dali In Verse’ is a narrative version of some of Salvador Dali’s paintings, ’Love Is Where The heart Is’ takes us on a journey of romance through verse and in ‘Sonnets Throughout The Year’ she shares this beautiful romantic poetry form with us. Her latest collection, 'Two Hills,’ was inspired by her grandmother’s recollection of her home in Scotland.

We look forward to Sarah sharing her work, and her thoughts behind writing her poetry, with us.

**********

NEW MEMBERS ALWAYS WELCOME

Members: The full annual membership fee includes admission to our monthly meeting. It also covers in-house competitions, attendance at workshops and other writing events. This represents very good value particularly for those who participate in the free workshops where they can benefit from the knowledge and expertise of other writers.

Visitors and Country / Online Members: You can attend your first monthly meeting free of charge. Future attendance is £5 per visit. The Country / Online membership also entitles you to attend two meetings per year and to enter all competitions.

title: Writers Critique Group
description:
Sutton Writers hosts a number of Writers Critique Groups. The Monday evening group hold their meetings fortnightly at the Thomas Hall Community Lounge.

This Writers Critique Group will accept readings of writer's short stories, chapters from novels/novellas in the making and poetry. Feedback is provided to each other by those that participate.

**********

NEW MEMBERS ALWAYS WELCOME

All attendees: The hall hire cost is very reasonable and is split between those who attend on the night. Historically this has cost each attendee, Members and Visitors alike, roughly £3 each per evening.

Members: The full annual membership fee includes admission to Writers Critique Groups. Members only have to pay the hall hire charge.

Visitors and Country / Online Members: You may attend your first Writers Critique Group free of charge (plus the hall hire charge). Future attendance is £5 per visit (plus the hall hire charge).

title: Writing Session
description:
It can sometimes be hard to get the motivation, or even just the time, to write. Sometimes we need a change of scenery and some creative energy in the air. If you’re feeling this, and want to make progress, come along and sit among your fellow writers at this writing session hosted by Sutton Writers member Lauren McMenemy.

These sessions do exactly what they say on the tin: you sit, and you write. It's protected time for creativity, with the bonus of having others in the same boat alongside you. You won't be reading out any work - you can keep it totally to yourself - and there won't be any guest speakers. This is really just about getting words on a page.

Bring yourself, your laptop/paper and pen, buy a drink and get some work done on your own current project. If you don't have something on the go, Lauren will have some writing prompts and tools available for you to play around with - you never know, they might just inspire your next work of art!

Look for a table of writerly types - we'll be the ones with laptops at a pub! - and come and say hi. Stay for the whole session, or pop in for as long as you can, but please RSVP so Lauren knows how many to book a table for. Contact her or Sutton Writers via meetup if you have any questions.

Hope to see you there!

title: Using the tarot to inspire writing
description:
In this session, Fiongal Greenlaw-Meek from the Wellness Foundry will talk about the tarot as a source of inspiration for writing practice.

Speaker Biography
The hugely sought-after Fiongal Greenlaw-Meek is a Psychic, Tarot Master and Spiritual Coach. His mission is to make intuitive practises available to all as he believes it's the greatest path to healing, clarity and growth.

Fiongal has worked with Chanel, Dior, Selfridges, L'Oreal & Harvey Nichols and has been voted *London’s Top Tarot Reader* in Time Out.

The Wellness Foundry - an intuitive, wellbeing and place of spiritual rest consisting of Tarot & Psychic Readings, Healings, Astrology and Psychic Art launched in 2018 to provide others with spiritual insights and knowledge to navigate their best life’s path. Also offering events, workshops and Fiongal runs several intuitive development circles.

This session is free for members of Sutton Writers. Non-members are welcome and are invited to pay a voluntary £5 via Buy me a coffee https://www.buymeacoffee.com/suttonwriters

title: Shape and Tone that Manuscript!
description:
Are you a writer with a complete or nearly completed manuscript draft? Preparing to submit to an agent? Polishing your synopsis?

Polish that final draft with tutor feedback and peer review. Receive good questions and positive feedback from likeminded creatives. All genres welcome.

Green Ink Writers’ Gym is run by freelance writer and editor Rachel Knightley. A former copywriter and subeditor for Telegraph Media Group, Harvey Nichols and Transworld Publishing, Rachel left her “sensible job” in 2008 to run theatre-based fundraising and new writing events for Macmillan Cancer Support, including the now annual “Green Ink Sponsored Write” at Waterstones Piccadilly. Rachel’s short stories are published by Swan River Press, Writers’ Forum and CCWC Press. Her plays have been performed by the National Trust, HENs Theatre and Endpaper. She is currently working on her first novel while taking her PhD in creative writing.

title: Make Writing Friends, Get Writing Done!
description:
• What we'll do
Where better than Europe's biggest book shop to make new writing friends, drink tea and get a load of writing done?

Join us in the gorgeous basement cafe of Waterstones' Piccadilly for 2pm; that'll give us time for chatting and tea/coffee/cake choosing. There'll be a creative writing warm-up exercise led by Green Ink Writers' Gym's Rachel Knightley at 2.15pm. Then, from 2.30pm, it's "you time" to get that story/chapter/poem/essay/etc out of your head and onto the page! We'll stop for more chatting/coffee/tea/cake at 3.45pm.

Only ten places so 'first come first served'. Priority given to PayPal bookings but cash on the day is fine if there are still spaces (keep checking this page to be sure, or message Rachel).

Looking forward to writing with you!

• What to bring
Whatever you write best with and on! Fully-charged laptops especially welcome.

• Important to know

title: Editing and Rewriting – Week 1 of 8 Workshops
description:
Are you a writer with a complete or nearly completed manuscript?

Preparing to submit to an agent or publisher?

Polish that final draft with tutor feedback, peer review and editorial tips and exercises. Receive helpful questions and positive, practical feedback. Hone your editing skills as you respond to your own work and that of others. Regular reading slots, dedicated time to rework your material and reignite your imagination.

Book one workshop for £15 or visit Green Ink Writers' Gym's website to book a discounted 'season ticket' for all eight sessions.

All genres welcome but places strictly limited! (No more than eight participants to a workshop, so only five places open through Meetup.)

title: Creative Writing: 6-week workshop course from 20 April
description:
Boost your confidence – and your word-count!

From sharpening your dialogue to structuring your story, Green Ink Writers' Gym puts you fully in command of your creative writing toolkit.

Whether you're completely new to writing, are an experienced writer switching genre or just looking to take your hobby up a gear, this six-week course gives the skills, confidence and inspiration to help you find your voice and tell your story. Each workshop focuses on a fundamental area of writing applicable to novels, short stories, poetry, memoir, life-writing and flash fiction alike: Character and Setting, Description and Dialogue, Plot and Structure, Voice and Style, Editing and Refining.

All genres welcome but places limited! Book one workshop for £18 or visit Green Ink Writers' Gym's website to book your discounted 'season ticket'.

title: Creative Writing at Waterstones Piccadilly
description:
Creative, practical and inspiring writing workshops. Each workshop is applicable to novels, short stories, poetry, memoir, life-writing and flash fiction alike – just bring yourself, and whatever you like to write in or on (fully-charged laptops welcome!). Join us in Emberton's (downstairs cafe-bar) for all-new sessions on character, setting, description, dialogue, plot and structure.

Boost your confidence and your word-count and network with new writing friends.

From sharpening your dialogue to structuring your story, Green Ink Writers' Gym puts you fully in command of your creative writing toolkit. Book a workshop through Meetup or for a discount on the full course visit www.greeninkwritersgym.com

title: Join us for a FREE Creative Writing Workshop
description:
Develop your work-in-progress or begin a whole new writing world with creative exercises, positive discussion and inspiring stimulus. This is a free workshop for writers to enjoy. Don't worry if you've got loads of experience or none at all – this is a positive environment to write, make new friends and move forward with your story.

Just bring yourself and whatever you like writing with and on (fully-charged laptops welcome)! Tea, coffee, cake available to buy from the cafe. If you have any questions, just get in touch!

title: Creative Writing at Waterstones Piccadilly
description:
FIRST WORKSHOP FREE ON MEETUP then discount on full course!

Creative, practical and inspiring writing workshops. Each workshop is applicable to novels, short stories, poetry, memoir, life-writing and flash fiction alike – just bring yourself, and whatever you like to write in or on (fully-charged laptops welcome!). Join us in Emberton's (downstairs cafe-bar) for all-new sessions on character, setting, description, dialogue, plot and structure.

Boost your confidence and your word-count and network with new writing friends.

From sharpening your dialogue to structuring your story, Green Ink Writers' Gym puts you fully in command of your creative writing toolkit. Whether you're completely new to writing, are an experienced writer switching genre or just looking to take your hobby up a gear, this six-week course gives the skills, confidence and inspiration to help you find your voice and tell your story.

Book a workshop through Meetup or for a discount on the full course visit www.greeninkwritersgym.com

title: Join us for a FREE Creative Writing Workshop
description:
Develop your work-in-progress or begin a whole new writing world with creative exercises, positive discussion and inspiring stimulus. This is a free workshop for writers to enjoy. Don't worry if you've got loads of experience or none at all – this is a positive environment to write, make new friends and move forward with your story.

Just bring yourself and whatever you like writing with and on (fully-charged laptops welcome)! Tea, coffee and other writing stimulants available to buy at the cafe-bar, within easy distance of our quieter, reserved area. If you have any questions, just get in touch!

title: Week 1: Creative Writing, Rewriting and Editing at Waterstones Piccadilly
description:
Take your work-in-progress forward with creative and inspiring exercises to sharpen your scenes, clarify your ideas, strengthen your plot and bring out your voice as a writer. Bring individual scenes, chapters, poems or whatever suits you – make progress and friends!

Each workshop in this six-week course is applicable to novels, short stories, life-writing, memoir, poetry and flash fiction alike – just bring yourself, and whatever you like best to write with and on (fully-charged laptops welcome!).

Your first workshop is FREE when you book through Meetup.com. You'll also receive a 10% discount voucher to use on any session or course in your first term with Green Ink Writers' Gym. Book now or get in touch here: info@greeninkwritersgym.com/www.greeninkwritersgym.com

title: The Writing Room (Silent Co-working Space)
description:
While our courses take a break over the summer, we're running pop-up silent writing workspaces for anyone who wants to grab some quality creative time.

Turn off your sound (and video if you like) and join the Writing Room! The chat box will be open but please stay muted so as not to jog anybody out of their flow!

£2 per session or email Rachel to pay £5 for access to every session over the summer.

title: Rewiring Your What-ifs: Confidence & Creativity Coaching
description:
Rewire your “what if…” circuitry away from anxiety and towards engagement with your goals, values and personality. Each session will be a mix of practical coaching tools and creative exercises to get you more comfortable in your driving seat for art, work and life.

Dr Rachel Knightley is a fiction and non-fiction author (Black Shuck Books, 1984 Publishing, Illuminate/Hodder Educational), presenter (Starburst Magazine/Channel, Indicator Films) and business and personal development. coach. She studied Teaching Creative Writing at the University of Cambridge and is completing her PGCert with Barefoot Coaching and the University of Chester in Autumn 2022. Visit rachelknightley.com or DM to ask questions/say hello!

**Week 1: Goal-setting**
Sometimes a busy or stressful time means dealing with the ‘immediate’ in our lives constantly and the ‘important’ more rarely. This can mean what we want takes a back-seat to what we fear. Today is a chance to connect with each other, reconnect with ourselves and explore relaxing and intriguing coaching tools to focus on what you enjoy, love, value, and what steps can connect your wishes and hopes to your habits and goals for the work, art and life you want.
**Week 2:** **Characterisation – in Life** **and Art!**
Who are the characters that we carry in our minds, whose opinions, wishes and values affect our decision-making? Both in our fiction and day-to-day life, today is an opportunity to get to know those voices, ask what they want, and ask yourself whether you still want them as major or minor characters. Enjoy a mix of exercises to bring your own voice out of the chorus, and actively select which voices get to stay in your backing group!
**Week 3: Plotting – The Story So Far**
Today we explore the relationship between character and plot: how events create characters, but also how characters, as they change, change the world around them as a result. Enjoy a mix of practical exercises, story tools and problem-solving activities to make your story grow your way. These techniques will work for decisions on the page as well as those you make in work, at home and with family and friends.
**Week 4:** **Time and Place**
Today we’ll look at what it means to feel present in your life and story, and how that sense of being present allows you to experience and utilise your time. Make un-rushed, value-centred choices about what you do, how and who you spend your time with and what you give space to in life and on the page. Explore and develop incisive questions for your unique story, on the page and off it!
**Week 5: Freedom Not Fear: Approaching the Blank Page**
When you are clear about your character’s objective, it’s much easier to know what dialogue and actions they will select. This is just as true in life as it is on the page or on the stage. Today, we’ll be using tools, activities and resources to explore self-direction and value-aligned action. Bring “show don’t tell” into your boundaries in work and life, and into the quality of your creative and professional writing.
**Week 6:** **Moving Forward**
A celebration and summary of the discoveries you’ve made in art, work and life. Requests welcome for any favourite exercises to revisit, as we honour the journeys so far and plan for what happens next. Looking back to goal-setting in week 1, what are the things that were important to you then and how are you going to keep the ‘important’ above water when the ‘immediate’ is all around?

Book weekly through Meetup or book the full course at www.greeninkwritersgym.com

title: Write From Life – Memoir and Fiction Writing
description:
TWO PLACES LEFT!

Develop your unique voice and stories through the tools and techniques of professional writing. All levels of experience will gain confidence and advance their work-in-progress with enjoyable exercises and tips, informative and friendly discussion and extracts from fiction, memoir and non-fiction. Optional feedback slots are available to everyone who enrols for the full course (minimum of two per writer, 2500-word maximum per slot).

Dr Rachel Knightley is a fiction and non-fiction author, presenter and business and personal development coach. She trained in Teaching Creative Writing at the University of Cambridge and is completing her PGCert with Barefoot Coaching and the Uviersity of Chester in autumn 2022. Visit rachelknightley.com or ask questions/say hello by direct message here!

£42.50 per session or book for the full course at www.greeninkwritersgym.com

**Week 1: Writing Mindset: Using Your Artist’s Palette**
Mastering access to the full range of memory and imagination that every writer mixes to create their unique voice and story. Exercises to liberate and encourage free movement around your thoughts, feelings and questions about the world all of which will inform your stories.
**Week 2: Through These Eyes: Getting to Know Your Protagonist**
Your central character is the reader’s – and writer’s – eyes and ears on the world. Whether they’re based closely on you or not like you at all, this week’s exercises and extracts will help you use your own life, thoughts and feelings as fuel to discover who they are and where they’re taking the story.
**Week 3: Raising Personal Stakes: Plot** **and Theme for Fiction and Memoir**
What your story is about will be the essence of what your character has to face. Developing on what you’ve learnt about them, today we ask what’s the worst thing that can happen to them, who they are (or want to be) and how do they grow by the events of the plot?
**Week 4: Framing the Journey**: **Beginnings and Endings**
The more you know about your characters, plot and theme, the freer you will be to decide how you want to present your story to your reader. Should it be chronological? Or is there a later event that, if revealed earlier, will ensure we’re hooked? Explore different shapes and routes your story’s journey could take.
**Week 5: Short and Long Form: A Moment or a Process**?
Today we’ll explore the differences between short and long-form memoir and fiction. We’ll use techniques to identify the key moment of change around which you can shape a compelling narrative through use of pace and momentum.
**Week 6: Live Editing**
Select an extract of your current work-in-progress to receive live editorial feedback. Today will be a tour of the process from conceptual discussions to how, when the time comes, you will work with an editor on line-editing.

She trained in Teaching Creative Writing at the University of Cambridge and is completing her PGCert with Barefoot Coaching and the Uviersity of Chester in autumn 2022. Visit rachelknightley.com or ask questions/say hello by direct message here!

£42.50 per session or book for the full course at www.greeninkwritersgym.com

**Week 1: Writing Mindset: Using Your Artist’s Palette**
Mastering access to the full range of memory and imagination that every writer mixes to create their unique voice and story. Exercises to liberate and encourage free movement around your thoughts, feelings and questions about the world all of which will inform your stories.
**Week 2: Through These Eyes: Getting to Know Your Protagonist**
Your central character is the reader’s – and writer’s – eyes and ears on the world. Whether they’re based closely on you or not like you at all, this week’s exercises and extracts will help you use your own life, thoughts and feelings as fuel to discover who they are and where they’re taking the story.
**Week 3: Raising Personal Stakes: Plot** **and Theme for Fiction and Memoir**
What your story is about will be the essence of what your character has to face. Developing on what you’ve learnt about them, today we ask what’s the worst thing that can happen to them, who they are (or want to be) and how do they grow by the events of the plot?
**Week 4: Framing the Journey**: **Beginnings and Endings**
The more you know about your characters, plot and theme, the freer you will be to decide how you want to present your story to your reader. Should it be chronological? Or is there a later event that, if revealed earlier, will ensure we’re hooked? Explore different shapes and routes your story’s journey could take.
**Week 5: Short and Long Form: A Moment or a Process**?
Today we’ll explore the differences between short and long-form memoir and fiction. We’ll use techniques to identify the key moment of change around which you can shape a compelling narrative through use of pace and momentum.
**Week 6: Live Editing**
Select an extract of your current work-in-progress to receive live editorial feedback. Today will be a tour of the process from conceptual discussions to how, when the time comes, you will work with an editor on line-editing.

title: Rewiring Your What-ifs: Confidence & Creativity Coaching
description:
Rewire your “what if…” circuitry away from anxiety and towards engagement with your goals, values and personality. Each session will be a mix of practical coaching tools and creative exercises to get you more comfortable in your driving seat for art, work and life.

Dr Rachel Knightley is a fiction and non-fiction author (Black Shuck Books, 1984 Publishing, Illuminate/Hodder Educational), presenter (Starburst Magazine/Channel, Indicator Films) and business and personal development. coach. She studied Teaching Creative Writing at the University of Cambridge and is completing her PGCert with Barefoot Coaching and the University of Chester in Autumn 2022. Visit rachelknightley.com or DM to ask questions/say hello!

**Week 1: Goal-setting**
Sometimes a busy or stressful time means dealing with the ‘immediate’ in our lives constantly and the ‘important’ more rarely. This can mean what we want takes a back-seat to what we fear. Today is a chance to connect with each other, reconnect with ourselves and explore relaxing and intriguing coaching tools to focus on what you enjoy, love, value, and what steps can connect your wishes and hopes to your habits and goals for the work, art and life you want.
**Week 2:** **Characterisation – in Life** **and Art!**
Who are the characters that we carry in our minds, whose opinions, wishes and values affect our decision-making? Both in our fiction and day-to-day life, today is an opportunity to get to know those voices, ask what they want, and ask yourself whether you still want them as major or minor characters. Enjoy a mix of exercises to bring your own voice out of the chorus, and actively select which voices get to stay in your backing group!
**Week 3: Plotting – The Story So Far**
Today we explore the relationship between character and plot: how events create characters, but also how characters, as they change, change the world around them as a result. Enjoy a mix of practical exercises, story tools and problem-solving activities to make your story grow your way. These techniques will work for decisions on the page as well as those you make in work, at home and with family and friends.
**Week 4:** **Time and Place**
Today we’ll look at what it means to feel present in your life and story, and how that sense of being present allows you to experience and utilise your time. Make un-rushed, value-centred choices about what you do, how and who you spend your time with and what you give space to in life and on the page. Explore and develop incisive questions for your unique story, on the page and off it!
**Week 5: Freedom Not Fear: Approaching the Blank Page**
When you are clear about your character’s objective, it’s much easier to know what dialogue and actions they will select. This is just as true in life as it is on the page or on the stage. Today, we’ll be using tools, activities and resources to explore self-direction and value-aligned action. Bring “show don’t tell” into your boundaries in work and life, and into the quality of your creative and professional writing.
**Week 6:** **Moving Forward**
A celebration and summary of the discoveries you’ve made in art, work and life. Requests welcome for any favourite exercises to revisit, as we honour the journeys so far and plan for what happens next. Looking back to goal-setting in week 1, what are the things that were important to you then and how are you going to keep the ‘important’ above water when the ‘immediate’ is all around?

Book weekly through Meetup or book the full course at www.greeninkwritersgym.com

title: Dark Comedy Writers & Performers
description:
Depending on whether people have already written anything or not, we can read and give feedback, bounce some ideas around, film something or just work on our own stuff alongside each other. Or someone might have a better idea.

I need help with re-writing a short film script about a university fresher. Very 'Louie' inspired.

title: Dark Comedy Writers, Evening meetup
description:
Depending on whether people have already written anything or not, we can read and give feedback, bounce some ideas around, test out our lines and scenes together, or just work on our own stuff alongside each other. Whatever time allows!

Foyles has accessable toilets upstairs and has lift access, to the left as you enter bookshop. Cafe is 5th floor.

Anything you're not sure about, feel free to post or direct message the organizer

title: Dark Comedy Writers & Performers
description:
We will have a table from 6pm, some may come earlier to sit and work. We will have a work period until 7.15pm, then we can introduce ourselves, and share our progress or goals, as people wish.

Depending whether anyone has already written anything or not, we can read and give feedback, bounce some ideas around, test out our lines and scenes together, or just work on our own stuff alongside each other. Whatever time allows!

Foyles Cafe closes at 8.15 approx, then anyone wishing to socialise we will go round to the The Angel pub across the road.

Foyles has accessable toilets and lift access, to the left as you enter bookshop. Cafe is 5th floor.

Anything you're not sure about, feel free to post or direct message the organizer.

COVID: Until current pandemic levels change please can everyone attending maintain regular self-testing, before and after travelling, and take all other steps to monitor your transmission risks.

...We will be indoors in close proximity: Masks not mandatory in venue but we would encourage them as much as you can.

Please respect distancing as much as possible, once together and talking with others. And do not travel at all if you or others around you have tested positive for Covid, or you have possible symptoms and are not sure. Thank you.

ACCESS: Foyles has accessable toilets and lift access, to the left as you enter bookshop. Cafe is 5th floor.

Anything you're not sure about, feel free to post or direct message the organizer.

title: Dark Comedy Writers & Performers (in-person)
description:
We will have a table from 3pm but some may arrive earlier or later: the cafe space is open until 6, but stops serving by 5.30.

This is an in-person group offering an informal space to connect and co-work, for those who would like to get involved with each others work or improve their own.

Depending whether anyone has already written anything or not, we can read and give feedback, bounce some ideas around, test out our lines and scenes together, or just work on our own stuff alongside each other. Whatever time and numbers allow!

Foyles has accessable toilets upstairs, and lift access to the left as you enter bookshop. Cafe is on 5th floor.

Anything you're not sure about, feel free to post or direct message the organizer.

title: Writing & Performing Comedy Sketches For Youtube
description:
Let's get together and make some sketches. We can film them and upload them to our Youtubes, IGs or whatever (or not film them if you prefer). This is the first time I'm trying to organise this so we might have to work things out as we go along.

Example of I mean:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sUed_iKUO6U&list=PLEPylCyeEzoVWEZ7AKSGBINmu09uDHO1T&index=2

Probably more suited to those who're happy to act as well as come up with ideas, though all welcome.

Open to ideas on how to run things, venue etc.

title: Filming Comedy Sketches For Youtube - Writers/Actors/Filmmakers/Runners
description:
Let's get together and make some sketches for fun. We can film them (on our smartphones) and upload them to our Youtubes, IGs, TokTiks or whatever.

Example of what I mean:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sUed_iKUO6U&list=PLEPylCyeEzoVWEZ7AKSGBINmu09uDHO1T&index=2

All interesting in making videos welcome - we need funny people, unfunny people, actors, directors, people to just hold the camera or a light or get audio.

**If you do have filmmaking equipment please bring it!**
Make sure you have a fully charged phone with lots of free space.
Also the more props the merrier as it's easier to come up with ideas when you have stuff to work with.

I'm expecting quite a few people so we might have to split into 2 or 3 groups.

I'm just making this up as I go along so I'm open to ideas on how to run things, venue etc.

title: Initial Meetup - Planning
description:
Hi

This will be the inital meeting of the group and it will mainly be focused on how the group should be going forward. We'll discuss the structure of our future discussion sessions, how to share stories within the group, the method of choosing works to be discussed and other events for the group.

So bring your best ideas and come meet fellow weird writers.

Look forward to seeing you there.

group.name: London Weird and Horror Writers Meetup

title: Initial Meetup - Planning
description:
Hi All

I think we had some issues with people finding me in The Lamb for our last session so we will be trying the intial meet up again. Just look out for the large blue book of Lovecraft's complte works sat on a table. Also just to note that I now have no beard and a shaved head (unlike my photo).

As before, this will be the inital meeting of the group and it will mainly be focused on how the group should be going forward. We'll discuss the structure of our future discussion sessions, how to share stories within the group, the method of choosing works to be discussed and other events for the group.

So bring your best ideas and come meet fellow weird writers.

Look forward to seeing you there.

group.name: London Weird and Horror Writers Meetup

title: Short Story Meetup - October
description:
Hi All

After a sucessful intial planning meet up in August (and some how September slipped away from us), we now have our first fully fledged short story meet up. In these we will discuss two or three short stories prepared by our members, say what we liked and offer helpful hints.

We have selected our two stories for October and will be circulating these by email. If you would like to come along and read the stories in advance just drop me a private message on Meetup and I will add your email to the chain.

At this Meetup we will also be taking volunteers for stories in advance of our November meetup.

Just to note that The Lamb also has an upstairs so we may be there. Just look out for the large blue Lovecraft book.

Look forward to seeing you there.

group.name: London Weird and Horror Writers Meetup

group.name: London Weird and Horror Writers Meetup

title: Xmas Meetup (Eye of Argon) - December
description:
Hi All

As Christmas will be approaching by the time of our December Meetup, we will be departing from our usual format for a festive special.

Still in The Lamb (meeting a little earlier and at the weekend), we will be doing the Eye of Argon Challenge. The Eye of Argon by Jim Theis has gained a dubious reputation by being considered one of the worst fantasy works written. The challenge involves reading the Eye of Argon without laughing or hesitating, passing the book on to the next reader once you do.

So feel free to come along and we will be back to usual in January.

Just to note that The Lamb has an upstairs so we will likely be there. Just look out for the large blue Lovecraft book.

Look forward to seeing you there.

title: Weird Writers Christmas Competition
description:
Hi All

Following on from our Christmas special last year, we will be holding a special session over Skype for this holiday period.

To replace our normal structure, we are running a competition for parodies, homages, rip offs and plain plagiarism. Essentially write a story in the style of your favourite author, genre or trope and we will see which is the best.

Deadline for submissions is 8 December.

If you would like to attend, drop me a message with your email address and I can send you the full details and Skype link.

Hope to see you there.

Look forward to seeing you there.

group.name: London Weird and Horror Writers Meetup

title: Online Pandemic Flash Fiction - September
description:
Hi All

In a change to our usual sessions, for September we will be doing a flash fiction session for anyone who wants to be involved.

Simply put we will be writing pieces of less than 500 words about (any) pandemic (real or metaphorical). These will be submitted ahead of the session and we will discuss these on the evening.

We read the stories in advance and these are circulated by Google Drive. Submissions are open to everyone so there are no pre-picked writers.

If you would like to come along, submit and/or read the stories in advance just drop me a private message on Meetup with your email and I will send you the link which also contains details and deadlines

This meeting is via Skype so I'll also send you the link to this with the stories.

Look forward to seeing you there.

title: Weird Writers Christmas Competition
description:
Hi All

Following on from our Christmas special last year, we will be holding another special session for this holiday period. This will be in-person.

To replace our normal structure, we are running a competition for best cross overs. Essentially write a story involving a clash of styles or genres, well known tropes in new context or beloved characters in unknown settings.

Full entry parameters are in the normal email.

Deadline for submissions is 17 December.

If you would like to attend, drop me a message with your email address and I can send you the full details.

Hope to see you there.

title: Show and Tell Meetup - August
description:
Hi All

This is a change from our usual session in that this will simply be a chance to chat about our favourite books, films, comics, music or whatever. Just come along with a few things in mind that you wish more people knew about.

Horror and weird preferred but feel free to stretch that to its limits. No need to actually bring the thing but also feel free to!

This will be a physical meeting in the Duke, 7 Rodger Street. I have booked a table and we will likely be downstairs.

Look forward to seeing you there.

title: Write Together - Best Location for Writing!
description:
I found the perfect location for aspiring writers to get together and write in a beautiful and very quiet (practically empty!) location.

There's wifi, computer ports, and coffee!

Bring your laptops, bring your notes and let's all have a lovely mix of writing in silence amongst other writers and networking, encouraging each other.

There's enough space for writers to break out to chat without disturbing others.

I look forward to writing with you all!

Bring your laptops, bring your notes and let's all have a lovely mix of writing in silence amongst other writers and networking, encouraging each other.

There's enough space for writers to break out to chat without disturbing others.

I look forward to writing with you all!

title: WRITERS & ACTORS WORKING SUPPER - books, plays or screenplays read or performed
description:
https://secure.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/c/7/3/0/600_466550992.jpeg

FIRST WRITERS AND ACTORS SUPPER CLUB

(£5 for costs)

First and last one of year!

Bring your best, troubling or controversial plays, screenplays or books - we'll try to mix it up. Depending on how many of us are present we will aim to look at either a couple of chapters from books and an Act or two as appropriate for either a play or screenplay.

When you RSVP please MESSAGE me to:

*. Indicate whether you are a WRITER, ACTOR or DIRECTOR.

* Let me know with plays or screenplays numbers of characters and genders.

At this stage we will cast on the night and actors may be quite busy!

We will all muck in with reading as needs indicate, the space is quite flexible. We should all be prepared to say something helpful to fellow writers.

REFRESHMENTS WILL BE AVAILABLE

Please come clutching £5 to cover costs 🙂

PAULINE FINDLAY JOINING US REMOTELY FROM AUSTRALIA!

https://secure.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/7/1/6/2/600_466709026.jpeg

group.name: WRITERS AND ACTORS LUNCH & SUPPER CLUB

title: WRITERS & ACTORS WORKING LUNCH - books, plays or screenplays read and performed
description:
https://secure.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/c/7/3/0/600_466550992.jpeg

WRITERS AND ACTORS SUPPER CLUB. (£5 for costs)

Bring your best, troubling or controversial plays, screenplays or books - we'll try to mix it up. Depending on how many of us are present we will aim to look at either a couple of chapters from books and an Act or two as appropriate for either a play or screenplay.

_____________________________________________________________________________________________________

THIS MONTH'S FULL REHEARSED READING OF PLAY BY MEMBER: LISE LEROUX

DON'T BLAME THE APRICOTS
A dark comedy reminiscent of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, A Clockwork Orange and The Stanford Experiment. A full-length play based on a psychopath rehabilitation experiment...

______________________________________________________________________________________________________

When you RSVP please MESSAGE me to:

*. Indicate whether you are a WRITER, ACTOR or DIRECTOR and what if anything (no pressures) you would like to do on the day

* Let me know with plays or screenplays numbers of characters and genders.

REFRESHMENTS WILL BE AVAILABLE

Please come clutching £5 to cover costs 🙂

title: THE BLACK LIST - SOCIAL HUB FOR SCREENWRITERS
description:
GREAT NETWORKING EVENT FOR SCREENWRITERS!

A NICE LITTLE GO-TO FOR GROUP - I HAVE DOWNLOADED x10 TICKETS The Black List expanded our Happy Hours for one primary reason: to create social hubs for writers around the world where they can meet other screenwriters and discuss the craft and the reality of the screenwriter's life.

So join your fellow writers at our London happy hour! Come to enjoy the drinks and the company. You never know who you might meet!

We host happy hours on the first Wednesday of every month

title: CRIME WRITING MASTERCLASS (BRIGHTON)
description:
• What we'll do
A GREAT GO-TO FOR US CRIME WRITERS IN THE GROUP!

£55

PURCHASE TICKET ON EVENTBRITE (SEE LINK) AND THEN RSVP. https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/brighton-crime-fiction-masterclass-tickets-42649215953?aff=eac2

In association with Waterstones, the much-lauded Crime Fiction Masterclass rolls into Brighton, following on from the success of two masterclasses in London and one in Manchester.

Four experts in the field of fiction and crime will give you all the tools you need to get your crime fiction right. Bestselling author Erin Kelly will teach you how to introduce drama into your fiction and how to access the research you need.

FOUR FANTASTIC EXPERTS

1) Serving CSI ad author Kate Bendelow will take you through a crime scene and tell you how to avoid the pitfalls.

2) Graham Bartlett, an ex-senior detective, bestselling author and adviser to worldwide bestseller to Peter James, will teach you how things really work in the police.

3) Kate and Graham will combine their experience to teach you the realities and procedures involved in a post-mortem.

4). Bestselling author and practising criminal lawyer Neil White will guide you through the legal system and teach you how to get it right.

LUNCH AND REFRESHMENTS ARE INCLUDED!

Once we have numbers we'll work out a good meeting point for traveling together hopefully

• What to bring
Pen, Paper or laptop.

• Important to know

group.name: WRITERS AND ACTORS LUNCH & SUPPER CLUB

title: WRITERS & ACTORS LS CLUB ON BOOK BARGE!  READINGS AND BOOK SALE OPPORTUNITY!
description:
WRITERS & ACTORS PICNIC!

A BRING YOUR OWN PICNIC AND SHARE YOUR WRITING!

A CELEBRATION OF WRITING AND ACTING ABOARD A BEAUTIFUL MOORED BOOKSHOP!

IF YOU HAVE A PLAY OR SCRIPT THIS CAN BE PERFORMED ABOARD BARGE TOO - IT'S NOT JUST ABOUT BOOKS!

A floating bookshop on Regent’s Canal towpath

A 1920s Dutch barge has been lovingly transformed into a floating bookshop. It used to travel along Regent's Canal, but it’s now taken up permanent residence by Granary Square in King’s Cross. As well as keenly priced books they boast a woodburning stove, friendly dog and live jazz performances.

SELL YOUR BOOKS VIA SHOP!
The usual readings of book excerpts from books, plays, film scripts, poems AND for PUBLISHED AUTHORS Word-on-the-Water will sell copies of your books via bookshop (50:50) with bookshop but a vibrant passing trade here by the canal.

We can supply good readers for you i.e. you can do it if you choose via on-board microphone (let us know if you have any needs in that regard).

WRITERS AND ACTORS LUNCH & SUPPER CLUB.

title: FREE SPECIAL WRITERS WORKSHOP WITH BESTSELLING AUTHOR - ANGELA CLARKE
description:
We've booked a special workshop with author, columnist and all round writing expert Angela Clarke. As well as the author of several bestsellers Angela also works as a manuscript reader for The Literary Consultancy, and private clients. In 2015 was awarded the Young Stationers’ Prize for achievement and promise in writing and publishing. It will be amazing to have her in attendance.

Get your FREE ticket here:-

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/writing-meet-a-bestseller-angela-clarke-social-media-murder-series-tickets-48981840002?aff=affiliate1

WE'LL LET ANGELA INTRODUCE HERSELF!

I’m The Sunday Times bestselling author of the Social Media Murder Series, a screenwriter, playwright and presenter. My debut crime thriller Follow Me was named Amazon’s Rising Star Debut of the Month January 2016, longlisted for the Crime Writer’s Association Dagger in the Library 2016, and shortlisted for the Dead Good Reader Page Turner Award 2016. Follow Me has been optioned for TV production. Watch Me the second instalment in the Social Media Murder Series went straight into the UK paperback chart at number 15 in January 2017.

My memoir Confessions of a Fashionista is an Amazon Fashion Chart bestseller. My next novel, a standalone psychological suspense thriller is called On My Life and has the set up: framed, imprisoned, pregnant. It’s out in March 2019. You can find out more about me at www.AngelaClarke.co.uk

________________________________ooooOoooo________________________

Normal workshops of your new work will take place with Angela Angela ready to "comment on as many as do read on the day.." as well as introduce you to her recent work. It's gonna be a good one!

WALSC are delighted to have secured the iconic Library a stone's throw from Trafalgar Square. Please buy dinks from the bar (so we get to use venue again)! Nibbles should be available.

In association with Womens Radio Station who will be covering event.

title: MEET BEST SELLER MENTOR & PUBLISHER - AMANDA SAINT
description:
WE ARE HONOURED TO WELCOME AMANDA SAINT OF RETREAT WEST TO JOIN WRITERS AND WRITERS LUNCH & SUPPER CLUB THIS NOVEMBER.

As ever your best, troubling or controversial plays, screenplays or books to be performed / read for peer and (on this occasion) specialist feedback

• LIVE MUSIC RECEPTION
• A TALK ABOUT THE ART OF WRITING
• Q&A WITH AMANDA ABOUT WHAT IT TAKES TO BE A BESTSELLING
AUTHOR AND HOW SHE HAS STEERED SOME BESTSELLING AWARD
WINNING AND NOMINATED AUTHORS TO BESTSELLING GLORY!

• FLASH FICTION COMPETITION WITH JUDGES: AMANDA SAINT AND
ROSE McGINTY Author of Electric Souk (Winners chosen by clapometer - prize awarded for best)!

• PUBLISHED WRITERS WORKS
Rose McGinty - Ekectric Souk
Mina Adoo - Inky Black Woman

• WORKSHOPPING NEW WRITING - WITH SPECIALIST FEEDBACK
• ENHANCED REFRESHMENTS FOR THIS SPECIAL!

ABOUT RETREAT WEST & RETREAT WEST BOOKS
Retreat West was founded by novelist and short story writer, Amanda Saint, in 2012. So far some of the people that have worked with us include Man-Booker Prize shortlisted author, Alison Moore; multi-award-winning short story writer, Vanessa Gebbie; Polari Prize winning-novelist and founder of the London Short Story Festival, Paul McVeigh; and the head of the Faber Academy’s fiction programme, novelist and poet, Richard Skinner.

We’ve also worked with top literary agents for the First Chapter competitions, including Jo Unwin in association with Rogers, Coleridge & Wright; Susan Armstrong, at Conville & Walsh; Jenny Savill, at Andrew Nurnberg Associates; Laura Williams at Peters, Fraser and Dunlop; and Diana Beaumont at Marjacq.

In 2017 what we do was expanded and Retreat West Books independent press was launched. We’re publishing anthologies of the winning stories in the annual Retreat West Competitions, as well as commissioning short story collections and novels from emerging authors and having open submissions for various charity anthologies. See all the titles we’ve published so far, and the ones we have coming soon, here.

ALSO IN ATTENDANCE

ROSE McGINTY author of ELECTRIC SOUK

Depending on how many of us are present we will aim to look at either a couple of chapters from books and an Act or two as appropriate for either a play or screenplay.

Please come clutching £5 to cover costs 🙂

NOW ON EVENTBRITE!
https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/meet-best-seller-mentor-publisher-amanda-saint-tickets-51719762201?utm-medium=discovery&utm-campaign=social&utm-content=attendeeshare&aff=escb&utm-source=cp&utm-term=listing

title: ONLINE WRITERS & ACTORS SUPPER CLUB & FILM DISCUSSION
description:
https://secure.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/c/7/3/0/600_466550992.jpeg

ONLINE WRITERS AND ACTORS SUPPER CLUB.

Bring your best, troubling or controversial plays, screenplays or books for discussion. Depending on how many of us are present we will aim to look at either a couple of chapters from books and an Act or two as appropriate for either a play or screenplay.

AGENDA
1. VIRTUAL MEET AND GREET (US & UK)

2. DISCUSS AND READ SECTIONS OF WRITING PROJECT - FOLLOWED BY CONSTRUCTIVE PEER FEEDBACK*.

3. DISCUSS THIS MAY'S FILM CHOICE CHOSEN BY KANDACE CAINE:

IMITATION OF LIFE (1959)

ZOOM LINK WILL BE SENT JUST AHEAD OF THE MEETING

*PLEASE EMAIL ME IF YOU WOULD LIKE A CHAPTER, ACT OR SECTIONS OF YOUR WRITING READ FOR YOU. WE HAVE ACTORS AND ACTRESSES IN THE GROUP.

P.S.
I just want to propose in advance that the next discussion might centre around the new HBO series I MAY DESTROY YOU by Michaela Coel. It surrounds issues of consent and thought it has so many issues arising in it that a good discussion might follow. It gives us a month to catch up on via various platforms, Apple TV being one of them and BBC Iplayer for those in the UK. Any thoughts / objections?

Issues raised in I MAY DESTROY YOU include: Consent, Homosexuality, Casual Drug use, Alcohol, Victim Blaming? The list goes on!

title: THE BLACK LIST - SOCIAL HUB FOR SCREENWRITERS
description:
GREAT NETWORKING EVENT FOR SCREENWRITERS!

The Black List expanded our Happy Hours for one primary reason: to create social hubs for writers around the world where they can meet other screenwriters and discuss the craft and the reality of the screenwriter's life.

So join your fellow writers at our London happy hour! Come to enjoy the drinks and the company. You never know who you might meet!

We host happy hours on the first Wednesday of every month

title: THE BLACK LIST - SOCIAL HUB FOR SCREENWRITERS
description:
GREAT NETWORKING EVENT FOR SCREENWRITERS!

The Black List expanded our Happy Hours for one primary reason: to create social hubs for writers around the world where they can meet other screenwriters and discuss the craft and the reality of the screenwriter's life.

So join your fellow writers at our London happy hour! Come to enjoy the drinks and the company. You never know who you might meet!

We host happy hours on the first Wednesday of every month
